headline: Most toxic and poorly managed work area I have worked in
pros: Practice Shield of Mayo is a great place to work to feel good about what you do. I used to work in the Practice Shield.
cons: Information Security (IS) does not share the values of Mayo Clinic. I have heard IS managers mock the Mayo values. Managers in IS do not support employees, they only look out for themselves. Managers of different units are vindictive to each other which makes it very hard on the members of the units to move work forward. No managers have an IS background but they are making IS related decisions. They spread emails in jokes and spend their time on other useless activities rather than doing real workload management and other manager activities. HR protects managers and there is no one to go to. Everyone is simply going along with the disarray in order to not get on the bad side of their managers. There is no room for honesty without negative backlash. The people who actually want to do good work are leaving or looking. The people who want to fake it and be lazy are staying but complain behind the managers' back to others. It is toxic and depressing to work here.

headline: Just meh...
pros: Culture of the unit was amazing! Teamwork oriented. Patient oriented.

They brag about record breaking profits but give their employees a 2% raise. Nursing assistants that had 10+ years loyalty were at the same pay rate as brand new, baby nursing assistants. Same with nurses. The health insurance was meh. $70/month for a $3000 deductible plan.... I've had better. The grass IS greener on the other side. "Mayo Clinic" was a disappointment to my high expectations of premium benefits, pay and treatment as a nurse as they can be the best for their patients, but not their staff.

headline: Job Review
pros: The work itself can be challenging and interesting. There is a sense of satisfaction in working with a team to help patients receive their best care. It might be a good place to work if you're young and just starting out (and don't mind adhering to an extremely strict attendance policy that doesn't allow you to have any kind of life).
cons: I've realized that Mayo Clinic Rochester's priorities seem to be focused more on the needs of the doctors (i.e., their training and research) than on the needs of the patients. If these happen to be in alignment, then that particular patient is given a "red carpet" treatment and may even be the subject of a published journal article; however, if the patient's needs do not contribute in any way to the overall development of the doctors who are being trained here, then those needs may or may not get met - but if the patient complains, they are sent to the "Office of Patient Experience" where their complaints are basically "contained" and dealt with separately (in other words, so the doctors don't have to deal with them). Mayo's other focus seems to be on maintaining a favorable image with the public, which is often in direct conflict with reality (such as publishing articles on how they support equity towards women when they are actually quite misogynistic in practice). In fact, it seems that Mayo Clinic Rochester has focused so hard on research that they've completely fallen behind in practically every other area where other companies have progressed, and have tons of catching up to do. Finally, their new policies toward career advancement require competition and reward youth (and sometimes seniority), so if you begin working there as an older adult you can just forget taking advantage of any opportunities. Realizing all of this as an employee has been discouraging and depressing, to say the least.

headline: false Morals
pros: usually work with pretty good people
cons: even though they say they are non-profit, they are very money driven and motivated. Their motto is "needs of the patient come first", but morally the only care about making money, so if you are a patient with money, you get what you want. If you are a patient without money you get left behind. Its sad that this Mayo legacy of trust and commitment to patients and their care, now comes down to dollars.

headline: Door opener- not career
pros: At one point if you change departments you are allowed to keep your pay or have your pay increase based on your new department pay rate. You can sign up for leadership training with the approval of your supervisor( this does not guarantee any results of having a possible role in leadership).
cons: So I've been there for quite a few years and it seems to be getting rapidly worse. I've seen a lot of abuse of power and covering up as well as retaliation. There are constant threats to terminate people for what is turning out to be any reason. Poor communication. Constant policy changes almost weekly to daily and you're penalized if you do not know these. New hires with little to no experience are being offered higher pay than the current employees that have been there for years. People who apply for one of the Mayo clinics other sites and are hired for the said site but physically sit in another state are NOT being paid the posted compensation on the positions they applied for because they live in another state. Benefits are not the best at all (pricing and coverage details vary depending on which department you work for). You are treated as if you are a child (For example : The "Stars" kids get elementary, an almost exact replica and each "star" means something different) but instead of stars, you get coupons. For Medical Leave, you are only allowed to make up 3 days per quarter (even if your department is still actively working and during business hours they will not allow you to make up the hours ( as if the individual can control whatever medical issues or treatments are required for them; this also varies as to which department you work for. I have learned that you are not allowed to share information with your colleagues even if you think that could keep them out of trouble or things that you guys just may disagree with and may have general questions about. My coworker is a private person and she tried to add her husband to her insurance and their response to her was; pretty much, well you never talked about your husband or mentioned that you had a husband before so we're going to need your marriage certificate as proof. I have been in meetings where supervisors have told several of my coworkers who had general concerns that they should be grateful that they even have a job because of everything that's going on. In addition, the major issue that's happening is if you happen to be on the call or an assignment that runs over or into you're 15 minutes or your lunch, they are implementing rules that if you don't get off on time or you don't log out on time then you completely miss your break and or you only get to use what's left of it (Meaning if you are on a call that runs 5 minutes into your break you only get 10 minutes left of a break or they'll tell you you're not allowed to take your break at all. The same thing for your lunch. If you are on a call and the call runs 10 to 20 minutes into your lunch you are only allowed to take a 50 or 40-minute lunch instead of a full-hour lunch). Everything you do is timed. Everything. More responsibilities are being added without additional allowed time. So if you get a patient or a client who is just so confused and has a lot of questions you only have 4.5 minutes to answer their questions and if it goes over that you are in trouble. You're rushing them off the phone and leaving more questions than answers and you have 3 minutes to note the call in said person's account anything over and your score suffers drastically and threats of termination role in. There is a lot of writing off the wealthy's debt and sending people who are struggling financially and health-wise to collections. It is a very stressful environment. A large number of my team members have announced that they are seeking employment elsewhere. Everything I have mentioned has been spoken out to leadership and though they stated they were going to look into it there have been zero results yet and it has been 2 years of decline. The only response we received is that there will be no active changes in regards to anything I've mentioned above.

headline: Becoming to money focused
pros: Depending on your role you can get paid very well for similar jobs in the area.
cons: The philosophy "the needs of the patient comes first" are slowly losing their meaning. If you aren't doing something that actively make money for the clinic, it feels like you aren't valued. The sisters aren't around to defend that philosophy and I think they would be disappointed to see how it's changed. Will make large donations to "end racism" and make sure it's all over the media but has no issue contracting, the most culturally diverse departments. Removing much of our culturally diverse staff, from the employment/healthcare benefits they deserve. Then 'educate' remaining staff on the issues of minorities not having access to quality healthcare. Which is one of the largest inequality issues in the US. It's abhorrent to see them contract these departments but still lecture about the inequalities in healthcare for minority populations. They could have remained to be part of the solution.

Exclusive, not inclusive, beat down their strongest employees to make them feel worthless. Targets often feel threatened, humiliated by team leads, managers in front of staff. No effort to change, they blame the staff they target, laugh at them and call them "disgruntled employees". Extreme toxic NARCISSISTS are drawn to this institution and become intoxicated with power. headline: Used to be a unicorn
pros: I have worked at Mayo for six years as an inpatient RN. Mayo was the best hospital I could have asked to work at when I first started. The hospital is clean, used to be very well staffed with nurses who really knew their stuff. Mayo has a lot of resources available, such as phlebotomy, STAR RN (ICU nurse who rounds on critical patients), vascular access team (RNs who do central line dressing changes, place PICCs, access PORTs). The nursing staff who work here are overall very nice and willing to help one another.
cons: COVID has been awful for all hospitals; however, Mayo has not supported their nursing staff throughout the pandemic. They think giving the staff a $500 gift card and offering double pay to pick up additional shifts (for a short amount of time, that you have to schedule two weeks in advance) makes up for not giving us any other incentives for drowning with terrible staffing ratios the past six months. They do not care that we are incredibly short staffed and are having trouble giving patients the care they deserve and expect at Mayo; but, they still have no problem sending individual emails to their staff if something was done wrong. They want to say "the needs of the patient come first" any chance they get, but the truth is, they only care about the bottom line. They have lost their respect and appreciation for their nursing staff and they have made that incredibly obvious throughout COVID. We didn't expect things to be easy throughout the pandemic and understand staffing may be short, but Mayo was the worst paying hospital in the area and refused to pay their staff anything extra to help retain staff. Now our floors are filled with travel nurses who have no idea how to care for our patients and who are making twice as much as us. Well done Mayo.

headline: Values are going downhill, healthcare is business afterall, poor management prompting high turn over
pros:
Good benefits package, ongoing support for education within Mayo's growth project, dedicated staff, above average patient to nurse ratios

Great place to START your career, but certainly not to live out your career here.
cons:
Within certain departments, there is a lot of toxic culture. Constant bullying that continues to be unaddressed by their "leadership." Those in management positions are so focused on climbing the ladder, and not actually being there for their people. With high turn over rates, the management team is still scratching their head as to why people are leaving. They do not know how to ask the right questions, and are very elitist in how they manage. So focused on xyz degree, xyz speciality, when in reality, experience and actual abilities should come first.

At the end of the day, regardless of how many years you have served, you are replaceable. They are more willing to replace than to retain. Unwilling to be flexible on things like schedules and life events only place employees in a weird spot to choose their family or their career. High expectations to complete work out of work hours, and little room for overall career growth. 

Care is expensive here. Whether it is because you don't have the right insurance or all providers are booked, it's hard to get in. Seems like the majority of cared for at Mayo are the rich and privileged. Appointments are hard to get - even if your condition is time sensitive...requires patients to leave continuity of care within the system.

headline: Good benefits but unfortunately some bad management

You must clock in and out at precise times and if you are early, you have to wait until your "in" time to clock in so if you are by your desk, you appear to be a slacker to patients. Micromanagement and favoritism, lots of cattiness and spying on through security cameras by managers. Also not much room for advancement and when salary ranges change, you don't get pushed to the top of the range if you were already at the top, everyone else just catches up and makes the same as their senior colleagues.

headline: Toxic working culture
pros:
The campus location is nice and safe.
It's easy to use PTO to take days off in my unit.
Food in the employees' cafeteria is budget-friendly.
A lot of staff work remotely, so it is super easy to find a space in the parking lot.
cons:
Before I worked at Mayo, I thought the negative reviews about Mayo on Glassdoor would not represent my experience at Mayo. Unfortunately, I experienced something that I did not hope for and felt the same pain.

There is insufficient support with high expectations to handle a heavy workload once poor-quality training is complete.

Narrow-minded employees contributed to the toxic work culture in my unit. While I was tolerant of my toxic co-worker for a while, it caused me a lot of stress and anxiety. If you experience a similar situation at Mayo Clinic, do not put up with yourself, because your tolerance may not bring you a positive outcome automatically.

Managers have very poor leadership skills. If you see a high turnover in a team, that's a red flag.

While salary and benefits seem better compared with other hospitals, it is not worthwhile to sacrifice your health and job satisfaction to earn them. The managers claim they care about staff's well-being, but actions speak louder than words.

You have to use your PTO to get your holidays paid.

A lot of backstabbing and ego. To stay humble is not appreciated.

Communication is horrible among different departments.

The needs of physicians and patients come first. Staff may be not treated with respect sometimes. Some doctors are very difficult to work with. While the Office of Diversity and Inclusion sent a lot of messages for diversity and inclusion, I did not feel my work culture was diverse and inclusive.

headline: Great place to gain experience or get your foot in the door
pros:
-Highly professional environment. 
-Good pay even for jobs that don't require a college degree. 
-Good training, excellent classes. Great place to gain a variety of new skills.
-Depending on your department, leadership and culture can be fantastic. 
-Lots of emphasis on diversity and inclusion.
-Patient interactions make work feel meaningful. 
-Mayo (for obvious reasons) supports opinions of real scientists, doctors, and experts, as opposed to lame politicians.
cons:
-No sick days, paid vacation, paid holidays, etc. You have to use your precious PTO for literally EVERYTHING. 
-If you have to stay home because you're sick (even if you have a doctor's note) Mayo considers that an "unexcused" absence and it becomes an occurrence. 
-Some departments tend to hire external applicants just because they have a personal connection to the supervisors or other employees, even if that person bombs the interview. 
-Despite Mayo trying its best to send messages of diversity, inclusion, and tolerance, you'll still get narrow-minded coworkers who scoff at those ideas. (But it all depends on the culture of your department.)

headline: Buddies > Qualifications
pros:
- The pay
- The benefits
- The employer on the resume when leaving the company
cons:
- Too much focus on the buddy buddy system and not enough on the qualifications.
- Incompetent leadership at every corner
- Leadership/Hiring Managers that get intimidated by a candidates qualifications and experience
- Very little room for growth. Too many people competing for the same job.
- Large egos and high pride around every corner being a Mayo employee. 
- Speaking honestly and professionally is frowned upon if the feedback doesn't allign with personalities. 
- Too much dependency on Mayo Clinic being the be all end all place to work.
- Climate fosters obedience over growth.

headline: Corporatized health care, not provider autonomy
pros: Salary, benefits (healthcare, pension), continuing education funding
cons: Mayo Clinic used to be an amazing place to work; however, in the past 4-5 years the workplace culture has taken a dramatic negative turn. Provider autonomy and ability to make the best clinical decisions for their patients has been replaced with a corporate structure of untrained managers dictating aspects of clinical care that they do not understand. Quality providers are leaving in droves because we did not spend hundreds of thousands of dollars and years of our lives on education and training to have no control over our workflow, schedules, and caseload. Nor do providers appreciate being micromanaged to death when we are busy just trying to treat our patients with the best care possible. At Mayo there is much preaching on topics like employee wellbeing, but the culture does not support anything of the sort in practice.

every other weekend, rotating 8 hour shifts, days and evenings. No choice in just days unless you have been working there for like 30 years. On your feet a lot and walking a lot too so must have good shoes.
We are very short staffed and they need to work on making more incentives for their current employees. headline: The money isn’t worth your sanity
pros: Salary. Mayo is not matched by any hospital in the valley as far as pay. The money pays for them to abuse you and get away with it.
cons:
They’ve removed all perks.
Do not listen to employees.
You are just a number, you don’t matter.
Constantly threatened to be written up.
Micromanagement is a theme. Big brother worse than the NSA...so they can find reasons to punish you.
Extremely high turn over in all of finance whether you’re registration, prior authorization, or other.
Lack of opportunities for promotions or moving up.
Over the top favoritism with people completely qualified and educated being passed over for promotions while others beyond fit for the role and are power hungry narcissist are allowed to control, punish, and pick on the weak.

headline: Grass Not Always Greener
pros:
Higher paying facility compared to others in the Phoenix Valley. 
Challenging work, many opportunities to expand personal knowledge.
Patient-centered care with many providers who are abundant in their knowledge, thorough in their assessments, and detailed in explanations of care plans, both to the nurses and patients.
cons:
Elitist, highly political leadership atmosphere.
Since it "pays well," you are expected to eat, sleep, and breathe work 24/7; this creates a lack of work/life balance.
All RN work is highly micro-managed, you are expected to be a nurse the "Mayo way" or no way, even if this does not work in application to direct patient care.

headline: Good if you pick the right Primary Investigator as thesis advisor
pros: Good camaraderie, clinical focus with basic science options, good benefits package for healthcare. Graduate student representatives work with the school administration to address structural issues and the administrative side cares about students.
cons: Many students struggle with mental health with minimal support structures in place. Graduate school itself is understanding, but there is little recourse for a bad PI. Not very supportive of student parents in terms of benefits (no sick child care, daycare, etc.).

headline: Loved it at first, but the Kool-aid wears off
pros:
*Good pay for the type of work I do (especially compared to other libraries)
*I enjoy my work and my department
*Has done a good job addressing racism and discrimination, including weekly conversations with minorities and clearly is trying to actively address these issues
*Handled the COVID-19 pandemic extremely well!
cons:
*No maternity/parental leave (other than the minimum required by law)
*Company recently dropped tuition assistance benefits
*If you don't drink the Kool-aid, you won't fit in
*If you're not in some very specific areas (i.e. Clinical, patient-care work), it feels like you're not important to the organization
*Administration minimizes employee concerns (going so far to call legitimate concerns "myths"
*Feels like organization keeps moving away from the original ideals of the Mayo brothers. Lots of lip service to the values.

headline: Pay is better than most
pros: Pay for CNA/PCT position starts higher than the other big hospitals in Jax. No blood sugar checks, but you’ll do foleys. Learning hospital, so opportunities to shadow. Great cafeteria. Majority of coworkers are cool, easy to work with. Still offer a pension, 403b, partnership with ASU for continuing education, Mayo medical insurance.
cons: New PCTs starting out at higher pay rate; probably same for RNs. HR will not negotiate pay. I don’t understand why hospitals do this, it doesn’t help retain experienced staff. Rare to have 3 PCTs to a unit when I left (November) so usually 14:1 or 28:1 and very unrealistic expectations for patient care/charting. Most of my coworkers were burned out, but I guess that’s becoming the standard for healthcare. You’ll float, feels like it happened every other shift and you’re not being paid like the flex team. Stopped offering tuition reimbursement last August and partnered with ASU instead. Not beneficial for my current educational goals.

headline: Used to like but got screwed over
pros: love my coworkers, intelligent and diverse staff, amazing resources
cons: I got laid off during covid. I was supposed to get $5,000 towards grad school calendar year. I was registered for classes already and ended up having pay $10,000 out of pocket. Mayo rehired me two months later. However, i was no longer eligible for the benefit anymore (have to work there a year continuously). They didn't give me a pay raise because it's policy if you come back within a year to the same position they cannot adjust your pay (i had learned 3 coding languages over the two months i was gone). To top it off I got an accidental letter saying i owed them $5,000 from because i terminated my contract early and had to repay the sign on bonus. Had to call the their legal office and explain I was furloughed.

headline: So-so
pros: Benefits are good- access to great care. Depending on your role and department things can be good.
cons:
It is an extremely oppressive culture. You must do and act the “mayo way” not only at work but out side of work becuase it is preached that no matter where you are- as an employee of Mayo you are a reflection of the institution. Having an opinion and forms of self expression are not well liked. 

The work all depends on your department. There is way too much autonomy for departments to make their own choices regarding things such as PTO and the like. 
I have been a victim of and seen instances of bullying and harassment none of which are ever appropriately dealt with. HR does nothing nor compliance especially when the once doing these things are in any type of leadership role. However if you are a “little guy” you will be chastised for every mistake you make. 
If you know the right people and have the in your career can be fruitful and a walk in the park. If not, you will be stuck doing the lowest jobs scratching until your nails bleed to get anywhere. And even if you know the right people if they don’t like you enough your screwed. 
Senior management is still living in the past and are slow to get on board with innovation and improve quality and job experience for those that work under them.

headline: Just okay
pros: Good schedule for OR RNs, mayo has a great pension with 401 K match, will pay for undergraduate degree (recently stoped paying for all graduate degrees). Pay is comparable to other Minnesota hospitals (they actually make more in the twin cities). Current RN pay is $35.07-$53.69.
cons: Comparing mayo to other top name hospitals I have worked at they are just okay. There health insurance is fair, no maternity leave just STD (not the same), having to use there insurance being a patient here sucks, there OB/L&D unit sucks it’s a complete joke (it’s not there money maker they don’t care). Horrible schedule for floor RNs (always rotating day/night), lots of turn over, people don’t stay. As an RN on the floor you loose a lot of skills (can’t do IVs, foleys, EKGs, they have other people who do that). They do not pay holiday pay because “you can work a holiday and take PTO for the same day”.

Feels like you’re just a number owned by the company/management.

headline: Not bad while here, but poor termination
pros:
-For research, a very good work/life balance
-great benefits (including a fantastic employee only gym)
-
cons:
-My termination was handled very poorly. I received an email sent to me from Human Resources that my contract was ending, and my bosses had to find out my contract ending from me forwarding my email to them as opposed to them wanting to let me go in the first place. This email was also sent only a few weeks before my last day, which apparently is less time than average for a notice of termination. 

-OPART is supposed to be the human resources for postdocs. when I emailed them HR related questions, they told me just to contact regular HR. 

-Parking is Abysmal

-

headline: If you value integrity,  intellectual, and professional freedom, stay far far away
pros:
$ (they do pay you for your soul). Don't fall for that - there's a lot more ways to make money.
Free coffee for doctors
Mediocre art in the patient care areas - though usually the frame job is more valuable than the object, but that's a classic Mayo feature: shiny on the outside, something warmer and stinkier on the inside.
cons:
Conformity is the #1 cultural value. Bureaucratic subordination is #2. Kissing the chair's hindquarters is #3. Not complaining that any of this doesn't smell like roses is #4. Going to long boring meetings in which nothing in particular is decided is #5. Findings ways to squelch innovation is #6. Being the most boring person you can possibly be is #7. Making sure you don't inadvertently make a celebrity unhappy - or someone that someone in the bureaucracy thinks is important to the institution's image - is #8. There are more, but you get the point

What's worse, they say it's all about needs of the patient comes first, but really its all social control of you. It's absolutely amazing how problems in some administrators head turn into grave patient safety issues while real patient safety issues are ignored. You need to give up every shred of self dignity to work in this communist styled dumpster. If you value your soul, if you value your sanity, if you value your own personal safety (no they don't give a darn about any of those things), this is not the place for you.

headline: Occurrences and policies
pros: I loved my job! I bent over backwards for my patients. I loved hearing all the success stories. Loved being able to tell a patient who needs an appointment that I got them one! I loved everything about working there.
cons: Do not miss a day. Do not be late. Do not go to the hospital, er, get stuck in traffic, blow a tire, get stuck on the side of the road, anything! You will receive an occurrence if it is not already approved PTO. I had been admitted into the hospital and I still received an occurrence. Granted I had others a lot of them with Drs notes but again they were never counted. My alarm didn't go off, I was stuck in traffic anything it just added up until I met there termination number. Before I was terminated I was told about a policy that of course was NEVER brought to attention and not something you would think to look up and I was still in trouble for it. I got in trouble for something outside of work and I tried covering it up because of fear for my job and when coming clean it didnt matter. I apologized for losing my intergrity. It didn't matter that I was great at my job and patients loved me. It didn't matter that I didn't think it was any of their business or that if it came out I would lose my job and was scared... Well here I am now because of their occurrences, unknown policies, and because I didn't tell them personal business in fear of my job.

headline: RN joined Mayo at a tumultuous time
pros:
I've worked at Mayo Clinic in Rochester for almost a year now and I have been impressed with how well employees are treated and protected during the COVID-19 pandemic. 
- Benefits include short-term and long-term disability, as well as a private pension plan; bedside nurses are immediately eligible for short-term disability (after a 24-work-hour waiting period) without having to wait a year for coverage to kick in
- Sense of camaraderie and mission at the hospital in Rochester is very much true to the spirit of the Mayo brothers' mission
- New employee orientation included a broad and detailed overview of both history and mission, with explanation of how this contributes to the ongoing mission of the organization
- Working alongside physicians at a variety of stages in their training can be interesting and rich in learning opportunities
- Demonstrated commitment to addressing racism both within and outside of the Mayo organization
-Coordinated, efficient and effective response to the COVID-19 pandemic with early initiation of institution-wide measures to promote health & safety of patients and staff
cons:
- RN pay is not competitive with that of the Twin Cities' hospitals
- Penalties called 'occurences' are incurred if a nurse calls in sick (incentivizing nurses to come to work sick!)
-Nurse scope of practice is very limited in comparison to other acute care hospitals; RNs do not place IVs, perform bedside bladder scans, place urinary catheters, or administer blood products on units classified as 'general care' floors

headline: Reality of Mayo
pros: Mayo Clinic is highly revered and respected with a reputation for being the best in research, medical treatment, and patient care.
cons:
It was the worst experience of my 42 years being in the American workforce.

There was very little training with high expectations to succeed once the inadequate training was complete. 

During orientation and training for the position it was ingrained that "Mayo works as a team, no one person can succeed alone." It turned out to be just a platitude. You 'will' be left on your own to succeed. Unless, you find the right 'cliques.'

The 'higher-ups' in my department were nurses with rotten attitudes who treated me as if I had zero intelligence or knowledge with nothing to offer toward the good of my department. I was an imbecile in their eyes right from the gate. I never stood a chance...

headline: Toxic Culture, Fraudulent Research
pros: Witness the results of a medical non-profit aspiring to be a transnational corporation. If you're lucky, you'll even get to witness patient suicides or deaths in clinical trials, which are promptly covered up by the administration and HR!
cons: Incompetent management, tolerance of data manipulation and fraud, and poor research culture. WARNING: it is difficult to move into academic research after being at Mayo Clinic, as their reputation for poor research and fraud is catching up to them. The downward spiral of Mayo Clinic has begun, and will only be compounded by COVID-19. Get out if possible and stay away if you can.

headline: Good for your resume
pros:
Friendly Environment
Predictable work hours
Needs of the patient come first
cons:
Polarizing (consulting/doctoral staff are on one end of the spectrum, everyone else is on the other end--this applies to benefits, pay, expectations, and treatment of staff). 
New CEO is very focused on $$ and some policy changes/enforcement are frustrating and demeaning
Working there during the pandemic is frustrating and though they are "reducing risk" they are not creating a "safe work environment"
Pay raises are only for cost of living adjustments... you do not get additional pay, credit, etc for going above and beyond. And yet you're expected to go above and beyond while staying within the scope of your job.
VERY difficult to move within the organization
No parking offered to non-consulting staff
Benefits are no longer very valuable as they keep changing for the worse
Work-life balance is terrible

headline: Fantastic benefits, too many politics
pros: The benefits at Mayo Clinic are second to none. Compensation is average as compared to other employers in the area. Telework is an option in most of the revenue cycle positions.
cons:
There is a lot of politics being driven by higher up the chain. They have lost sight of quality because of the drive for quantity.
Moving up in the company is impossible without appropriate paperwork - a bachelor degree gets you moved up regardless of subject matter the degree was in. Management gives unclear instructions about 30% of the time so not everyone is on the same page. Discipline is not fairly enforced and unfortunately favoritism is alive and well in the revenue cycle here.

headline: Health Systems Engineer Review
pros:
- Mayo is proud to be the best and focused on maintaining that reputation so high quality is expected 
- Lots to learn from a top health system 
- Large health system with many opportunities 
- Breadth of projects
- Good work life balance (very rarely worked more than 40 hours per week)
cons:
- Slow to innovate (With reputation as the best they are slow to change and try new things)
- As with many large institutions there are a lot of committees and a lot of bureaucracy. Takes many committees to make a decision. 
- Internal movement is not encouraged (stuck in role for at least 2 years)
- Specifically in ME&IC specialization is not encouraged, all are viewed as generalists and project assignment does not take into account individual strengths 
- Pressure to conform to Mayo Clinic way and become a Mayo "lifer". Constructive feedback is not well received.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Mayo's compensation for nursing staff is tops in the valley.  They truly care about the patients and staff by acuities.  This leads to nursing having greater job satisfaction and not getting burned out with overwhelmed staffing assignments.  Typical shift on med/Surg floor 3:1, ICU 1:1 or 2:1.  There are always plenty of resources around to help out.  You can tell Mayo Clinic puts the money they have back into the facility to create an unparalleled working environment.
cons: The upward movement is slower because people don't leave once they work there.  Pay for supervisors and management could be higher for job requirements.

headline: Nice place to work. Plenty of resources available for staff and for patients

headline: Stellar Diagnostics, Fast Growing,  but Dark Ages Administration (but doing better)
pros:
Good benefits, personal access to some of the world's best medical diagnostics, decent retirement incentives, tuition reimbursement, a fast-growing institution with $4 billion to achieve the stated goal of offering the WORLD'S best healthcare by 2030.  Great real estate appreciation in Rochester.

Exposed to some of the best physicians and researchers in the world, with Mayo recruiting talent from across the globe to achieve their 2030 goals.

2030 goals offer a lot of opportunity for career growth.
cons:
With our new CEO starting just one year ago, administration is coming out of the dark ages.  Today's more modern leadership/management philosophies are steeped in the model of "the inspired employee".   Not so much here - this has been a very traditional top/down hierarchical system like one would commonly see 15-20 years ago.

However, I already see signs of moving in the right direction with our new CEO who speaks regularly about the importance of a joyful and fulfilled workforce, - championing the undeniable basis that the institution will be unable to continue offering the world's best health care if the employees responsible for creating said health care are not joyful, fulfilled, inspired, encouraged.

No employee parking in Rochester.  You will need to find another way to get to work; and winters in Rochester are brutal so waiting at a bus stop is beyond miserable.  But the bus system is good; it's clean and runs just about all over town, and Mayo pays for it.

I was told I would have 2 weeks of PTO first year but NOT told that I would be forced to use these for every holiday AND for every day missed due to an inability to travel (due to bad weather ie frozen streets/white out conditions).  And PTO is slow to build - it takes a few years to build enough PTO to have a decent vacation plus cover holidays plus cover bad weather days.

The Rochester locals, who you'll be working with largely, are courteous, but mostly hail from many generations of farmers.

Extremely difficult for newcomers to build a social life.  Most locals spend their weekends with their families, and they're generally closed-off to "outsiders".

Very little direction is given to the new employee re navigating this large institution's highways and byways.    

Compensation isn't super competitive.

Most employees are stressed out, with more work to do each day than they can possibly do.  But there's a general acceptance of this so you're likely to be "cut some slack" when you can't get it all done - but generally, you need to find a way.  Many non salaried employees work while not clocked in so they can get it all done.  Overtime is either highly discouraged or not allowed at all - but you're expected to get it done.

cons: Just another healthcare organization with none of the esprit de corp there used to be. Robots and the naive, welcome. Independent thinkers and innovators, look elsewhere. Cut throat, backstabbing work environment. Dysfunctional organization that is rotting from the inside. Unresponsive HR. No work/life balance.

headline: Very unorganized
pros: Small call center, benefits, and cafeteria on site.
cons: Very unorganized, there was no training job aids and there was no equipment to listen in on calls. I had to shadow someone but had to wait until the end of the call for the rep to explain to me what happened. Felt like being thrown to the wolves once I started taking calls and I was frequently the only person in the call center. I didn't get a training manual until 3 weeks after I started. My TL was lazy and constantly was taking long/extra breaks. High turnover. Was alot of drama going on between employees.

headline: Great company to work for

headline: Disneyland

headline: The grass isn’t that green
pros: Patient population not as high in acuity compared to other local hospitals. Having the Mayo name on your resume carries weight. Depending on what unit, the culture is different and can be refreshing if your current unit doesn’t have the best culture.
cons: Micromanagement to its finest! I can’t speak about other units, as I mentioned they were a lot different compared to mine. Being acknowledged as a part of the team and not just “the help”. RN’s have that demeanor of “I work at mayo so I’m above all” type of vibe. Definitely a “who you know” and not what you know can go a long way also. Again, this is not for all units of the hospital.

headline: Highly educated professionals with integrity
pros: The vetting process to become a Mayo representative  is stringent. You must have 15 hrs of solid clinical and business experience and value patient care above everything. Peers are of a high moral caliber and collaboration is the underlying culture descriptive.
cons: Salaries are well below industry standard. (About half) PTO is not really your paid time off but dictated to use over holidays.

headline: Opportunity is there, but you have to play the politics game.
pros: Plenty of opportunity and resources for movement and growth. Competitive pay. Due to the amount of candidates looking to work for Mayo, many of the people who are hired are top performers in their profession.
cons: VERY bureaucratic leadership system. Adherence to policy varies from department to department.  Mid level management are allowed to make unwritten policies without board approval and are protected by blanket statements at the end of each company policy stating "or as requested by area supervisor". Disciplinary action is up to supervisor discretion, and can be very unforgiving if they throw the book at you, corrective actions do not fall off for 2 years and it is VERY difficult to move positions during this time.

headline: Some good, some bad
pros: I worked with some great people. My immediate supervisor was great.
cons:
It is impossible to advance within the organization. They really do not hire from within especially across departments for allied health employees.

Additionally, in my department, for the past three years people have continuously  not been allowed to take time off and are subject to constant overtime due to extreme understaffing. Quite a few supervisors micro-manage their employees and contribute to a toxic work environment.

headline: Happy to Be Gone
pros: In the beginning of my career there were a lot of positives working at Mayo. Over time this has changed.
cons: Lab value quantity over quality.  I worked at Mayo for 35 years.  They were at one time a leader in health care. Now they are resting on their laurels and seeking profit over quality of care.  When I called HR to find out my obligations for retirement, I was told, "We say you need to give notice, but for someone at your level, no one really cares."  35 years of service with all positive performance reviews and "no one really cares."  This is probably they best summary of Mayo anyone could write.

headline: Abusive Management - Skip Compliance Hotline - use video on you phone, then get a lawyer
pros:
For me, it is a short commute.
Decent benefits
cons:
Abusive manager- Dept manager that literally cornered a colleague in their cube and was screaming and waving her arms while yelling at the colleague who had no idea what the manager was screaming about. It was as if the manager had gone berserk. Found out later that the compliance hotline closed the report without anyone ever contacting the reporter or the verbally abused employee. 

My advice - skip the black hole that is called the compliance hotline. They will do nothing. Use your phone - have the presence of mind to hit video because even the audio will be helpful and go get a lawyer. 

Very little advancement unless you know someone on the interview team.

Research has lost its way. Do not go on a treatment study. No one in clinical research seems to know how to do their jobs very well. It is all about supporting the pharmaceutical companies and the money they can bring into this billion dollar organization and not about ensuring patient safety.

headline: Great employer but not a nimble organization when nimbleness is essential!

cons: The organization isn't nimble enough; too many layers of approval that delay innovative solutions. Once something finally gets approved, it's no longer novel or better technology is already available. Organization also doesn't understand the unique needs of regional hospitals and clinics.

headline: Need more mid-level jobs
pros: Job security, benefits, pay, networking, opportunity to telework dependent upon one's position and department.
cons: It feels as if many departments prefer to hire externally. They expect a high level of experience for many jobs without providing the opportunity to their current employees to gain that experience. It's really disheartening.  There are a lot of low and high-level jobs, but not much in the middle. For these reasons it can be very difficult for one to reach his or her career goals- especially if you work in an unrelated department.  I do not recommend taking just any job to "get your foot in the door" unless it's in the department you want to be in. This is not a good method and rarely works.

headline: Patient care  experience is unfound elsewhere in the world.
pros: Exposure to complex clinical situations; nursing staff is invested in their role in patient care and advocacy. Fair compensation. Free CEU in-house.
cons:
Management and nursing staffing office consider nurses to be interchangeable widgets on a schedule with vacancies, constantly changing from day/night shift multiple times a week. There is no such thing as a work life balance if you are a staff nurse. There are many "staff satisfaction" surveys, though it would seem that little is done to improve the declining morale among nursing staff. 
Managers face punishment if they provide a reference for current or former employees for career or educational endeavors.
There are few other employment options in the area outside of Mayo, resulting in submission of nursing staff in order to keep jobs. Additionally, management bends employment laws to meet the needs of the company rather than protecting the employee. HR works closely with management with the goal of moving up in the company, therefore employees are not fairly represented when issues arise.
Not much opportunity to attend offered education in house that is not required for position. Management rules with an iron fist - autonomy of thought is not acceptable.
Regarding receiving health care: as an employee, you are triaged to receive appointments last, often not getting an appointment with your primary provider and being told there are no appointments on the available calendar (within 12 weeks). Unfortunately, the city this company resides in is in rural Minnesota, and they are the only available provider for the 40,000 employees and their families. Sadly, the health of employees suffers and health needs are unmet due to the poor management of health resources, rationing of care.
Average new nurse time at Mayo is approximately 18-22 months - meaning within a year new employees have already begun searching at other employers for positions.

headline: Mayo has changed...and not for the better!

headline: The Needs of the patient are the only needs to considered...unless you are an employee".
pros: I loved working with patients on the phone especially since I had 5 years of previous scheduling experience working at the Hospital and ED discharge desk.  I worked for the next 5 years at the Arrowhead Family Medicine office.
cons: Unfortunately, my husband passed away unexpectedly in June of 2015.  This same Friday, my supervisor of 5 years relinquished the Arrowhead site to a former Supervisor who chose to write me up for all my tardies and/or absences that my former Supervisor worked with me on.  I took 5 1/2 months off on personal leave to attend to my 2 children who at the time were 13, and 17.  Additionally, I had my disabled parent living with me and for whom I needed to take care of as well.   After returning to work in January of 2016, and attending the funeral of my mother-in-law.  I was immediately reminded that I was on my first written warning and that any further tardies or absences would not be tolerated.  In August, 2016, my daughter returned to school to start her first year in high school.  She missed her ride and I had to take her to school and sign her in. Upon arrival, my supervisor, Linda Hallett, glared at me and I knew it would probably be my last day.  I workded the entire day that Friday.  At 4:45pm, she called me into her office to terminate me, she put her hands on me and tried to make me sit down to offer me some "resources".  She fired me 10 years to my service month, knowing that not only did I lose my husband, but I lost my mother-in-law in December 2015, My cousin in March of 2016 and My father in law in July 2016.  My daughter was suicidal for the first 6 months after her father died and my 17 year old son did not speak about his father for almost 2 years.  She never gave me credit for the great accomplishments I did achieve in my 10 years with Mayo Clinic and, ironically, she retired 6 weeks after terminating my employment and to top it off...she made me ineligible for re-hire.

headline: Stay far, far, away if you value your license and your sanity
pros:
Some of the staff are amazing human beings

Some of the patients

The critical care physicians and ICU medical staff
cons:
Nursing administration is dumpster fire quality. They could care less about the patients and worry more about inner office politics and how they can make people quit so they do not have to fire them rather than the issues at hand.  The CNO seems to truly cares; however, the level below that position paints a rosy picture to make themselves look good so the CNO has no idea what is truly going on. 

Extremely short staffed all the time on purpose. The needs of the patient do not come first unless you’re wealthy. 

Inadequately trained nursing staff that struggle to make it through a shift because of poor training. The turnover is beyond abysmal. Look how many ICU openings there are all the time. Triple and quadrupled ICU patients at times. That is absolute madness! Not enough management for the number of employees either. 

A culture of bullying and blame/shame game with a “Mutual Respect” facade painted on top. 

Terrible time off. You are given a PTO bucket that is utilized for everything. Sick days, time off, cancellations, etc. 

You are told not to come to work sick but when you call in you’re given an occurrence. We work with sick people in high stress environments, people are going to get sick but we are penalized rather than nurtured.  

Zero pay incentive to succeed. No holiday pay, no certification pay, no preceptor pay. Zilch. Shut up and do what we say or you’re targeted as “a problem” employee. 

Lazy charge nurses are allowed to remain in charge. They sit at the nurses station and micromanage with clipboards never helping staff and do what they have to to look good. 

Extremely high staff turnover?!? Entire units turnover multiple times in one year. Entire units! 

Survey results no longer publicized to protect awful managers so they can make it into administration. You should see how many grievances are filed on nurse managers. It will blow your mind! They promote 20 somethings with minimal experience into management positions. Just because you have a masters doesn’t mean you’re management experience. 

Nurse managers that close their doors when it’s noisy on the unit rather than helping their staff out. They are too good for that now apparently. 

Patient safety issues. 

One could write a book about how awful this place is but it will not change a thing.

headline: Not open to welcoming outsiders at all!!!
pros: Too few to discuss based on the overall circumstances of work.
cons:
I spent  almost 2 years in Rochester MN, therefore I will keep this brief and frank. 

If you are not a local, be prepared to be treated unfairly as if you are an imbecile by locally planted employees  with less education , global experience, and career success  than yourself.  

As a minority with a graduate-level education from 2 top-tiered  (top 20) universities, I was shocked at the level of passive aggressiveness from the Sr. Managers. Most are from nursing backgrounds from local universities who received MBA in management management and have such a disdain towards outsiders it was unreal. Many of them are in locations in NW Rochester (Global Business Services), to the main campus where I saw several part-time GBS nurses transfer to and infect their brand of behavior.  

Not only this, based on conversation I have had with others who worked with mid-to-senior level leadership expressed similar situations.

I simply gave a two-week notice and left this organization for Minneapolis, MN. Mayo needs to work on their internal branding and behaviors of their long-term, well-seated, sense of entitlement local staff.

 These individuals I encountered worked for Global Business Services, Office of Access Management, Human Resources and a few other departments .

Be warned!! There are far too many excellent healthcare facilities that can equally attract and retain top-tiered minority talent without the backlash of the negative behaviors exhibited by the locals with little global experience/leadership. 

I would discourage any person of color with exposure to large global companies to re-think their choice in travelling to Rochester, MN.

cons: Very rigid standards. Medics don’t interpret cardiology they read the machines. Rigid structure and equipment placement policies. The our way or the highway mentality. No personalization of anything. All done according to SOP

care about money
big business
only take care of rich

headline: Medical Secretary
pros: Best place to work.

headline: Mayo Clinic Review
pros: Good pay, nice staff, doctors are nice
cons: No cons this place is amazing

headline: Intern - Science of Healthcare Delivery
pros: I worked at both the Phoenix and Rochester Mayo Clinic campuses. Both are unique in their own ways, but the one in Rochester runs the "city." Opportunities to explore varying medical professions, the doctors are open to allow you to shadow them.
cons: Phoenix Mayo Clinic staff were amazing, however, the ones in Rochester (Science of Healthcare Delivery Department) were a bit weird. They spread rumors and take it to a whole new level.

headline: Medical Transcriptionist/Editor
pros: Great pay.  Quality care.  Patient-centered mentality.  Lots of perks.
cons: (Mostly specific to my department) Inconsistent directives. Disorganization. Budget seems more important than employees. Those not FT don't seem as valued.

headline: Great job, too bad it is being phased out
pros: Telework. Benefits. Feeling of accomplishment.
cons: Not completely direct with regard to the future of job.  They are sacrificing quality and accuracy for money.

headline: Prestigious Hospital Where Pay and Expectations Don’t Mesh
pros: Resources provided , pay, and benefits
cons: Being short-staffed and new policies being implemented without any warning

headline: Paramedic
pros: Great people to work for. Good benefits. Co workers are great. Value education and bettering yourself.
cons: Long hours and not a lot of patient care.

headline: Emergency physician
pros: Love to explore at world's famous hospital
cons: far away from my home country

headline: PCT
pros: worked as a team with nurses and doctors
cons: 30 min lunch break is too short

headline: Was good, job just going away
pros: I believe Mayo Clinic itself is a good place to work and has a good message.
cons: The way criticism was shared was often harsh and belittling.

headline: Physician
pros: Still many caring physicians and nurses in spite of a very real decline in the Mayo culture. However, the Mayo Model of Care has deteriorated over the last decade as “the needs of the patient come first” has been replaced by “the bottom line comes first.” Very sad.
cons: Hard to recognize as the institution I trained at almost 20 years ago. Resources are strained, money concerns have replaced what is best for patients and the quality of care has eroded dramatically. The Clinic in Florida is “Mayo “ in name only. Left after over a decade as a staff position as I could not continue working for an institution which has lost its moral compass.

headline: Great company if you fit the mood
pros: Mayo has a long tradition of great patient care. Many delicates people and good benefits.  It has a lot of the Midwest nice culture but everyone works hard and is trustworthy.
cons: Can be in the box and a bit stuffy.  It is also in a cold place so the wonder can be tough.  Also, Rochester is a small town so there is not a lot going on outside of work.

headline: Great Co
pros: Pay, Hours, Respect, Growth, location
cons: Nothing bad enough to list

headline: Registered Medical Assistant RMA
pros:
Mayo cares just as much about their employees as they do about their patients.  It is a very positive work culture and environment.  

The pay is generous and you get a raise every year.

The employee premiums for medical and dental benefits is super affordable
cons:
Parking at the Phoenix location is  difficult.

Nothing happens very fast at Mayo, everything is decided by committee.  Just filling a recently vacated and much needed position takes many months.

headline: ICU RN
pros: Good support from coworkers, you’re set up to succeed and help patients succeed. Good compensation and opportunity to work extra.
cons: No cons come to mind. This will probably vary by work site. I guess parking in Rochester is time consuming and confusing.

headline: Micromanaging and unsupportive
pros: Great benefits, a very talented team of peers, competitive pay. That’s it, I can’t even make the 20 word minimum.
cons: Chronically understaffed, even at full staffing (which is rare). Leadership micromanages while not comprehending the roles their technicians are in. They watch you on video monitors constantly. They are condescending and aggressively critical. One supervisor openly admitted to enjoying bullying and making people uncomfortable. Frequently unprofessional and inappropriate (e.g., verbally asking staff - in front of each other- to rate an employee on a scale of 1 to 10; pulling aside an LGBT staff member to say Mayo is forward thinking; joking about getting a paper bag when an employee was having a personal life crisis; trash talking other employees). There is no support beyond what the pharmacists and technicians can give each other.

headline: IR
pros: benefits, pay, flexible, opportunity, TA
cons: overworked at times, understaffed at times, long days

headline: Mayo Clinic
pros: Great facility with good benefits and pay
cons: Parking privileges are hard to obtain

headline: Cardiac Monitor Technician
pros: Benefits, Pay, Ample amounts of overtime.  Mayo is always expanding so job security is never an issue
cons:
management avoids conflict and doesn't manage people who need to be disciplined.
Winters are long and cold

headline: Nobody wants to retire
pros: Paid-time off, benefits, colleagues work hard
cons: Management only cares about themselves

headline: Amazing place to be
pros: interdisciplinary practice and collaboration encouraged
cons: location is in the middle of nowhere

headline: Mayo Clinic
pros: Overall good benefits and pay.
cons: Terrible parking if you're not a doctor or haven't worked for the company for 20+ years.

headline: Mayo Clinic Research
pros: Good benefits, great gym available
cons: Parking and transportation to downtown are difficult, especially if working night shifts

headline: LMSW Social Work
pros: Incredible caring culture.  Great benefits and pay.
cons: Corporate and strict work environment.

headline: Great company
pros: Great benefits and pay. Most units have good managers, but a few do not.
cons: Expectations and wages are different depending on which site you work at despite attempts to consolidate. Like all hospitals, it is cutting staff and expects more from staff despite sicker patients. Some managers have enough support for a good work /life balance while others are extremely overworked.

headline: Radiation Therapist
pros: Job growth and outlook great
cons: Parking in Rochester turns some talent away

headline: Great Company
pros: Everything, great work life balance, amazing support from management, and assistance in professional and personal development.
cons: Easy to get lost in the size of the organization, however, this can be avoided through outreach and networking.

headline: Happy
pros: Mayo Clinic is as compassionate to their employees as they are to their patients.
cons: Like other large companies or corporations, there is a moderate amount of politics to navigate.

headline: Mayo Clinic
pros: Decent staff and work area
cons: Sometimes gets a bit hectic

headline: Great place
pros: Great work place benefits package
cons: Middle management can be a bit stodgy.

headline: Experience is highly dependent on what you do and your boss
pros: Mayo Clinic is well known. Great employee gym. Facilities are quite good, lots of cutting-edge medicine is done.  Career opportunities are great in some areas.
cons: Mayo is still remarkably old-fashioned. This can be great for many people in many roles, but can make it an uphill battle for career-minded women to be recognized for your work. The organization is still rather centered around male doctors with stay-at-home-wives... i.e., gym childcare hours, appropriate benefits, lack of sufficient breast pumping rooms in work areas, and lack of formal maternity leave  support the men + stay-at-home-wives well, but start leaving working women feeling unsupported or valued. This is particularly true for women with non-traditional-female careers, such as research. Finally, several women I personally know have run into pure sexism with certain bosses. Sexist jokes about women always spending your hard-earned money that you're expected to laugh at, being told that it looks impossible to make it in research if you decide as a woman to have kids (though men can be parents just fine), and holding maternity leave personally against someone is ridiculous. Beyond that, it took years for HR to finally deal with a research PI who held lab meetings that somehow women are never invited to, took womens' names off of research papers they authored (typically without telling them) and assigned highly technically qualified women basic lab maintenance roles that men are magically exempt from. Why are these types of behaviour tolerated by Mayo culture?

headline: CNA
pros: Pays great, reimbursement for education, very organized, no tolerance for bullying
cons: Very strict on discipline (almost zero compassion for life events), very unwilling to rehire or transfer, mandatory meetings/activities outside scheduled hours

headline: great
pros: I loved working at mayo
cons: managers tend to expect more work to get done than is possible in a 50 hour week.

headline: If you want to be bullied this place is for you
pros: The benefits and health insurance are very good.
cons: They preach a culture of acceptance and diversity but they allow rampant bullying to happen and supervisors all the way up to corporate allowed our bully's to continue with making the work environment more and more hostel until I finally had to quit.

headline: Janitorial
pros: Money, Benefits and that is it.
cons: It is a very toxic environment. It's very classist, clique, closed minded and realize when you go there to work you're putting on golden shackles.

headline: Benefits/pay above industry standard
pros: Benefits and pay are great, so I'm way above the posted high salary. Full pension plus 401k retirement. Adoption assistance. Newer technology and resources.
cons: Bureaucracy. Silos. Top down structure. Don't vet their executives very well.

headline: Registered nurse
pros: Benefits, advancement, opportunity, keeping patients number one always, the unique specialty teams developed for nursing staff
cons: Parking,  majority of younger generation is exttemely disrespectful and judgemental,  mandatory floating to other floors all the time

headline: Hds
pros: Great company to work for
cons: I have nothing bad to say about them.

headline: Loss of values
pros: Patients really do receive exceptional care.  I have sent family members here, and it's amazing to watch.
cons: The culture and values are eroding.  Focus is now on making money rather than advancing a clear mission.  Such a loss for what has been a very special place to work.

headline: Mayo
pros: Great atmosphere, decent food, and kind management

Innovative technology and research

headline: Great place to work

headline: Clinic Utilization Management - Prior Authorization
pros: Very flexible work environment, great work life balance, great benefits, competitive pay for the location, prioritizes patient care above all else
cons: Negative employee morale, unorganized leadership, zero transparency, no formal training, zero communication between separate departments, very inefficient processes, level of understanding of subordinate jobs by upper management is very poor, no new employee on boarding, unethical management operationally, the list goes on...

headline: Toxic Bullyin Environment at all levels
pros: Usually patients get good care

headline: Na

headline: Loyal employer
pros: Great colleagues and benefits. Very competitive pay.
cons: Mayo culture is a bit "one of us"

headline: Postdoctoral Research Fellow
pros: many project opportunities, friendly culture
cons:
high intensity work space
far from major cities

headline: Staff Registered Nurse
pros: They foster learning and growth. Always on the cutting edge. More progressive than most hospitals and lots of resources at your fingertips to make your job more efficient and enjoyable.
cons: Bad work/life balance, a recent increase of nurse-to-patient ratio. Mayo has high expectations of the nurses to go above and beyond, but the increase in patient ratio makes this very difficult. High stress due to patient complexity and acuity. Every nurse is expected to float.

headline: Three Years In
pros: Strong culture - the needs of the patient come first!

headline: The best hospital in US in 2017

headline: Java Web App Developer
pros: Great environment and culture to work
cons: I did not find any cons working here

headline: Inspirational Environment
pros: It’s an honor to work alongside so many colleagues. Everyone truly lives the company values when it comes to caring for patients.
cons: Management has been unfortunately bad. It is a punitive environment where only those who fall in one are rewarded. While this doesn’t apply to everyone, it is overwhelmingly the norm in this “nice” Midwest culture.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Low living cost and light traffic
cons: too cold in winter, too much snow

headline: Visiting Predoctoral Scholar
pros: The graduate school is relatively small (approximately 250 students total), which means everyone knows one another pretty well -- this has its own set of pros and cons -- but fosters a good sense of community overall.  I can't speak for all the programs, but BMEP has an especially wonderful coordinator who goes out of her way to ensure visiting predoctoral scholars are excellently taken care of.  Students are paid for by the program, and not the researcher, so they're generally in relatively high demand. There is a lot of patient data (that Mayo prides itself on protecting) available as long as the correct forms completed and the information is approved, which can really help with research objectives and have quite an impact.
cons: Sometimes Mayo has a lot of red-tape you need to wade through to access data and run trials, but given its commitment to protecting its patients, this is understandable.

headline: Amazed
pros: "Teamwork makes the dream work!"
cons: Sometimes any system is slow to make some kinds of changes at some levels in some ways

headline: Medical Practice Secretary
pros: Great Organization, Awesome Patients, loved working with professionals.
cons: Can be some drama. Try to focus on the positive and the patients.

headline: Administrative Assistant
pros: Pay, benefits. Good employee cafeteria food.
cons: Extremely overly strict management. Overload with work is why they pay more. Managment micro manages and then the co workers micro manage each other.  Extremely unprofessional, corrupted manager, if the manager does not like you she will write you up for anything you said or do every day until your full of corrected write ups to be fired!  Just very manipulating management to the point of dishonesty.  And when the patient is dead please show respect to the family and employees in the hallway and in elevators by putting a sheet over the patient while in transporting!

headline: Understand your work environment and culture
pros: Good benefits and stable job.
cons: Majority of employees like to backstab each other and make themselves look better then they really are.

headline: Work place politics
pros: Close to where I live.
cons: Top heavy management. Mayo leadership has strayed from what the Mayo brothers built Mayo Clinic upon. Employees are valued as less impotant and replaceable at any point of their career. HR will side with management always, therefore, employees do not have any support against work place bullies (such as management or colleagues).

headline: Analyst

cons: Very large company, not very intimate

headline: Great Place
pros: Great Benefits, managers, and the work-life-balance is present.
cons:
Hard to be promoted
Easy to be replaced or moved to another section

headline: Clinical Research Coordinator
pros: Great reputation, however not so great to work there.
cons: Not competitive with pay at all

headline: IT
pros: Everything, great place to work.
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Excellent place to work
pros: Excellent training programs, great benefits and an amazing staff
cons: Can be hard to balance work with your personal life

headline: RN
pros: Every 3rd weekend obligation compared to every other weekend in my previous employer. Very professional environment. Great clinical experience. Higher salary.
cons: So many resident doctors. Cerner software is subpar from Baptist. So many missing. Charting is not organized. Nursing policies are not well established. So much to work on, so many gray areas compared to other hospitals. No core measures in the chart. No holiday pay. Only hospital in Jacksonville that does not give holiday pay. Bad insurance plans.

headline: Registered Nurse, great experience
pros: Pay, benefits, coworkers were great, lucky to have great management.
cons: Mayoisms, lack of autonomy

headline: You can do better than here.
pros: Job security, brand name recognition on your resume, lateral mobility, and semi-frequent raises.
cons: Much of the pay scale is on the low end when compared to other local healthcare organizations + overcrowded parking situation, low upward mobility, backstabbing from management+counterparts+subordinates, cult-like mentality from nearly everyone, very expensive health benefits, no paternity leave, and unpaid holidays for hourly staff (unless you use PTO).

headline: Postdoctoral Fellow
pros: A lot of clinical research goes on in the campus. Very good seminars and research sessions. Brand name is also helpful
cons: Research staff aren't treated well. Ridiculous management policies including full formal wear for laboratory works are not very staff- friendly. Very limited lab space. Parking is a nightmare

headline: Great Organization and Environment
pros: Mayo Clinic offers competitive compensation, an ethical and respectful work environment, and significant training and education opportunities in an innovative environment with talented coworkers.
cons: The benefit package is pretty good except for the health insurance, which I expected to be somewhat better given the organization is a healthcare provider. It isn't that it's bad, but the plan I'm under is high deductible with co-insurance.

headline: Fantastic
pros: Competitive Pay, Career growth and support, Paid Time Off.
cons: Can't think of anything negative

headline: Good place to work
pros: Fair pay, good healthcare, PTO, tuition assistance, opportunity to transfer to other work areas, working for one of the best clinics in the world. If you don't enjoy working here or just don't want to spend your entire career here, Mayo Clinic looks great on a resume.
cons: Only place I've worked that penalizes you for taking sick days. It's kind of ironic when you consider it's a medical facility, and they encourage you to stay home when feeling sick to protect patients. They have started outsourcing some support positions causing major morale issues in those types of positions. The interview process for supervisors often lends itself to hiring the "can sell ice to eskimos" types and not people who can actually lead. This causes a lot of disconnect between leadership and general employees.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: All around a great company to work for.
cons: It is in Rochester, MN..only thing I can think of.

headline: Food service
pros: The pros of working at Mayo Clinic (Food Service dpt.) were, the pay, hours, and the job itself. The environment was so vibrant and calm.
cons: The cons of working at Mayo Clinic (Food Service dpt.) were, really none. I enjoyed everyday i worked, had no problems.

headline: RN Phoenix
pros: Collaborative work environment! Outstanding relationship between all services: providers, nurses, techs, dietary, and housekeeping. The pay is the best in Phoenix and is $4 to $5 more per hour than competing hospitals.
cons: A very structured environment, strict, and may take some time to get used to it, but well worth it!

headline: Strong sense of mission
pros: Patient-focused culture, stable employment, benefits, people
cons: Overly formal culture, hierarchical, slow to change

headline: Excellent place to work
pros: Healthcare benefits, culture, people, resources.
cons: Slow organization to implement change but implements it well when it's done.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Excellent pay, part of an amazing team to take care of patients from around the world.
cons: Mayo does not use a merit system.

headline: My favorite place to work.
pros: Company atmosphere is by far the best anywhere.
cons: Union employees are treated differently. I would suggest not to go into contract with them.

headline: Lpn
pros: Happy to be working at Mayo.
cons: Wish benefits were better for employees.

headline: Development Technologist
pros: Great work environment and culture.
cons: Changes are very slow to implement.

headline: Finance
pros: Great benefits and devoted employees.
cons: Difficult leadership, poor work-life balance, bullying and intimidation by management.  I can only speak for Finance.

headline: Salary info for post doctoral fellow
pros: Nice marble building to look at
cons: Bus transportation is very bad

headline: Pharmacy
pros:
Benefits
Pay
Great cowokers
Work-life balance
Good overall company
cons:
Parking
Location
Big company- difficult to network

headline: Poor healthcare benefits from world renowned healthcare org.
pros: The patients, work environment, doctors, nurses and learning opportunities.
cons: You have to pay for all of your labs. Strep tests, biopsies, blood work, etc. are all paid by you until you reach your deductible, then you pay 20%. Free "preventative" screenings like mammograms are available, but if they find you have cancer during one, it becomes a "diagnostic" procedure, and they make you pay for it. You must go to Mayo Clinic for 1st tier coverage.

headline: Bizarre Occurrence Policy
pros: Awesome place to work and to come as a patient - Employees live the primary value "Needs of the Patient Come First".
cons: Do not plan on being: in the ER, hospitalized, in an accident, delayed in traffic, sick, 1-minute late, family emergency, etc. - unless you notify your supervisor 24 hours in advance, as you will be given an Occurrence. 10 in a calendar year and you are gone. Not a place for employees with children, as they have unexpected, unplanned issues that add up to more Occurrences.

headline: Amazing
pros: benefits, co-workers, innovative health care, compensation
cons: geographic location is not the greatest (incredibly cold in Minnesota)

headline: High turnover, 10 people quit or transferred within 1 year (social workers and case managers). Phoenix campus
pros: Physicians and nurses truely care for their patients. Overall provides quality healthcare. Innovative technology and medical equipment. Multidisciplinary team approach to care.
cons: Employees are overworked and under appreciated, high turnover, salary and benefits are just okay. Rarely have time to take a lunch break. No work life balance.

headline: Great Culture but Cautious
pros:
--Innovation-focused culture

--Helpful and welcoming coworkers

--Diversified development opportunities
cons: --Cautious in investing in new coworkers' development

headline: Clinical Assistant
pros:
Great benefits
Compensation is fair and competitive
Retirement .5 match
Raises are annual
Education covered to further your career at Mayo
cons:
Understaffed
Favoritism
Disrespectful to some employees
Can't use PTO
No work life balance

headline: Graduate Student in Immunology at Mayo Clinic's School of Biomedical Sciences
pros: Good stipend, the people are friendly and want you to succeed. Care about your well-being throughout the program. Time to graduation in the grad school is ~4.5 years, so pretty quick. Great research, cutting edge and very applicable! Lots of great mentors to choose from.
cons: Very high academic rigor rating. Very fast paced program, begins in the summer before other graduate programs. Winters here are long. Not a lot of night life or entertainment...but some. You'll be too busy anyways so doesn't matter.

headline: Good environment
pros: Best place to do post doc . Great great great
cons: Nil nil nil nil nil nil nil nil nil nil nil

headline: Great place to work overall.
pros: Great salary, great benefits, coworkers and managers care about you and your well-being. Low turn over. They have very high standards and will support you to meet them.  Very responsive leadership, even upper management in our department (over 120 people) would always take time to meet with anyone who had an issue. Hires many quality people. Employees for the most part treat each other with respect, no matter their job title.  Working for the number one hospital in the US does give one some pride. Company reputation is outstanding.
cons: Bureaucracy, it felt like an act of congress for anything to change. Long working hours. A lot of nights and weekends depending on your position. Not a lot of vacation for the first few years. When I was there the cafeteria food was a bit sub-par.

headline: Research Tech
pros: Flexible hours and nice facilities.
cons: Odd set-up of manager positions; a co-worker is also your manager.

headline: Easy Job, Terrible Management
pros: Great company, always meeting interesting people
cons: Management was incompetent and constantly made mistakes

headline: CNA
pros: Great benefits and friendly staff.
cons: Required to work holidays

headline: Mayo Clinic
pros: Collegiate minded and clean quality organization
cons: High requirements for employment and advancements within the organization.

headline: Clinical Research Assistant
pros: Good benefit program, access to healthy living center (gym) at reasonable cost, good PTO program
