cons: In the role of Clinical Research Assistant.  No advancement to Associate Clinical Research Coordinator and no pay increase without an Associate's degree if you are at the top of your pay bracket.  There is nothing in between.  Those without a degree who were grandfathered in as a coordinator several years ago fear no advancement opportunities, too.

headline: Dermatopathology Lab
pros: Positive Environment with friendly people, good system in place
cons: The work got repetitive and boring at times due to my position and limited medical knowledge.

headline: Clinical Assistant
pros:
Hourly pay is good.
Benefits are satisfactory, but becoming far less desirable (other compass Ness offer better).
cons:
Lack of diverse environment. You are given an "occurrence" despite the worst of circumstances, there is no compromise. You are treated like a peon and managed by the second. 
Feels like colleagues are out to get each other into trouble.

headline: Horrible staffed hospital
pros: Good benefits and there is really nothing else good to say about this company i an looking for better work
cons: Only pto no sick or holiday pay, never get a full lunch very short staffed no teamwork no help or no advancement

headline: Not a very good hospital to work at.
pros:
They have good benefits, PTO, Retirement, bus passes.
Some coworkers are nice, some are rude and some people are funny.
cons: Very disorganized, there’s absolutely no teamwork, lots of backstabbing, drama and above all, NO COMMUNICATION whatsoever!!!!! Mayo Clinic are WAY too much into themselves!!!

headline: Clinical Assistant
pros: Great work environment and coworkers.
cons: The salary was not negotiable.

headline: Mayo Myth: Perception versus Reality
pros: Good Benefits; Good medical care
cons: No room for advancement; ethically challenging - was told on more than one occasion by management that "there is the right way, the wrong way, and the Mayo way."Speaking from a laboratory operations perspective.

headline: Medical Resident
pros: atmosphere, teaching, facilities,  food, co-workers
cons: small hospital, far, strict, nothing else

headline: Clinic RN
pros: Great environment, professional culture, room for growth
cons: Bureaucratic leadership. staff RN are easily replaceable and they let you know

headline: You can't succeed if you are honest.
pros: A good place to be if you are there looking to just  get by and waiting for retirement.
cons: It isn't a place to grow a career.  Once Mayo have you,  they are focusing on the next person to hire to fill the promotional job that they were dangling in front of you  for the last 2-5 years.  They sing you  a song about career development and career opportunities to get you to do work above your pay grade.  Mayo doesn't believe in promotions, they only fill vacancies.  There are no incentive to work hard. So how do you get promoted you ask? Work on your soft skills. Learn how to suck up. Learn to appear busy.  The phrase "fake it until you make it"  couldn't be more true for this company. The company does not correct or fire anyone; they just  pass them along

headline: RN
pros:
Great, quality benefits for low price
Top quality physicians
cons: short staffed, non cooperative house supervisors

headline: Organization
pros: Great benefits. The purpose of the position is meaningful.
cons: There in the process of restructuring the hospital, mental unit and substance abuse treatment center. The moral is very low. There’s a lack of trust in leadership.

headline: CNA
pros: They offer much training and support to their staff. The pay s also a little higher then surrounding areas. I like the team spirit that the working enviroment has.
cons: There is however a little bit of a higher then you addittude here. All nurses work hard, all students had to work hard to get to where they are.

headline: Mayo RN review
pros:
*Great pay
*Co workers are passionate about their jobs
*Fantastic resources 
* Great opportunities for continuing education
cons:
*In the surrounding areas, there's not as much to as perhaps the twin cities. 
*It would be nice for the 1st tier for insurance to go elsewhere.

headline: Student nurse
pros: They care about their nurses a lot. They are very much about EBP. There are many opportunities to grow.
cons: They have high expectations which is a good thing. I do not have anything else to add.

headline: LPN Review
pros: Pay is decent, benefits are great, helpful coworkers. There are many RN opportunities for those LPNs who would like to advance in their career.
cons: Upper management has unrealistic requests, some other nurses/physicians are very snooty, unrealistic policies; everything unexcused is an "occurrence", even if it is out of your control but this is often overlooked and counted against you in the long run. Absolutely no parking which forces you to take the bus or shuttle which can be a pain.

headline: Mayo Clinic Review
pros: It was amazing and the staff were all so friendly.
cons: I did not feel like I was treated fairly.

headline: Clinic coder
pros: Nothing about mayo is good.
cons: Over worked and mandatory OT. Dont care about employees.

headline: RN
pros: The motto of the patient comes first is true! I'd say the majority of the staff enjoy their jobs at Mayo and it shows in how well we treat our patients. Sometimes we need to treat each other better though (sorry, should be under cons!). I've been an employee, a patient, and multiple family members have been patients, I'd give us a 98%, of course someone has to mess with the statistics! Seriously though, the nurses are treated with respect, the pay for I/P is much higher than ambulatory, but the cut in pay to come to Mayo from Banner was soooo worth it, two totally different companies. Love my job and my department! Education for nurses is highly valued and encouraged, most of our team are either in school for BSN or NP, or see how much we have learned, so they will be starting school once the benefits for tuition reimbursement kicks in-yes, Mayo offers that, does not cover it all, but it certainly helps! There is a ton of opportunities for growth, to be on committees, and to learn from our peers.
cons:
Can get clicky, what do you expect when a field has the majority of female staff.
The management can be political, so one learns to watch their P's and Q's, our voice as nurses has been heard more in the past several years, so overall, depends on who you wind up with as your Supervisor and your OA. There is a reason why Mayo is often rated #1 hospital in many categories, we are EBP, which can frustrate newcomers since change can take time there. But I'd much rather that then just going with winging it!

headline: A great, professional experience.
pros: To be apart of one of the best hospitals in the country and to have great staff helping those in need.
cons: Very competitive and hard to get a job here. You need to have a higher level of experience than most. But it’s a great opportunity for those who want to have the best experience In the medical field.

headline: Triage RN
pros: Can't complain about working Monday-Friday 8-5
cons: Mayo Clinic seems to be more focused on their name then the care of the patient. No equality between all locations despite they state that they are.

headline: Excellent Company
pros: Great company to work for as a clinician. All clinicians not only work in patient care but also research, quality improvement and other area. Good benefits, especially retirement if you are there long term. Patients would often say to me "everyone is so nice here." There is an overall culture of professionalism and compassion.
cons: Progress can happen slowly as the company is so big. New hires beware it may take months to start after you are actually hired.

headline: broken promises, propaganda and lies
pros: it still looks good on  your vita
cons: soul-less money grubbing, work their nonMD employees death -- patronizing toward NPs . No recognition for hard work. Only for years put in.  work 10 and 12 hours for 8 hour salary. inflexible on scheduling. very  authoritarian and conformist  milieu. NPs get none of the many perks MDs get. absolutely wretched, expensive  so called health insurance. pervasive atmosphere of well founded paranoia

headline: Nursing Summer III Extern
pros: Great hours, great support, transportation has been included
cons: would have liked more observation days

headline: Employment
pros: Great pay, benefits and work hours
cons: Management willingness to help or listen to concerns

headline: Expect no change-it’s a man’s world
pros: Good benefits and good pay. Providers are friendly and easily accessible. Work load is minimal and expectations are low. Technology is great
cons: Not as progressive as you would think, no incentive to learn more or excel, the staff is older , typically with BS not PharmDs and on their way to retirement so change is difficult.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: People, Atmosphere, Organization of Training and Onboarding
cons: There really were no any major issues for me here

headline: Varies greatly between departments but overall great company
pros: Employee benefits. Competitive pay.  Great environment for growth
cons: Each department is different, so your experience will depend mainly on your supervisors

headline: inpatient/patient care
pros:
Coworkers, teamwork, pay, well known company

People generally have stayed in their positions for the job security and their coworkers. The pay is good for the area, but not nearly enough for the job being done and the high expectations placed on patient care employees.
cons:
politics, favoritism, micromanaging, budget cuts, scheduling, burnout

The obnoxious understaffing (on purpose) has caused even faster burnout on employees and with strict rules, everyone has quickly become unhappy. They say you get 10 sick days per year, but really you get corrective action beginning with 6. Any corrective action results in held pay increases, no tuition reimbursement for a year, and other big incentives. Minor corrective action receives the same penalties as a major one. There has become no incentive to stay with the company anymore. The scheduling used to work well for students (seeing that probably half of departments are students pursuing education or continuing education that's required) but doesn't anymore and has been increasingly frustrating. 
Many management positions have been given to people based on who they know not their credentials. This causes a lot of upset for people who have worked hard for their higher education and strong credentials but not given a position because someone has a connection to upper management.

headline: Medicare and compliance activities along with trust and gift annuity experience.
pros: Salary and working from home.  Benefits are better then most in the Rochester Minnesota area and it has a high reputation.
cons: Uncertain job future with a new revenue system going in and budget requirements. Human resource tends to work for managers so if there is an issue against a manager that isn’t a legal issues the employee gets moved or let go.

headline: great place to work!
pros: great pay, management listens to employees,  low nurse/patient ratio
cons: no weekend differential,  can't always get a set schedule

headline: IT Unit Manager
pros: Excellent work/life balance.  Small community with significant growth opportunities.
cons: Limited performance based incentives limiting full staff potential.

headline: Not respectful
pros: Mayo name recognition. Pay.
cons: Atmosphere is One that basically says you are nothing, and unimportant, unless you are a Physician.  Management  has no personality. And they don’t care about work life balance. And they make it while knowing that you have no power because you aren’t a position and you  don’t have Sinyard he. There’s zero team environment and zero respect.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great place to work. It is very collegial, smart and dedicated people help patients get better. Employees are encouraged to grow and take additional training and attend lectures.
cons: Sometimes due to the sheer size of Mayo Clinic it seems that biroucracy is slow.

headline: Internal Medicine Resident Physician
pros: Amazing culture, historic, revolutionary, medical powerhouse, research powerhouse
cons: There are no cons here.

headline: Great health insurance benefits
pros: Lots of opportunities to grow within Mayo Clinic if you are working in the clinic. Cutting edge research. People are friendly. On site cafeteria is good and reasonably priced.
cons: Research group is on the background for priorities. Not much opportunity is given to fellows to cross train and learn from other departments.

headline: Financial Rep
pros: Great Pay, Very Professional, Great management
cons: Benefits can be a hassel.

headline: Registered Nurse
pros: The team work, benefits, opportunity for career and personal growth and development, and salary are all competitive and top-notch.
cons: Due to the opportunity of career development there has been a lot of position movement making the work environment feel unstable. This isn't really the case but it gives a little uneasy feeling to working.

headline: A Career at Mayo Clinic Can Be Many
pros: Tremendous opportunity for growth and mobility if you perform in the role you were hired. I was there for six years and had the opportunity to make significant contributions in leadership roles in three distinct parts of the organization. The organization truly cares about its employees. The culture of the organization is to invest in the health of the body and the mind leveraging its Healthy Living Center that started as an employees only facility but has expanded to be used for patient care.
cons: Rochester is a city that some enjoy living in, but it was not for me. The city is really built around Mayo and IBM and IBM is not thriving as it once did so their is a bit of a gloomy environment. Since much of the population is transient, there is clearly some areas that are not well cared for. The parking is horrendous and entry level employees have to bus in from off campus.  The organization has lost some focus on the needs of the patient in recent years through seeking to diversify and I do feel it has been detrimental to the brand.

headline: Arizona site vs Rochester site
pros: Having worked at multiple Mayo clinic sites has been great for establishing invaluable colleague networking.  A great experience.  Things always come up that can circle you back to a former connection which will help you on a current project.
cons: Arizona site is significantly smaller with fewer opportunities.  Parking is ample there which is always a hot topic in Rochester.  Scottsdale and Phoenix campuses are miles apart so consider which campus you'll be working at compared to where you live if you don't want an hour+ commute one way.

headline: RN
pros: Clean, professional work environment. Great coworkers. Free parking. Good doctors. Patient services provide ample opportunities to seek care in the outpatient setting.
cons: Political drama impedes promotional opportunities. Extracurricular involvement in committees provides employees with more power and influence than they should be given.

headline: Registered nurse
pros: Good overall benefits, good docs,
cons: Despite a anti retaliation policy staff are constantly punished and retaliated against under the guise of improper work

headline: It is a great place to start and learn skill sets.
pros: You can get training in almost any specialty and help your career take shape however you would like.
cons: There isn't as much first assisting with so many residents, fellows, and medical students around.  There is a lot of retracting and running the camera.

headline: Working at Mayo Clinic
pros: Great place for physicians to develop and learn
cons: No longterm scope for people who are not physcians

headline: Great To Work For
pros: Great salary, flexible hours, kind, compassionate co-workers, professional environment
cons: major con is parking, also health benefits just average

headline: postdoctoral fellow
pros: Nice city and work environment. Job Security
cons: No good educational institutes in the city.  Not easy for spouse to find many options

headline: Great Place
pros: Super talented professions, super nice people,  great working environment, great benefit
cons: The location is a little remote

headline: RN
pros: Good pay and a great place to work. Good nurse to patient ratio and lots of support.
cons: Did not always have an aide on night shift.

headline: I have worked for 28 years on paying insurance claims
pros: The company has good pay and good benefits. In my department we have flexible hours. I also am able to telework.
cons: The biggest con is communication.  When there are changes or updates it is not always communicated to all areas that should know about it.

headline: Excellent Experience
pros: Great culture. Always team work, working for the best for the patient. Good benefits, with hard work and good resume you can go far in your career.
cons: I don't have bad things to say, more than the cafetería for employees could serve better food. For some people Mayo can be to strict and by the book.

headline: Inpatient rn
pros: you get the "value" of the mayo name on your resume
cons: Nursing administration are sharks and don't care about the staff

headline: research traniee
pros: very comfortable environment, easy to work with my colleagues, great benefits
cons: limited spare resources, cold weather

headline: Best place to work!
pros: Very professional atmosphere, great work energy.  Comfortable salary and/or hourly pay. Great benefits. Has lots of opportunities to grow your knowledge, in fact they even pay for your conference to attend.
cons: No negative reviews from personal experience. I didn't face any cons at this place, it's been a good experience.

headline: Mayo Clinic Jacksonville
pros: Mayo is a great place to work, they are like a family. They are driven to take care of the Patient's needs and not worry about the money. They treat their employees great with benefits starting day one.
cons: Pay is not the greatest.

headline: Credit Resolution Analyst
pros: Enjoyed analytical work, respectful, educated Co-Workers
cons: Management and Supervisor micro-managed, newly promoted Manager, allowed Supervisory Staff to manage the department.

headline: Systems
pros: Diversity and opportunity to transfer to a completely different area.
cons: The size can be a drawback, you can get lost in the crowd.

headline: Wonderful
pros: Incredible institution, very good pay, great benefits, $13000 CME/Travel pay, $2000 to spend on journals etc,pension plan.
cons: Living in  Rochester can be challenging. Mayo is Semi/Pseudo academic conservative institution.

headline: Patient Service Representative
pros: Mayo Clinic displays one of the greatest and prestigious pillars of healthcare professionalism, dedication and hard work for various individuals seeking medical care.
cons: No cons working for the company

headline: Mayo Clinic - IT Software Engineer
pros: Unlike most companies today, as a non-profit company that deals with human health and lives, the Mayo Clinic hires only top-notch people with world-class skills, so you get to work with the best and brightest. Mayo understands that programmers working remotely produces better code, faster, and of higher quality. They actively encourage anybody who can (myself included) to work from home. This creates positive morale. Benefits are excellent, including accumulating PTO that the employee can use at any time for any reason.
cons: There are so many different systems at Mayo that some are using obsolete versions of languages and tools (i.e., programs in 1990's pre-.NET ASP with Access databases and IBM 370 COBOL systems). In addition to state of the art development projects, you will be confronted with maintaining or upgrading older software. This is a job for programmers with long experience

headline: Fantastic support, great place to thrive and grow
pros: Great place to move up, continuous education and learning, multiple resources available to improve your career. Working at Mayo has helped me improve both personally and professionally
cons: I can't think of a con for this company, I have loved my experience in Mayo Clinic in the two years I have worked here

headline: Do it for the benefits!
pros: Excellent benefits even as a part time employee.
cons: Pay is a bit low for the technical skills required/performed.

headline: CNA
pros: Good people to work with and wonderful patients.
cons: Not enough CNA's on the floor working

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Great pay
OT any time
Great PTO
Awsome workout facility 
Tuition assistance 
Great training 
Fertility and adoption assistance
cons:
Benifts are getting worse
Parking is terrible
Easy place to get lost
Not as personal 
Long wait to see doctors for yourself

headline: I love this job
pros: Stable job, good salary, great fellows.
cons: Very stressing, some annoying people.

headline: Great Experience
pros: Great organization for long term growth
cons: Difficult to move up in the organization

headline: Great Company, Amazing Hospital
pros: Great Company Culture, Ambitious Vision, Impressive facilities, Respected Name and Brand, Plenty of Resources for research and patient care. Amazing Gym membership optional with employment for employees and their families.
cons: Sometimes being in a large organization like this can become very bureaucratic.

headline: Great employer, but could use more flexibility
pros: Wonderful benefits, supportive management, excellent work-life balance initiatives like free wellness seminars  and classes and on-site workout facility, tuition reimbursement.
cons: Sometimes not critical enough of long-time employees whose productivity has relaxed. Low morale among some teams due to management not being fair. 24 hour on-call rotation expected in many positions. Unwillingness to hire part-time employees. The waiting list for an on-site parking spot is 12.5 years.

headline: Terrible Pharmacy Management
pros: Great benefits and pay, great co-workers.
cons: No work-life balance (you get PTO but can barely use it in our department) and POOR excuses for/overpaid management

headline: work experience
pros: Nice environment, work culture, friendly town,
cons: Not too many opportunities for growth unless you are a physician/administrator

headline: Creative Careers at Mayo Clinic
pros:
Mayo Clinic is a world renown leader in healthcare - as such, there is a great deal of professional prestige that accompanies any role at Mayo. 

The stability of the organization and it's low turnover are comforting assurances for employees with family commitments or who simply desire stability. 

The Mayo pay ranges are surprisingly competitive and the benefits, while diminished from the early 2000's, are still significant.
cons:
For a creative professional, the lack of creative latitude due to tight branding restrictions and corporate standards can be stifling.

For top-level creative endeavors such as campaigns, rebranding initiatives and the branding of new offerings, Mayo has a history of going to outside resources before looking internally.

While upheld for medical innovation, there is a prevalent and lesser-known culture of resistance to change, new ideas and new ways of conducting business. For those in creative roles, this becomes evident in the day-to-day policy-laden  parameters of the work and the committee structure for approvals.

headline: MRI Technologist
pros: Very good pension, great pay, stable work environment that is basically economy proof
cons: Management is old fashioned, takes a long time to get new ideas implemented, catty behavior among techs, too much work

headline: Benefits are good but the managers aren't.
pros: Benefits are good, PTO is great, health insurance is cheap.
cons: Managers treat you like a number not a person. HR doesn't do anything when you report bullying to them.

headline: Favoritism
pros: Competitive Pay, Health Insurance, You can earn 3 weeks of PTO in your first year, Clean Facility,
cons:
Favoritism is a key issue in my department. If you are not part of the click basically they don't want you to be apart of their team.  If one of their "favorites" brings up a concern to management they always take their side and they don't let you speak. People get treated differently. When you bring up a concern it always comes back on you and you are at fault. 
Parking is very far from the building.
You have to use PTO on holidays.

headline: behavioral therapist
pros: its close to my home
cons: busy, clarity, knowledge, bad referral process

headline: Awesome Company!! :)
pros: I have been working at Mayo for more than 1.5 yrs now and I will say that I am blessed to be working here as the values of this organization matches so much to mine. Friendly colleagues,  supportive team and growth opportunities within the organization are only few things to mention. Great benefits keeps me going forward and looking to many more years at this company. Everyone here is friendly and supportive. My manager is the best manager I have had in my entire career. I am happy and satisfied to be a Mayo employee. Looking forward for more years to come. :)
cons: Don't see any cons yet.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Great Benefits, Lots of opportunity
cons:
Old School Environment
Lack of Parking
Suits

headline: Empty promises
pros: Great co-workers and teamwork.  Also, ok benefits but that will be changing soon, too.
cons: Empty promises. No follow thru and leads you on then pulls the rug out from under you. Ever since Dr. Noseworthy took over it's become all about the all mighty dollar not the needs of the patients or staff.

headline: Lots of hiding behind a good name
pros: Great support from peers, lots of opportunity to be involved in research, cutting edge technology, diverse patient population
cons: Lots of hiding problems, convoluted reporting structure, rely heavily on the name to justify non-standard practices

headline: Patient Service Representative
pros: Flexible hours, competitive pay, good benefits
cons: Poor management and demoralizing supervisors

headline: Love it here.
pros: Compassionate care, brilliant physicians, the best RNs on the planet. Wonderful network of P.A.'s/N.P.'s. Great teamwork by all staff. Beautiful facilities. Good benefits. Patients love coming to Mayo.
cons: Mayo doesn't take all insurance and sometimes it's hard to hear when patients get turned away because they couldn't afford care.

headline: Great place
pros: Great atmosphere and growth opportunities
cons: Long wait for downtown parking

headline: Great Hospital to work at
pros: Very clean, welcoming, top notch equipment, great programs for development, great team work
cons: Anniversary with the company gift card each year-$2.75 card appreciation, not even enough for a meal.

headline: Stabile/Innovative/Friendly
pros:
Job stability with incredible patient care
People really living the needs of the patient credo
Happy employees are friendly and easy to get along with
cons: Culture of safety works clinically but not administratively

headline: I want to work here forever!
pros: Mayo is one of the leading healthcare enterprises in the world and they treat their employees accordingly. I feel spoiled as an RN at Mayo and I hope to spend my entire career with them.
cons: Sometimes it can be challenging to keep up with the ever changing policies and procedures, but they *are* evidence-based and so important to the health and welfare of not only the patients that we treat, but also to he staff.

headline: Not too shabby
pros: Benefits, pay, job security, #1 hospital in the world
cons: Little room for advancement in research, having to deal with patient care oriented culture when working in research

headline: RN
pros: Very good pay, diverse patient population
cons: Terribly boring city for young, new graduate nurses. They are very conservative, and are just getting rid of their archaic computer system for Epic. You can't even park at your own job. You're treated like a number. The nurse residency program is a joke and a waste of time.

headline: Data Analyst
pros: The benefits were not that bad
cons: Better work environment for the employees

headline: Mayo growth
pros: The continuous growth of the Mayo community and the caring of its employees.
cons: Not enough parking for staff or visitors.  Better shuttle service.

headline: You will love it here
pros:
Good hours
Awesome benefits
Good training program
Fun Environment
cons:
Stressful
Long days
Sick People
Lots of them

headline: Excellent employer who really cares about their employees
pros: Outstanding professional growth opportunities, excellent pay and benefits including tuition assistance, health insurance, pension and 403b. Outstanding CEO and culture of "patient comes first"
cons: Corporate environment with many layers of management that make things difficult to move forward at times. Physician led organization with fewer opportunities for allied health leadership.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Friendly staff, Good hours, Great pay.
cons: Working weekends and a lot of mandatory meetings but overall great place to work.

headline: It REALLY depends on where you work within the organization.
pros:
High Salary
Good Retirement
You meet some great people
cons:
Administration
Flexibility with schedule (None)
Administration
Very outdated policies ( They just passed a rule last year that women could where open toed shoes without panty hose... )
Nepotism (Everyone higher up is related to everyone else.  Doctors' wives, children, nieces and nephews, grandchildren, hold positions they are woefully unqualified for)
Administration (In general, the Administration doesn't care about anything except furthering their own agendas and working themselves up the Mayo ladder)  
The Overall culture of Mayo is one that you either shut up and drink the Kool-aid or your life will be hell.  Again, their are pockets of resistance, but you hear more bad things than good.  The turnover rate is crazy.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Great work environment, supportive colleagues.
cons: Harsh winters for a prolonged duration.

headline: Great organization
pros: It's a honor for most employees here and people are proud of working in the world level best hospital.
cons: Not much space to change the management system.

headline: Huge company, fair employer
pros: Always growing. Most healthcare related positions are well paid. Excellent benefits. Non profit. Lots of opportunity for career growth.
cons:
Physician lead organization tends to weaken areas needing professional development. 
Run very much like a government. 
NO parking for newer employees.
Strict dress code.
Most positions require a degree. Higher positions require higher degrees. 
Poor education assistance.

headline: Same name - different organization, values, integrity, and real mission.
pros: Close to work, do receive paycheck.
cons: Lip service, dishonesty to both pts and employees. Riding the name for what it used to be.

headline: Administration
pros: Needs of the patient truly come first.  Great management style.  Very professional.  GREAT benefits.  World class healthcare.  Very detailed.
cons: Because of structured environment lose some individual creativity.  Very "button down" culture.

headline: Informatics
pros: Working for a world known company
cons: Getting too big and forgetting the smaller clinics and hospitals

headline: Perioperative Nurse
pros: Appropriate staffing, awesome leadership, best wages and compensation package in the area. Many opportunities to work on committees and broaden horizons.
cons: Bachelor's in nursing required after hire within a fixed time period.

headline: Pretty good place to work.
pros: Professional environment where you are treated like a person, rather than a number. Good benefits, good working conditions in most departments.
cons: Too much middle management and bureaucracy. PTO is plentiful, but not always easy to use. Promotions can depend on who, not what, you know.

headline: good place to work if you can get on full time
pros: great people, patients are nice
cons: if you are a temp employee there are few opportunities to move to permanent

headline: physician assistant
pros: Great work/life balance. Feel like part of a team.
cons: I am very happy wiith my employer.

headline: Mayo has access to amazing talent and technology, but old-timey attitudes and politics are a major obstacle.
pros: Nearly everybody at Mayo loves their job, which is great for morale.  It is wonderful to work where you have options and resources for your patients. The treatment approach truly does take input from everyone on the healthcare team. It's not just Dr's writing orders. Pay is competitive, and benefits are fantastic.
cons:
Mayo is fearful of, and very slow to any change that's not an instant image booster. If it's not impressive and eye-catching, it's not worth the effort. 

Depending on your position or particular supervisor, not everybody is held to the same standards. Any attempt at clarification of expectations results in "alternative facts" being presented, which is a huge red flag.

Some of the medical staff have an embarrassingly low understanding/tolerance for patients with concomitant social issues, and disparaging comments, even in the presence of supervisors, go unrebuked.

headline: Amazing employer, great people
pros: You learn every day, you work with some of the best people in the world in their respective field, the facilities are amazing.
cons: Can't think of any thing bad to be honest.

headline: RN
pros: professionalism, high tech, education, great reputation,benefits
cons: hostile environment, stressful, poor pay, strict rules, punitive

headline: Registered Nurse
pros:
Great:
1. benefits
2. professional development opportunities 
3. work environment
cons: 1. parking is difficult / time consuming

headline: Great company if you like big business
pros: Incredible benefits, PTO time, and wage right when you start the company. The training is very thorough and the people are great!
cons: No additional income possible except the yearly wage bump. No matter how hard you work everyone gets paid the same depending on seniority only.

headline: Concerning trends
pros: Good benefits and good people
cons: Top down direction from Rochester. No commitment to local communities. Bottom line comes first. Little interest in the concerns of front line staff

headline: Good Benefits
pros: Great benefits, retirement, and insurance.
cons: Low pay and minimal staff.

headline: Good
pros: Great coworkers, great retirement, benefits, physicians, patients, hours, thankful for the wonderful people I work with.  Mayo hires the best nurses
cons: There are not a lot of cons when it comes to this company.  Turn over with management is something I have seen here.

headline: Solid employer. Incredibly supportive, vibrant culture.
pros: Supportive environment. Vibrant community. Flexible work environment.
cons: Limited growth opportunities. Low salary for performance expectations.

headline: Great company with some difficult people
pros: Great benefits, flexible hours, engaging and challenging work.
cons: Many smart, talented people work at Mayo Clinic -- unfortunately, some of people are difficult to work with.

headline: Research fellow
pros: Great working environment, good experience
cons: stability, depends on several factors

headline: If you are ok working for the mafia
pros: Good hours, enjoyed my job, loved those I supported.
cons:
Working for Mayo is like working for the mafia.
It's not a warm fuzzy feeling.
Mayo does some horrible things to the staff it's truly sad. From what I hear, it's about to get worse.
Mayo is excellent at giving minimal raises and bragging to the public on how much they value their employees. BS.
After a raise, they jack up the health insurance at a crazy rate.
Sooooooo happy I got the H out!

headline: Interventional radiology
pros: Great culture, great teamwork, patient centered care. The best hospital I have worked for. Takes care of their employees.  Yearly raises, great benefits!
cons: parking needs to be better for employees, and a gym membership or gym on campus would be nice to have.

headline: Phlebotomist
pros:
Great benefits, amazing supervisors and good working environment .
You learn new things everyday while interacting with providers and nurses
cons: Phlebotomist are under appreciated in lab therefore, go out get a degree . Don't let phlebotomy be your life carer

headline: GReat place to work and get treatment
pros: Great pay, benefits are the best. Minor pension and 2% match roth 401k. Nurse to patient ratio is 1:3 in all areas and 1:1 or 1:2 in critical care
cons: I do not work there anymore

headline: RN
pros: Great pension, Flexible schedule, Work every third weekend, Friendly coworkers, Excellent experience
cons: Low pay, Short-staffed, No holiday pay

headline: Special Project Associate II
pros: This refers to the Research realm of Mayo Clinic Jacksonville. The amount of data and information available to do our work is huge. The healthcare plan and salary packages are great. My supervisor is honest and easy to work with. There are many opportunities to attend
cons: The work is repetitive and tedious at times, so a lot of attention to detail goes into the work. Most of the work is self guided and self driven.

headline: Customer Service
pros: The best of the best
cons: Understaffed thus causing low morale

headline: Cook
pros: Great people to work with
cons: Cant reach upper management when needed

headline: Amazing company.. with a catch
pros: Mayo Clinic is the best hospital in the US for a reason- amazing patient care, real grounding on company culture, and because of it's salary caps limited competition.
cons: Salary based on years working at Mayo, no external experience is considered.

headline: Cultures and Ethics
pros: Great Benefits, Outstanding leadership and Doctors.  Job security, Difficulty getting promoted, Organization promote diversity.
cons: Lower level management and staffs lack professionalism, ethics and diverse cultural awareness, gossip too much, over sharing of personal information.

headline: radiologist
pros: organizational culture values employees contributions
cons: some inconsistencies in leadership strength

headline: Mayo
pros: Good benefits. Company vision is inspiring. Comfortable work environment. Job Security. Leader in providing excellent health care and improving health care through research and advocating for improved health care policy.
cons: Big company with big bureaucracy. Dress code.

headline: Great Company
pros: great resources, get to work with a diverse group of people (culturally and education)
cons: location, winters, there are a lot of bosses

headline: postdoctoral research fellow
pros: great place to work and learn
cons: the only thing is that your work in small city

headline: Your boss can make or break you
pros: No required OT, late nights, holidays, and weekends for non ED and floor staff. Set schedule. Average PTO for hospital. Tuition assistance. FMLA benefits. Great healthcare benefits. Unmatchable high pay. Coworkers become friends and are like family.
cons:
Harassment and bullying from a staggering portion of management.  Bosses that belittle, put down, intimidate you. Lack of opportunities for growth as no one ever quits, when they do management promotes friends over highly educated and experienced members.

Staff terrified to report anything to HR for fear of retaliation from management. Mayo IS AWARE of bullying in the workplace but nothing has changed.

Racists comments I've heard from coworkers about the patients is discussing and unacceptable. I've reported some of these comments to management with nothing ever being done.

Clear signs of favoritism. Employees that should be let go are kept on due to being friends with the boss. Bosses that write up one employee for something and then ignore others that do the same.

headline: Detailed review and analysis of an experienced former worker
pros:
Of a very high quality, with outstanding results that you can only get at the Mayo clinic.
The staff are very supportive and experienced to a high standard, amazing facilities to comfort you when in a predicament.
cons: Very costly, but worth near to every penny, but I shall not dwell over it so all but that is great and a must say perfect.

headline: Appt specialist / PSR
pros: Benefits, patient care is highly specialized and always on the cutting edge.  Specialty dept providers and their staff are "hands on" and available to their patients & their needs.  Respect for Diverse cultures, both employees and patients.  Many various areas  to pursue careers.
cons: Top heavy administration with a Lack of continuity in interpretations of policies from supervisors.  Human resources is extremely vague when pressed for clarifications of policies and typically recite scripted responses to employees when the information is questioned.  Supervisors do NOT treat  ALL of their employees with the same respect...and, unfortunately there are no positive outcomes should the employee escalate their concerns.  They can choose whether or not to enforce policies with employees which is extremely disappointing to watch.  I saw it happen many times until it finally happened to me, after my husband unexpectedly passed away.

headline: RN
pros: Cleanest, best patient-staff ratio, and best salary for new RNs in the area. Longer training periods than other hospitals.
cons: No holiday work bonuses like at other hospitals because, and I quote, "It's a privilege working at Mayo." Like that compensates for getting no incentive to be away from our families on holidays. :\ Be prepared to float a lot if you work on the floor.

headline: Consultant
pros: Good benefits, nice place to work
cons: Salary is not competitive.  Cutting benefits every year.

headline: Software developer intern
pros: Very friendly and chill environment
cons: The place or the location has nothing exciting.

headline: Assistant
pros: It has the most long term employees of any company I've worked for.   For instance, it  is not uncommon to meet employees who have worked at Mayo for 20-30 years.  The work is rewarding even in non-clinical departments where I worked.
cons: Working in AZ, you feel that nothing can be done departmentally without Rochester office being involved.  Any changes takes years to implement.  Not a fast-paced organization.  Many management positions have been moved to Rochester, so upward mobility is very limited if you are not willing to move.

headline: Culture and Politics
pros: Excellent research opportunity, good working environment.
cons: Steep politics and difficulty getting promoted.

headline: RN
pros:
- Competitive pay
- Care is nursing driven and we have a huge voice into what happens at Mayo
- Lots of opportunity to change positions or switch units
cons:
- Minnesota nice is very present 
- Rotating shifts are scheduled sometimes where you switch from days to nights quickly

headline: mayo
pros: Lower patient to nurse ratio than majority of hospitals
cons: political favoritism depending on the department

headline: Overall a good organization to work for
pros: Good career development and continuing education opportunities are in place.
cons: Lack of respect given by senior leadership to front line staff.

headline: RN
pros: Tuition reimbursement is better than most other institutions. Pay is descent for the area.
cons: Impossible to get any time off, insurance benefits for staff is terrible. Spousal surcharge, often denied claims, and charged for common vaccinations. Will work here for 20 plus years and never get parking priveledges.

headline: Great benefits, inconsistent staffing
pros:
Awesome benefits 
Fair pay
Great pension
cons: Inadequate staffing, poor management, hard to advance

headline: Business Analyst/HIMS
pros: Colleagues, great leadership, flexibility,  and work life balance.
cons: No growth opportunities. Do not have any more cons.

headline: Great place to work for
pros: Impact on lives, Infrastructure, Colleagues, Satisfaction, Benefits
cons: Pay for non-clinical workers, bias in support for scientists (non-MDs).

headline: Clinical Research
pros: You work with the best people in the world
cons: Very long hours, skewed work life balance

headline: Enclaves of Good and Bad
pros: Financially stable environment; cogs can feel safe remaining cogs and those willing to do what it takes have some chance of advancing.
cons: Highly political environment with enclaves of in and out-group individuals. While the professional physician staff are a more diverse group, the administration remains a cultural desert. Dominant group ethnics who are also members of the dominant group religion will fare the best. Expect prayers at Staff Meetings as this is a Christian-oriented organization.

headline: Poor Place for Roles Outside Patient Care, Especially Teleworking
pros:
Telework from anywhere in the United States
Passionate culture dedicated to patient needs
Great work/life balance
cons:
Hard to get things done (e.g. decisions, getting a vendor on board, IT needs)
Conservative, risk-averse culture that requires an understanding of language use, dress code and decorum
Managers are promoted within the ranks and are not well-trained to be efficient, supportive managers
Not accommodating of differing time zones 
Required use of VPN for all teleworking activity like email; Access to the internet very poor through VPN
Groups are not as well-trained as individuals in private companies
Many lifelong employees which result in fear of risk and lack of training / growth
Benefits are not great for teleworkers, especially salary and health plans (with the exception of the reimbursement account for vision and dental)

headline: RN
pros: Tuition reimbursement, prestige, staffing to acuity. World Renowned.
cons: Not enough minorities in management and administration,

headline: Anonymous
pros: Clinical staff are awesome. Treat patients well.
cons: Don't reprimand people that don't work. Those that work hard burn out fast picking up slack of others.

headline: Finance Analysts
pros: The company respects employees, values employees and it is a good company to work for if you plan to retire.
cons: It is slow to make any changes or updates within the company. Sometimes managers will not appreciate your work. Because it is a slow pace working environment you can be in the same position for years without a promotion even you have the skill and higher education

headline: Great employer
pros: Mayo clinic culture is very unique. They are family oriented, and so good to their employees. Mayo mission is "the patient comes first" and really is. All together, we are a big happy family.
cons: Parking situation could be better.

headline: Registered Nurse
pros: The culture of Mayo Clinic cannot be found anywhere else you work. Compassion, teamwork, and the patients always come first.
cons: I wish it were located closer to where I live!

headline: Clinical Research Coordinator
pros:
Flex time - work no more than 40 hours per week
Great management
cons: No growth for employees. Senior CRC position is not available.

headline: Planning Services
pros: No training so you have the opportunity to develop your job your own way (for me this was a pro since manager could give no help)
cons:
A lot of immature gossipers are in this area. Some are never given work, so gossiping is all they have to do. Managers do not follow up on any personnel issues.
Since it is an administrative related area, this area does not really get what Mayo is about.
Difficult to be a woman in this area unless you are willing to do some things you normally would not do with the men in the area (and some women are doing that -- seems to pay off for them). Boys club mentality exists (lazy boys club). Employees take advantage of the incompetence of managers. Disrespect is perpetuated because the employees not doing this observe how easily the managers are manipulated.
The good employees end up leaving. The other good employees are looking. So what is left? The IT area of Mayo that supports this area is totally incompetent and makes it impossible to make progress.

headline: Medical, and School (Shields) excellent employment and training.  Researchers go elsewhere.
pros: Competitive pay, Good benefits, excellent PTO.  Reasonable expectations for work load.  Very friendly work environment with an incredibly diverse workforce.
cons: If you are in the Research (shield) there is absolutely no advancement without Masters or Ph.D. if even then.  Parking is an admitted problem with no effort to correct.

headline: Wonderful Place to work
pros: Mayo Clinic has a wonder benefits package. Has the ability to see more unique cases.
cons: The limited parking space provided to employees.

headline: Good Employer
pros: Good benefits. Decent pay. Remote work opportunities.
cons: Business professional dress required (i.e. suits for men). Parking and transportation.

headline: Professional Nurse South-Africa
pros: Very professional and nice dr's
cons: Terrible managers with bad human relations skills

headline: Run Away!
pros: Great senior physicians, great senior researchers, good food, great exercise facilities.
cons: Ignorance, back stabbing, no best practices, low pay.  These are people who vote for Trump, against their employer's best interests, and against the patients.  Ramped affairs.

headline: Only if you grew up around here.
pros: Small city is family friendly.  Mostly stable jobs.  That's it unfortunately. Need more words to meet required 20 word minimum.
cons: First line managers.  Low raises, top out career ladder and pay scale quickly.  Have to leave town if you want to change employers.  No parking for a small city.

headline: Lies
pros: Wages are pretty high in this town, so that's nice I suppose?
cons: I was hired in when the food service department was in desperate need of workers because Mayo had just announced they were outsourcing the department.  I was hired after being told by HR that I would be able to transfer out of the (soon-to-be leaving the company) department into another department in as little as three months.  Now that I am here, I am told by my department that actually I can't transfer for a year..  The only issue being that by the time the year has come around the department will have already left the company; I will no longer be a Mayo employee and therefore can't apply to transfer.  This, among other lies told about the actual job description, lead me to have very little trust for Mayo.  The Food Service department may be leaving the company, but we are the canaries in the Mayo coal mine.

headline: Growing experience.
pros: Leadership opportunities are ever growing but there is a lot of bouncing around of techs. Each new manager has a different style but none of them follow the same protocols.
cons: Weekends and Holidays are a downfall. The pay for my position isn't that high. There would be great benefit in having weekday only.

headline: Materials Handler
pros: The pay and benefits were good.
cons: Management didnt have people skills and they didn't care about safety of the workers.

headline: Mayo
pros: Mayo offers great benefits.
cons:
There are many times where I feel like we work in a "people factory"
Parking is terrible here!!

headline: Mayo research
pros: opportunities, collegiate, surrounded by experts
cons: big departments, overly conservative approaches

headline: Was a fabulous place until the last few years. They stopped caring about patients. The focus became only on money
pros: Long noble heritage.  Used to be the patient came first. Some staff still remain with that belief but most have left or retired
cons: The new top leadership locks patient focus. It's all about money. Bullies are not dealt with but overlooked. This creates a toxic culture.

headline: Mayo Clinic
pros: It is amazing to be apart of world class healthcare.
cons: It can be difficult to move departments within Mayo Clinic.  Especially if you are in administration and not patient care.

headline: Great co-workers
pros: Great learning and work environment.
cons: Not a lot of promotion from within.

headline: Pca
pros: Team work, great support and opportunities
cons: It's hard to deal with my schedule while in school

headline: Pharmacy
pros: Great interdisciplinary people to work with, common goal shared to put the person being treated first
cons: Pharmacy leadership lacks direction and vision; promotion is based on time spent at Mayo rather than actual merit; work-life balance is solely dependent on department you work in, some value it but most don't; IT structure is excellent in some areas but not in most.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Supportive culture in a top notch hospital.
cons: Work week not the traditional Sun-Sat.

headline: It's okay
pros: Everyone at Mayo is pretty nice, but cliquey. Lots of job opportunities, but it is difficult to actually move up or transfer. You have to network to get any where.
cons: The pay is pretty low compared to other hospitals. Mayo doesn't reward or punish employees. The only way to get in trouble is to be late or absent too many times. Its nice if you're a great employee, but they never fire or reprimand bad/lazy employees.

headline: Great people and great work
pros: Wonderful and supportive teams. I work in the IT department and have always felt welcome and great energy.
cons: If you work downtown, parking can be difficult.

headline: Mayo Clinic - a reason to brave the MN winters
pros: A big name company in a relatively small-town setting. Plenty of research and clinical laboratory opportunities. Great environment for a career in healthcare.
cons: Awful downtown parking, but shuttle and public transit available. It depends on your field, but career growth opportunities can be limited.

headline: Mayo Clinic
pros: Mayo Clinic takes good care of its salaried employees, with flexible work hours, and healthy work atmosphere, little overtime, and competitive pay.
cons: You may not want to work elsewhere! Which can encourage lifer-ism and the lack of dynamicism that comes with it.

headline: Patient Experience Specialist
pros: Extremely stable and good pay
cons: Stressful and sometimes ignorant leadership

headline: Consultant
pros: Takes great care of their employees with excellent benefits
cons: Decision making sometimes takes longer than anticipated

headline: Great Company to work for
pros: Mayo Clinc Rochester is a great employer to work for. It always keep its employees best interest in mind while making conscious decisions regarding future growth and development. It is interested  not only in people's employment/career but also in fostering a sense of community and work-life balance.
cons: Maybe the weather can be a little harsh in winter time?

headline: Logistics Associate
pros: very friendly enviroment and proffesional
cons: hours are crazy and holidays are non existent but still a great job

headline: work environment
pros: Very nice and latest technology,clean and decent work environment.Most of the co workers are friendly and cooperative.
cons: Race and politics are rampant,open discrimination against minority and blacks in some areas.Very hard to work independently as writing ups,discrimination,biases and verbal abuses makes every day work impossible  to work.No one care about minority voice.If you are written up by your white co worker even for very simple things,it is done deal you are over! No one care about you say if you are minority or black,the faulty is automatically yours.Some white employees are openly hostile if you don't worship them.

headline: Surgical Services
pros:
Best (ranked #1) hospital in U.S.A. 
Lots of areas to work
decent pay
benefits
paid short term disability
generous with time off during orientation
cons:
lower pay than it should be
politics run the hospital
cutting costs at every corner
Dr is ALWAYS right

headline: The Disney World of Nursing
pros: Amazing resources for new grads and experienced nurses. Great teamwork environment, physicians are respectful of nursing staff and value nursing input to patient conditions.
cons: Sleepy town and high state income taxes. Difficult place to live for college new grad and/or single status. Entertainment is very family oriented.

headline: Excellent ratios, good benefits and pay, cold/small city
pros: Great workplace, friendly people, quality of management varies unit-to-unit, 1:1-2 ICU ratio, 1:2-3 PCU ratio, 1:3-4 floor ratio, pay is excellent compared to national average when factoring in living cost, excellent PTO accrual
cons: Get floated when your unit is overstaffed, a few units are crazy busy while most are reasonable and some are nice, cold climate, not much to do in town

headline: Environmental Services
pros: Love my new job! I like working by myself, and feeling like I really help the patients. Great benefits!
cons: None! I like the atmosphere and the people. My schedule is the only draw back. I'm sure I'll get used to it.

headline: Clinical Laboratory technologist
pros: Benefits and good work/life balance.
cons: Management can overlook what some people do and yet have more of a negative filter towards others, and  only notice the few times you make mistakes and dwell more on it , while others can make the same mistake and they are more apt to be forgiving to that person  or not even call them out when a mistake is made.  One just starts to question their ability to do the job even though they are experienced, while some people can get the accolades and are never verbally and publicly called out on real or imagined mistakes like others are.  They don't do anything when certain people make more egregious mistakes but can discipline other people for the same thing, it doesn't make sense and people notice when this happens.     There is skepticism about the utility of employee satisfaction surveys, people will not be really truthful thinking it will get back to them.

headline: RN
pros: Great working environment, have tools and equipment needed to provide exceptional patient care; very supportive of higher education
cons: Limited options for upward mobility in nursing;

headline: Lab Assistant
pros: They were flexible with my school schedule
cons: We were always understaffed and it caused stress.

headline: RN
pros: Great pay, great benefits, love my coworkers.
cons: Stress levels are high. We take the patients that other hospitals deny, which means they can be heavy, intense patients who are demanding, in many ways, because "Mayo is the best in the world." Inpatient hospital is not a hotel and that needs to be made clear. The patients at Mayo on general care floors can be considered PCU status at other hospitals. Often floated to units where care is so specialized (every floor at Mayo is specialized).

headline: RN
pros: Great health care, ok pay, good variety in jobs, some tuition reimbursement
cons: Management, lack of investment in employees

headline: Great Company
pros: Great benefits, good work-life balance
cons: Things move slowly due to size of enterprise. Lack of opportunities and development for research fellows.

headline: Some great, some not so great
pros: Great benefits, competitive salary, nice campus, great teammates
cons: Constantly changing schedule for half of the team, while the other half is given set schedules, management tends to favor certain clicks, difficult to implement changes

headline: Monitor Tech
pros: Great benefits, great company, great staff, great patients
cons: No holiday pay. No bonuses. No bonus pay for working extra shifts.

headline: Lab Assistant I
pros: Great Benefits. Nice facility. Friendly Employees.
cons: Supervisors are hard to come by and communicate with

headline: Director
pros: Great brand. Excellent healthcare. Good financial status.Some remote positions,
cons: Fast paced. Like other employers, there are some difficult management employees.

headline: The peers are nice. A beautiful and serene place to work
pros: At Mayo Clinic, They take care of you. They work with you in any situation. Patient Care is their top priority.
cons: There really aren't any cons. I can't think of one negative possibility at Mayo Clinic of Florida. The doctors, medical staff and other staff are just phenomenal at Mayo Clinic Florida.

headline: If you like bullying this is the place for you
pros: For the most part the work environment is pretty good, pay was decent and diversity and inclusiveness are big goals there.
cons: Management was no help with a lot of issues the overall theme was "deal with it yourself"  I was bullied by my immediate co workers for over a year and my numerous pleas for help to my supervisor were blatantly ignored. I even went to local and then Rochester HR for help who all told me that I wasn't being harassed and they wouldn't help me.  I saw this happen to other employees in other departments and they got the same treatment from management so they quit.

headline: Research Technician
pros: Awesome company, great work environment, great people, great culture. It felt great to work towards improving medical care for different patients.
cons: I don't have any complaints about working at Mayo. As you can read in the Pro's above, I had a great time working at the hospital.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great benefits and good pay
cons: Expect people to do more on less can be a challenge at times

headline: Clinical Assistant
pros: Work with excellent doctors, nurses, and other allied health staff. Patient needs definitely come first in my department. Nice employee gym.
cons: Very short-staffed, which can hurt patient care. Supervision is lacking, which causes a lot of issues. Parking situation is not ideal - especially in the winter.

headline: Great place for a career, avoid communication with management
pros: Many opportunities, innovative care approach, generally very helpful and kind staff
cons: Management, staff tend to form cliques or groups, parking and a focus on doing whatever is best and fastest for the company in resolving issues or problems.

headline: Occurrence System
pros: Mayo Clinic is the best place ever to work when it comes to caring for the patient. The "needs of the patient' truly comes first. I see it every day. I've worked here a very long time and have had the opportunity to move up as I furthered my education. It is a place that encourages you to better yourself and supports those goals.
cons: Mayo Clinic has a very bizarre absence policy. If you are an hourly employee and are one minute late for work (even if no past issues) - you receive an "OCCURRENCE". If you wake up sick with fever and call in sick - you receive an "OCCURRENCE". If your plumbing or A/C  or car broke down and you call in that you must meet the plumber, electrician, mechanic etc. - you receive an "OCCURRENCE". If there is an accident on the road and you run late due to the traffic jam - you receive an "OCCURRENCE".  After 6 "OCCURRENCES" there are formal consequences. "OCCURRENCES" drop off after a year has gone by using a 12 month rolling calendar. 10 "OCCURRENCES" and employee is terminated.

headline: Stable
pros: Stability in terms of salary and job
cons: Career mobility not heavily available

headline: Research at Mayo Clinic
pros: People are kind and helpful
cons: Bad weather and slightly conservative research

headline: RN
pros: Coworkers, friends, education, resume builder, PTO, staffing, resources, hours available, pay
cons: Can't schedule vacations because you have to request months in advance and then the schedule is posted only 2 weeks before, sometimes later, so you can't book anything like a cruise or airline travel. If I could shout on a mountaintop these words, to reiterate some of the other reviews on here about corporate hospitals, mark my words now: It's just another hospital!!!! It's hospital inpatient nursing! Nothing special about this place at all, not from the RN's perspective.

headline: Post doc fellow
pros: Great environment with many different specialties, scientists are hard working and dedicated to their success.
cons: Smaller academic setting than large universities

headline: Great place to work.
pros: World class leader in healthcare.
cons: I consider travel from one regional site to the next difficult and overly time consuming.

headline: Genetic Counselor
pros: Like the company focus on the needs of the patient.
cons: Culture can be rather stiff and focused on protocols.

headline: Great before change
pros: Great coworkers with excellent supervisors
cons: They outsourced the food and beverage operations

headline: Watch your back
pros: Most of the staff are great people.
cons: Management is only in it for themselves

headline: Needs of the employee come last.
pros: Pay, hours available, coworkers, education, experience on resume.
cons: If you died, they would call your family and ask why you didn't communicate better why you weren't at work, even if they first sent a death certificate well before the shift started. I am not joking. Bad health insurance plan, too for the best hospital in the country.

headline: Awesome
pros: Best environment and respect for employees.
cons: I can think of none.

headline: Great Culture
pros:
Great culture of teamwork
Benefits and compensation packages
Relocation Benefits
cons: Location- its cold in MN

headline: All that glitters is not gold
pros: Excellent compensation & benefits package (but be prepard to work 24/7 & from home for them), beautiful facility, overall positive small town friendly atmosphere despite size of campus and number of employees...just about everything you could want from an employer
cons: Focus changed from taking care of patients & employees to focus on the almighty dollar. Motto "Needs of the patient come first" apparently does not apply when the patient is also an employee. Too much administrative involvement..."took over" from the needs of the health care providers.  Immediate supervisors have too much power and vary in adminstration of rules. An issue could be overlooked by one supervisor and the VERY SAME ISSUE could be written up as a serious offense by a different supervisor.

headline: Fair compensation, Good benefits
pros:
Compensation
Benefits
Innovation
Mission
Annual raises  
Advancement opportunities
cons:
Still hold some archaic values, probably due to age of patient population
Space is very limited in the lab, as is true for many hospitals
Disrespect to the medical lab scientists and phlebotomists by nursing and providers, also common in other clinical environments

headline: research
pros: very good place to work and live.
cons: none, very good place to work.

headline: GI Tech
pros: Great Bunch of people
cons: pay not commensurate to work

headline: IT
pros: Great pay and good benefits, most of the people you work around are great. looks great on a resume
cons: Management plays games, decisions are made slower then a snails pace, groups that look for people to throw under the bus for their own enjoyment and or to draw attention away from their own work related mistakes/shortcomings. the PTO is a joke, it really only covers holidays and not much else.  Dress codes are archaic, it's not the 50's anymore. There's a lot of cons. It seems like it's a great place to work but not really

headline: Great Place to work
pros: good benefits, lots of opportunity to move up and/or switch departments to better yourself
cons: Some employees are kept when they are incompetent and should be let go or re-trained, but instead they get they same raise that I do every year.

headline: Mayo Clinic Scottsdale - Research
pros: Lots of information about the company offered at monthly all staff meetings. Yearly reviews with supervisor. Opportunity to take classes if wanted. Many science talks at campus.
cons:
No opportunity for pay raises other than possible annual (all staff) raises. Make sure you negotiate your starting salary well! 
All federal holidays etc. are paid for with PTO. Only 2 sick days counted into yearly PTO which means people come to work sick. If you want to see a doctor, you'll be using your PTO. 

Also, Mayo Clinic expects you to work AT LEAST 40 hours a week as a full time salaried employee, there is no flex time, thus you may be giving the company 5-10 hours of work weekly with no gain to you. 

Poor 401k match.

headline: Better then most
pros: Best pay and benefits in Rochester Minnesota. You would need to move to the Twin Cities for better pay. Would recommend
cons: As with any big company it is easy to feel lost. Things move at a snail pace. Takes a long time to fully accepted as another Mayo employee.

headline: Registered Nurse
pros: Work environment, continuous education, coworkers, and benefits.
cons: Located in Rochester, MN which is a bit isolated.

headline: Great Vision, Great Company Culture, Great People
pros:
#1 Hospital (U.S. News and World Report ranking of top hospitals)

Great co-workers and leadership

Trusted and premier destination for regenerative medicine and surgery, which has potential to revolutionize medicine.

Excellent Healthcare ( They truly care about patients and always put patients first)

Safe place for employees and patients

Nationwide (Rochester, Minnesota, Florida, Arizona, and Mayo Clinic Health System)

Collaborative Decision Making ( slower than usual but ensures things are properly vetted and consensus is reached)

Talented researchers, Education programs and Clinical Practice

Working towards better diversity and inclusion programs
cons:
Increase raises and competitive benefit packages so that top talent are retained and not poached away by other companies and hospitals.

Increase speed of decision making.

Parking sucks in downtown Rochester but Mayo Clinic offers complimentary bus service and park and ride to some locations.

headline: Great Employer
pros: Collegial atmosphere, great benefits, small town lifestyle (in Rochester) with big company perks.  Free bus passes, event discounts, and you get to contribute to a truly world-class healthcare institution.
cons: Small town life (Rochester) may not be for everyone.  As MC grows, danger of losing some of the personal touch that made MC what it is today.

headline: Training Program Coordinator
pros:
Excellent organization values that align with personal values.
Teamwork
Great pay and benefits
Opportunity for advancement
cons: Very large organization.  Can be hard to get foot in the door.

headline: Employer
pros: Stable position but many policies.
cons: Very political, do not bite the hand that feeds you.

headline: Mayo Clinic Health Systems
pros: Mayo Clinic Health systems provides competitive pay; good retirement/health/dental benefits; Mayo is a well-respective organization; and there are plenty of hours available to staff.
cons: Rolling schedules that change every 2 weeks for hourly employees makes it difficult to plan family get together or vacations in advance.

headline: Lab Assitant
pros: Great Benefits, Friendly co-workers, flexible schedule, opportunities to move up or acquire more responsibility, learn new skills on the job, friendly management, employee reviews leading to small raises
cons: There weren't a ton of downsides aside from the town. Eau Claire has a lot to offer but is smaller and wasn't really where I'd want to live.

headline: RN
pros: They foster good relationships between the nurses and the practicing providers. The pay and benefits are excellent. Many different types of positions available. You can literally work in area you want. Plenty of opportunity to grow. They foster education and working your way up the ladder.
cons: Parking, no parking unless you have been with them for more than 15 years, you have to bus in or find other options. Units do not have all the same rules, one unit can self-schedule, another can't for example.

headline: I absolutely love my job as a cna at Mayo Clinic!
pros: They have the most supportive staff of nurses and doctors!  The work as a cna is super fulfilling and I couldn't ask for a better work environment.
cons: Sometimes, twelve hour shifts can be overwhelming especially if done back to back.  Working a full day shift and then an evening shift is difficult.

headline: RN
pros: Excellent organization in which patient care truly does come first and colleagues are high quality team players
cons: Management can be, at times, inflexible.

headline: Nurse Practitioner
pros: You work with some of the smartest people in the healthcare industry.  The company is focused on research and education, which positions you to learn a great deal.
cons:
You don't get paid penalty rates for working holidays. 
The board of directors prolong the decision making process.  
The pay appears to be below the regular rate.

headline: staff rn
pros: Compensation, patient ratios, friendly staff, good cafeteria, good parking, professional development opportunities, high pay for precepting, clinical skills advancement, supported by management.
cons: Medical benefits, some micromanagement. Honestly there is not much I can say that is bad about the job. I just thought the coverage for medical benefits was poor compared to other hospitals.

headline: Respiratory Therapist
pros: The staff is very friendly
cons: none that I can think of

headline: Network group
pros: Very flexible and always a new challenge.
cons: Micro manage and don't listen to employees suggestions

headline: Clinical Research Coordinator
pros: I've been working for more than 20 years in various fields.  This is hands down the best company I have ever worked for.  Compensation is excellent and they really want their people to succeed and be happy.  That reflects in how we care for our patients and each other.
cons: There can be a large workload so you have to prioritize and use the many resources available that are available.

headline: Biomedical Technician
pros: Sharing of knowledge across the Mayo enterprise is very good. There is also a strong possibility that you can travel the nation to work.
cons: Mayo talks about integration of the health system sites with Mayo in Rochester but often it feels that Rochester is dictating to the rest of us. Not everything that is okay in Rochester is okay elsewhere. It's also common to get into trouble for having an alternate opinion to that of mother Mayo.

headline: research fellow
pros: Great people to work with. very nice working environment
cons: Rochester is a kind of isolated place

headline: Pharmacist
pros: Very professional environment with very smart co-workers
cons: Can be very intense work enivronment

headline: Good Place to work
pros: Experienced People with strong work ethics
cons: Very political and difficult to accomplish changes

headline: Dedicated group
pros: Lots of dedicated people who put the patient first.  Everyone works hard and strives to meet expectations and goals.
cons: Ultimately, Mayo is a business and decisions are made based on this fact.

headline: Innovative Culture Centered on Patient
pros: Cutting edge organization committed to doing what's best for patient care.  A collaborative team culture driven by data and results to discover new medical treatments, processes, and procedures.
cons: None to share at this time.

headline: Intern
pros: Great culture with caring people
cons: Housing is expensive so start searching early

headline: Limiting
pros:
Many learning opportunities
Possibility to change healthcare for the better
State of the art facilities
Beautiful campus
cons:
Administration is overbearing and micromanaging 
Poor leadership
Poor long term planning
Poor change management
Limited advancement opportunity
Mediocre benefits

headline: Project Manager Consultant
author_position: Executive Administration Project Management Healthcare Analytics
pros:
Number one rated hospital in the world
Collaborative decision making
They retain employees very well
cons:
Long commute times
Wages can be lower in their small size geographic market

headline: Top Ranked
pros: Top ranked culture of excellence where the needs of the patient come first
cons: All US healthcare systems are lethargic and archaic

headline: Registered nurse
pros: Great flexibility and opportunities. Great nusing input in policies
cons: Sooo large, beaurocratics, no parking,

headline: physician
pros: excellent colleagues, support from management
cons: not much really if you ask me

headline: Meaningful work at this healthcare facility
pros:
Employees are valued
Benefit package is competitive
cons: Healthcare reform makes working in this industry full of uncertainty

headline: Nursing
pros: Professionalism and world renowned medicine.  Clean work environment and state of the art equipment
cons: Top heavy with nursing management and administration.

headline: Account Service Rep
pros: Family atmosphere, great benefits and compensation, willing to work with you if you have family issues going on
cons: having a supervisor/ manager located in a different state off site

headline: Was better
pros:
Good work/life balance
Decent pay
Good benefits
cons: There have been many changes in pharmacy over the past year or so. A new leader came in like the new sherrif in town. Many people who had worked there for years quit or transferred. Leader is full of himself, thinks he knows better than everyone, and completely ignores his teams knowledge and experience. Quite disliked, but doesn't realize it or care.

headline: Excellent
pros: Excellent place to work. Working around patients makes you feel like you are helping people. You are surrounded by very competent and friendly people. Rochester has a nice small town atmosphere.
cons: The city may be a little too small for some and it can get very cold in the winter.

headline: Unbelivable place, out of this world
pros: Working with the biggest names, all under one roof. no big egos. This is as good as it gets.
cons: Cold weather of Rochester if you are not used to it. Spouse needs to be employed, otherwise may have trouble at home due to small city. Nothing bad about "The Clinic".

headline: The worst work culture I've worked in.
pros:
- Mayo collects some extremely talented staff.

- "The needs of the patient come first" is the mantra.

- Rochester, MN would not be what it is without the Mayo Clinic (#1 employer)

- This is a good place to start your career if you are from the local area.
cons:
- Minnesota nice (Passive Aggressiveness) reigns supreme at the Mayo Clinic's Rochester HQ.

- If you are an employee and a patient, you don't get treated like a pure patient. Cash in hand is key.

- "Mayo is a transnational corporation", not a non-profit.  Those words were spoken by the CIO in a 2015 department meeting, much to the surprise of the staff in attendance. Mayo is being converted into a corporation by C suite suits, where the bottom line is more important than anything else.

- Cronyism is rampant in certain IT/IS support areas. Talent/potential < Years of service/carrying water for management.

- If you don't drink the Kool-Aid, you will be benched. Mayo wants subservient employees, not free thinkers.

- Whistle blowers are targeted and persecuted. Regardless of what you are told in Orientation, do not blow the whistle until after you have everything documented. Even then, it's best to stay anonymous until after consulting a lawyer.

headline: Biostatistics Intern
