pros: I got to work with very smart people and I got to learn new skills and network. Also got the opportunity to sit in meeting with senior level statisticians and consult on a few cases.
cons: It's a lot of sitting down and sometimes I didn't feel as though there was enough to do. But everyone is helpful and kind and they are always willing to find something for you to assist with.

headline: Research Trainee
pros: Great people to work with as well as nice competitive environment. The food is great yet no stipend for food.
cons: They pay their research trainees NIL; not a single penny so you have to be able to financially support yourself which is not easy to do.

headline: Health Systems Engineer
pros: Mayo Clinic is a great name. A lot of employees have been at Mayo Clinic for a long time
cons: The department is currently going through changes and management isn't able to manage the current and future state.

headline: Lab Tech
pros: good training and overall a good place to start your career, decent pay as well.  People are great and there is always changes; mostly for the good
cons: you work long shifts, and shifts no one wants starting out, it is hard to get days off, and the pay could be better

headline: Great company
pros: Great place to work staff is friendly and everyone works hard because mayo compensates very well.  Always has the best equipment and is always innovating and leading the way in new medical research
cons: Starting to move some job services to contract company's and killing the culture of mayo

headline: Benefits, Stability, Pay
pros: Good benefits for family. Job stability if you keep out of trouble. Pay is average or above average for many jobs.
cons: Operates a bit like government in that things take time, layers of approval and sometimes political maneuvering. Limited advancement.

headline: LPN clinic
pros: Great patient interaction and nice facility
cons: Very routine and repetitive. Not challenging

headline: Terrible for research
pros: Can't think of any in all honesty. One positive is that you may have access to working with clinical data than working at an academic environment.
cons:
Mayo is run by MDs so basically to get hired as a PhD "professor" (just a title no one really teaches anything) you have to fit in rather than be a robust scientist. As a result this place is littered with sub par PIs who have no clue how to manage their post docs / conduct quality research / or hold best interests for post docs. Why? Well because there is no tenure here so a post doc becomes a sponge that needs to be squeezed of all resources so that the PI can show progress to their supervisors. In academia a tenured professor doesn't have such pressures and as a result quality stands out whereas at Mayo they are under pressure to get grants and produce (regardless of quality) so post docs are sent on fishing expeditions to get some data on some preliminary study so that a grant can be written.

Plus there's no academic environment such as seminars or sharing of ideas. It's a very desolate environment if you're a PhD.

People talk about benefits a lot here but honestly as a post doc I can't even afford those benefits so it's terrible for that too.

Overall if you're a PhD stick with academia. This is no place to advance your career.

headline: Senior research scientist
pros: Multidisciplinary environment with great physician-patient-research cooperation
cons: Limited growth in research field

headline: great place
pros: Pay and benefits are superb. Pay is greater then average for every field. Benefits include small pension and 2% match to 401k/403b, Roth 401k option.
cons: none at this time i can think of

headline: Lab assistant lead
pros: Recognizable name and reputation for future employment opportunities
cons: Treated like a number because it is so big

headline: Nice Place
pros:
Its convenient.
Benefits even for part time employees
cons:
Short staffed
Rooms are old and need updating

headline: Postdoctoral fellow
pros: Good place to work
cons: small city to live in

headline: An amazing place to work in
pros:
Great support for staff, particularly learning opportunities
Great benefits; medical, tuition reimbursement, career advancement
cons: Bureaucracy makes it difficult to effectively keep up with competitors

headline: Wonderful place to work
pros:
Mayo provides their own insurance and so my monthly premiums are literally a fraction (25%) of what I was paying through my previous organization.
Compensation is good.
People are really friendly to work with.
There's a lot of growth taking place over the next 20 years as Mayo builds the DMC (Destination Medical Center) in Rochester, which will add new facilities, an overhaul of the downtown landscape, and new jobs in the community.
cons:
All decisions are made by consensus, new employee onboarding takes months, new projects aren't always readily available so you often feel like there's not much to do (but the projects will always come). 
Mayo also has a specific way of doing things so there can be the conventional thinking that can bog down the need for change process.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Great benefits
Competitive pay
Decent work/life balance
cons:
Advancement opportunities limited
Laboratories are very specialized here. If you like working as a generalist, look elsewhere.

headline: Great organization with lots of opportunities!
pros: Brilliant colleagues and many opportunities to really contribute to the greater good of patients.
cons: Challenges in navigating large organizational structure with little transparency from department leadership.

headline: CNA
pros: Patient Ratios, salary, Caring environment, teaching hospital! The doctors, nurses and all staff are so knowledgeable, but they also are not arrogant. They do not mind when you ask questions, and are always willing to teach!
cons: Honestly i have worked at Mayo Clinic for 5yrs and i have nothing bad to say about it!!! i would not want to work anywhere else!

headline: Decent
pros: Flexible schedule, decent pay, great supervisor
cons: lots of travel, need a bachelors for anything

headline: Sr. BI Solution Developer
pros: Good company to work for..
cons: Not as such. It's bit far from Minneapolis. You have to live to get the full benefits..

headline: Administrative assistant
pros: I loved my job until the work differently initiative i was moved a few floors up to support doctors (ph,d) and lab supervisors.
cons: Entitled consultants. Hostile work environment. Secretary/Admit asst will be the first to weclome you and throw you to the rabid wolves. DLMP is not friendly, it is how can it please the consultants, directors. Management will not back you, consultants first. Lack of training,  with a constant reminders that you are replacable. Respect is another word for submission and poor work performance

headline: Registered Nurse
pros: Amazing environment and work space. Very structured environment so there are clear expectations for your work quality and quantity.
cons: No cons that I can think of. However Mayo is very structured so if you do not like a lot of rules this is not the place for you.

headline: Good Pay But Bizarre Environment
pros:
Salaries are good especially since Rochester has fairly low cost of living.  Free bus passes were nice too (there is basically no parking in downtown Rochester.)
Rochester is pretty pleasant and offers more services than you might expect in a town its size.
cons:
Very unwelcoming corporate culture...  it's the Mayo Way or nothing.   The organization seemed incapable of ever admitting that it makes mistakes.    Also as an employee you are forced to use Mayo as your health care provider and they don't handle routine care very well.

Their dress code is archaic and arbitrary.  No visible tattoos or piercings allowed, and in the non-patient care departments men must wear ties, women must wear hose (I think that last one was recently relaxed),. etc.

headline: Medical Assistant/Phlebotomy
pros: Good place to work if you lucky to end up with a supervisor that does not take sides within employees, and be fare and equal to everyone in the department.
cons: Working in a big place like that brings a lot of different personalities and some times that can be a conflict if your not one of your supervisor "favorite".

headline: Good place to work, facing some challenges
pros: Good place to work.  Fair pay, good benefits, opportunities to move between departments and to advance positions.  The tuition reimbursement has been a big help to my family.
cons:
Starting to become more political, so if you vary much from the political attitudes of leadership you feel kind of like an outsider.

Very much moving towards a "do more with less" attitude, and not wanting to staff adequately.  Also we've started to outsource lots of jobs to other companies, so employees are losing their benefits.

headline: Assistant
pros: Great benefits and fitness facilities
cons: Passive aggressive employees, need more trainin

headline: Consulting for Mayo Clinic
pros: The Mayo Clinic staff that we worked with were very nice and complimentary of our work. It was a great experience, overall.
cons: The Mayo Clinic staff that we worked with did not have clear goals or a clear budget to work with when they came to us for consulting.

headline: Medical Supply Technician
pros: Good benefits, lots of career advancement opportunities
cons: You get penalized for missing work when you are sick or have a sick child.

headline: Intern
pros: Great support for SLP intern. Learned a lot from all professionals in the rehab department.
cons: Unpredictable schedule of clients, but to be expected in an outpatient setting.

headline: Rn
pros: Good management fair and helpful
cons: Benefits have deteriorated,  poor salary in jacksonville

headline: Challenging
pros: Quality of Care, Brilliant Physician/Researchers
cons: Micromanaging, Lip Service to work-life balance, Bureaucratic, Little Opportunity for Advancement

headline: Clinical Assistant
pros: Mayo Clinic is a great place to work at. This was my first job out of college and it was an excellent experience!
cons: The supervisor I had was not the most helpful or beneficial to my growth as an individual, however that is my only con to the company.

headline: Certified surgical tech
pros: #1 in nation, history prestige
cons: Union ,no accountability, no support from leadership. Since #1 rating will be forced to work with even less so that we can maintain #1 at expense of employees

headline: Mailperson
pros: The job was the best job I ever had. Good pay and hours.
cons: No respect towards employees, bulling and harassment by employees and management. Lying by management. Human Resources cant or wont answer any questions and allow the bulling.

headline: Mayo Clinic Review
pros: Working at Mayo Clinic has given me great experience with the best patient care in the world and a clean work environment. Mayo also has the best all-around hospital staff than any other company. I have previously worked in other hospitals, but I have been at Mayo for almost 10 years and would not want to work anywhere else.
cons: There are not many. However, we used to have amazing benefits but they have since been cut back. Sometimes the work load can be stressful, but most of time it is not.

headline: Sr. Advisor/Consultant
pros: There are so many dedicated and inspired employees -- highly engaged people, with a passion for caring for patients. Beautiful facilities, and a lovely community to work in.
cons:
Very hierarchical.

Very committee driven, and slow to change.

headline: Analyst
pros: Great pay, hours and benefits
cons: Leadership takes forever to make decisions

headline: MT
pros: Close to home, nice day shift hours
cons: Low side of pay scale

headline: Respiratory therapist
pros: I love my co workers and my job.
cons:
Upper management doesn't know what is really like to work on the floor with patients. They just stay in their offices for the most part.
I refuse to believe that all Mayo Clinics are run as badly as this one.

headline: Hospitalist
pros: Excellent place. Loved working here
cons: No cons I can think of

headline: Exceptional Management - Team Oriented
pros: Mayo is one of the most team-oriented companies I have ever worked for.  As someone who came into their position with limited experience, they did an excellent job training me in and answering every question that I had.  I feel very comfortable working for Mayo and their culture is phenomenal.  Everyone I work with is dedicated to providing the best care/service that they can.  As a part-time employee, Mayo also is very accommodating for my schedule.
cons: This is not a 'Con,' but expectations are high.  Be ready to meet and exceed them with one of the best medical organizations in the world!

headline: Summer Intern Review
pros: Really good work life balance. Not as pushing as imagined. People are typical mid-west people, plain and kind-hearted.
cons: The whole place is in the middle of nowhere. You can literately walk from one side to the other within 30 mins.

headline: Fantastic place to start your career and your family
pros: Fantastic mission (to care/cure others) that drives the institution. You can live in a small city (100,000 people) and have a 5-10 minute commute. The cost of living in Rochester is low and there is a major metropolis (Minneapolis/St. Paul) 80-90 minutes away, including a major airport.
cons: The institution is very risk averse, which makes it slow-moving. Mayo provides little vacation days (3 weeks/year is what you get when you start). Compensation is significantly lower than in other companies. Left due to lack of opportunities for promotion.

headline: Ct technologist
pros: Good, professional working environment. Departments do a good job of managing up. Good starting wage and benefits.
cons: Below average pay for long term employees and those with advanced education. Longevity is not financially rewarded. Career advancement is difficult.

headline: Nutrition Associate
pros: Great staff members. Great benefits if your are a Mayo employee.
cons: After being told by HR that there was a 99.9% chance  our department would NOT be outsourced. They indeed did outsource our department. Also with the new company they said our jobs and benefits would be "comparable". This is not the case. They have been extremely shady while handling the process. Even not allowing managers to tell new hires that they will be outsourced. They have gone against the Mayo Values.

headline: Physical therapist assistant
pros: Getting high education is available
cons: Only health career educations has sponsorship

headline: Don't work here
pros: Reputation of the place is good, so it looks good on a resume. Honestly can't think of any other good things to say about the place. Coworkers were nice. Manager was rude and hostile and lazy.
cons: They don't really care about their employees unless you're a doctor. Don't get hurt there or they'll fire you, especially if the injury is a result of their negligence. Managers are not trained, therefore they don't know what they're doing and treat underlings badly. They make many mistakes and cover them all up. They double up the workload when people retire and don't hire any new people. My manager gavel essential work to her favorites and she spent much of her time doing shopping online instead of training people and doing her job.There is a lot of turnover here. Don't work here !!

headline: Nurse Manager
pros:
supportive working environment
many resources available
cons: Many opportunities for staff, many leave for further advancement, so in constant hiring mode.

headline: RN
pros: It is a very good workplace environment
cons: Lot of hours if you like to work overtime

headline: mid level management, RN
pros: competitive salary - no more or less than surrounding hospitals.  Great HR; fair and consistent with all employees.
cons: Became too focused on "big business" aspect, and less on quality care - not unlike other healthcare systems.

headline: Very Good
pros: Good place to work.  Very professional.
cons: Jobs seem to be very competitive.

headline: Meh
pros:
~Good salary, decent benefits
~Great job for those who have figured out how to put in the least amount of effort and get the same pay as those who are productive.
~Nearly impossible to get fired. It truly is a slackers paradise.
~Tuition benefit is great. When my graduate degree is awarded I will be looking elsewhere.
cons:
~Impossible to get ahead unless you know someone or are a person they poach from the outside; very slim opportunities for those who think they can work there way up - it pretty much doesn't exist. 
~Can be equally qualified for the same job (or have slightly better qualifications with specialty certifications that meet the department requirements), but if you don't know someone from the hiring department you won't get an interview - or you will get the courtesy- we have to interview 3 or 4 people even though we already  know who we are going to hire interview. 
~Foolish business model, for example rather than deal with the problem, they recently created an entire department to "project manage" (i.e. babysit) one area that wasn't producing. 
~Quickly get to know the people most likely to throw you under the bus and avoid them if you can. Every department has at least one, some have "gangs" that do it just for entertainment.

headline: A good place to work
pros: Working for a company that is well respected throughout the world.
cons: Living in Minnesota. Employee parking is a nightmare. Mayo can be a very rigid and strict environment in which to work.

headline: Great company
pros: Really nothing bad at all to say about this place! It was absolutely fantastic on so many levels. I highly recommend working there.
cons: I can't think of a single thing that would or even should be improved because it was such a great place to work.

headline: Scheduler
pros: Great benefits and salaries, paid time off offered.
cons: I have worked for this company twice the first time I worked for them five years and I resigned I should not have gone back I horribly forgot how management could be and Human Resources is NOT there for the employees. Biggest mistake I ever made was to return to Mayo.

headline: Some good, some bad
pros: Benefits, such as salary, PTO, tuition reimbursement are decent. Mayo clinic is a renowned facility.
cons: Work load is heavy and getting time off is very hard. Managers can make a unit great or horrible so hope you have a good manager. In last 5 years, have come to realize the mayo clinic is a business out for money

headline: CNA
pros: its a rewarding opportunity to work with other people
cons: its time consuming and working twelve hour shifts sometimes can really get you

headline: Great place to retire, not a great place to grow, especially outside Rochester MN.
pros: Stability, Good pay, work life balance, benefits better than average (but getting worse quickly), horizontal movement, a very big company.
cons: Saving Rochester Minnesota is the top priority at the detriment of the other smaller sites. Rochester is a city of less that 100,000 people, 40,000 of which work for Mayo. It is an anomaly and Mayo does't seem to understand their other main facilities in large metropolitan areas may be the future of the company. They are actively moving more jobs out of the other campuses to Minnesota in some strange effort to save the 150 years of heritage in the frozen wasteland that is Rochester. There is a multi billion dollar plan to make it a "Destination". I am sorry, but no one wants to be anywhere that is negative 50 degrees f. Small thinking and self preservation is strangling the once great Mayo Clinic.  My 15 year IT career ended because I wanted to grow in the company, but unless I wanted to stay at the job I was in I had to move to Minnesota to be anything above a worker bee. Management and above are all being forcibly moved to Minnesota.

headline: RN
pros: pay, benefits, career opportunities, tuition reimbursement, medical knowledge, educational opportunities
cons: parking ability, location, Easter not recognized as a holiday, scheduling issues.

headline: Junior Data Scientist
pros: Great work experience, rewarding work flow, simple projects, and creative outlook.
cons: Crazy work schedule, balance between work and life is difficult, and improvement of life medical care is slow.

headline: Courier
pros: time goes by pretty fast and there isn't a lot of micromanagement within the department
cons: pay could be better and there isn't much room to move up within the department

headline: Amazing organization
pros: Quality care for patients, well staffed, supported by staff and doctors, amazing management.
cons: Can't really think of any

headline: Research Affiliate
pros: Great learning environment. Got to learn how hospitals function.
cons: No complaints, helpful with the data I needed for my project

headline: Lab Employee
pros: Love the set schedule and the not so heavy workload
cons: Mutual Respect is supposed to be a policy here but the RN's act like children and cant wait to tell trying to get people fired versus being grown ups and addressing whatever the issue is.....Way too many politics. Not sure if the RN's are taking out on allied health professional what they get from the Physicians. RN's need way more education on test they inquire about because anywhere else some of their questions are no brainers.

headline: CNA
pros: Great company to work for, opens the door to many opportunities.
cons: Scheduling is sometimes difficult if you are a attending school at the same time.

headline: Houskeepingpro
pros: Provide good benifits and pay
cons: I have nothing negative to say

headline: Is Mayo still as goo as they want us to believe?
pros: I used to like working at Mayo Clinic also, but something bad is happening there.  I do not know what it might be, but even the physicians are leaving.
cons: I do not know what Mayo is doing to get rid of employees including physicians, but they seem to be leaving in droves.

headline: Rough place to work
pros: Benefits are good, including disability and retirement
cons: Overly demanding, treats many employees horribly, no work/life balance

headline: Patients come first, doctors second, students next, and scientists last
pros: The true focus and message of the Clinic is to improve the lives of our patients.  This is a heartfelt message that resounds.  There is fantastic interaction between clinicians and scientists that have led to important discoveries.
cons: If you are a scientist, prepare to be considered a second-class citizen.

headline: Great organization and grest people
pros: Very accepting environment. Team oriented. Varied job tasks. Free computer training and other job training. Great benefits.
cons: Not always enjoyable to follow all the added requirements of a health care organization.Some tasks were boring and repetitive.

headline: IT Auditor
pros: Good place, patient care comes first. Innovative Health care services.
cons: The weather in Rochester not too Okay.

headline: Jacksonville, FL
pros:
Mayo Clinic Rochester has consistently ranked the #1 and #2 hospital in the nation. The other clinics carry the name brand and try to deliver a comparable degree of health care service. 
I suppose Mayo is generally selective with their applicants, so most of the time, you will get very bright, competent staff, ie, your management and co-workers. I have had a varied experience here. It really depends on the people, like any place. But overall, Mayo staff seem committed to quality work. My one complaint would be the office culture in certain places. Just certain things, not all. People can be unprofessional or treat their work as a social hangout. :\ I had a co-worker who complained and bad-mouthed the patients every two minutes, which is understandable sometimes, but, all the time? It's so bad for morale. The bulk of people are pretty polite and kind, though. They do their job sufficiently enough. The doctors really care about their patients. 

Other pros:
403b
Health
Dental
Vision
Continuing Education Courses offered online/on-site - You can schedule these into the workday
Benefits University sessions are offered every enrollment season
Tuition Reimbursement - I hear this is mainly to go towards positions Mayo has a serious need for
Beautiful, well-maintained campus
Cafeteria food is A+. There is create your own stir fry Tuesdays and pasta bar Wednesdays
Great starting positions open up every year with chances for upward mobility
Chapel - Catholic 
Meditation Room
Ticket discounts for Jacksonville Symphony and other attractions
Various employee discounts including cell phone carrier & gym memberships
cons: Office gossip, co-workers complained, patients expectations unreasonable due to the "Mayo" brand experience - can't make immediate appointments for services, long wait times, this is a popular hospital

headline: RN
pros: Fulfilling, cutting edge, world renowned
cons: Does not pay as well as the competition.

headline: Great Place To Work
pros: Stable Company. Management overall is nice to workers.
cons: Stagnant Jobs. Very few opportunities to promotion.

headline: Declining concern for employees
author_position: I Am A Nurse With 22 Years Experience, 7 of Which Were At Mayo Clinic
pros: Teamwork approach to patient care. Good benefits (that were once excellent) including health, life, dental, and disability insurance. Paid time off. Fraud protection. Education reimbursement for the right people. A diverse population of employees from around the world.
cons: I was at Mayo clinic for seven years. I only worked in one of many departments at Mayo Clinic. There is a strong emphasis on education. Most management positions are filled based on education as opposed to their ability to do the job successfully. Obtaining further education is promoted as long as it does not interfere with the job. Employees are "coerced" into conforming with employer expectations or they are pushed out. Independent thinkers are seldom encouraged. Employees with mental health issues are not valued as individuals. The programs established for employee well being are geared towards encouraging employees to conform or quit. Parking is a big issue.

headline: Laboratory Assistant
pros: Good people to work with.
cons: Only cost of living raises given, not for years of service or performance. Benefits get worse every year.

headline: Admin assistant
pros: Benefits are stellar. Some work/life balance.  Cafe is overall healthy and offers great options.   It's ok, though the training period is long and drawn out.
cons: Can only use Mayo providers if utilizing their insurance. I get why, but wait times are long for appts. Dept. hired too quickly and there is not enough work to do. Should allow employees to transfer earlier than a year in, if wanting to retain them.

headline: Nice place to work
pros: The benefits and environment are rewarding and encouraging. They work pretty hard on making communicative easy, open and respectable to co-workers and from management.
cons: It's hard to feel supported with short staff situations. It is hard to find the information you need without going through numerous people to find the answer. Sometimes it is hard not to feel like a number.

headline: Staff nurse
pros: Fair wages and benefits are offered.  There are opportunities for advancement as long as you have your BSN.  You need your  MSN for management positions.
cons: The "Needs of the Patient" are not the priority here.  It is the budget.  Staffing is often shorted on the inpatient nursing floors despite the availability of staff.  Most nurses do not get their coffee breaks and many times the lunch break is shortened or not possible.

headline: Finance
pros: Flexible, good regard for personal/family issues that arise.  Great to be a  part of a company saving peoples lives
cons: Environment changing drastically with changes in health care.  Must be adaptable to daily changes without employee input

headline: Registered Nurse
pros: Love what I do, Love the nurse patient rations, usually 3-4:1
cons: I have no complaints after 6 years

headline: A Highly Political Organization
pros:
Great benefits
More resources as in manpower and supplies compared to hospitals in the area
cons: Keeps employees who are not productive.  Too many committees when solution can really be simple.  Forgets about the people who do the real work.

headline: PCA
pros: Good pay, busy work, good employees.
cons: low sick days, absents, scheduling

headline: What's behind the curtain?
pros: Great benefits and work life balance
cons: Leadership cares too much about the bottom line. It's like the need of the commercial payer patients come first. Poor access too.

headline: Is it healthcare or corporate America
pros: Not many, if you want a paycheck that won't bounce this place is it. There is no shortage in revenue.
cons: "They" try to tell you it's about patient care but actions speak louder than words. My pay was cut 25% because "they" said it didn't fit the mayo pay model. After over 20 years of working for and being paid by mayo my retirement company match contribution was cut, " they" responded by saying "but we gave you a pension" only problem is no credit for 20+ years of employment and we started at day zero. After push came to shove it was admitted they couldn't afford it, don't tell me it's about patient care. B as in B, S as in S !

headline: Postdoctoral Research Fellow

Basic research arm of Mayo Clinic seems underdeveloped. Very clinically focused (a pro and con).  
In research, teams are largely not defined by projects, but by expertise.. which can lead to disconnect among members working on projects together. 

Very top-down structure.

headline: Mayo Clinic

headline: PAs are treated like medical assistants
pros:
The pay
Potential resume builder
Pension (if you really want to work here for 30 years)
I'm supposed to write 20 words, hopefully this is now enough...
cons: PAs, as well as ARNPs, are expected to know as much as the Physicians, however are treated like we are the bottom of the totem pole. So we are good enough to do the seeing of their patients, assess, diagnose, treat, etc etc, but then when it comes to doing all the scut work, that is also our job. We are not treated with the appropriate amount of respect when it comes to anything, other than being trusted to (depended on to) do all of the patient care. But then when a patient needs to be called for a simple message (secretary or MA task), your patients vitals need to be taken (an MA task), something needs to be faxed (secretary task), a form needs to be entered in the computer (MA, CNA, or secretary task): the PA or NP is also supposed to do also do all of that. So basically, mayo sees all "APP's" (as they like to call us) as first year residents who the Physicians can unload all of their work on to, as well as can be used for clerical and any other task that needs doing. If you are a PA or an ARNP and are thinking of joining Mayo, keep in mind you will have no ancillary staff to help you, as is the case in the rest of the non-Mayo world. You are the ancillary staff, in addition to being expected to keep a full calendar of patients. Get ready for zero respect from the physicians. If you happen to go in to a surgical subspecialty, you will be delighted to see that between getting to the hospital at 6 am to "pre-round" on all of the surgeons patients before he/she gets there (read: pretty much do everything for the surgeon while he/she is either sleeping or in the "consultants only" lounge, rounding, getting to the OR before the surgeon, doing the assisting in the case, helping at the end of the case, prepping for the next case (it is now 2:00pm), you are not allowed in the surgeons lounge. The surgeon, and whatever other consultant who may chose to also accompany him or her, is free to grab whatever free snack and water or juice and watch some TV while you hold your pee and prep for the next case. Eating? Resting? Going to the bathroom? You haven't earned those privileges as an APP at Mayo. Oh, and by the way, you can create all the revenue you'd like with your full schedule, charging almost the same as the physician does and getting paid a quarter of that, but you are also not allowed to park in the garage. So you, Physician Assistant or Nurse Practitioner, can park out in Timbuktoo in the middle of whatever weather elements there may be and walk about a quarter of a mile a day to get to work while the physicians park in their designated spots in the garage, and get there after you do and you've seen their first patient.

You will get your hand slapped for silly things like wearing pants that don't quite reach your ankles (for females) or for wearing a casual zip-up sweater, even if your office doesn't have heat and you sit in a locked office all day not seeing patients once.

headline: Frustrating: Needs of the patient come first?? Not so much....needs of your employees? Beyond Last.  I didn't matter....
pros: Pay was ok, insurance and benefits, good.  Cafeteria benefit and discount was good, you could put your lunch on your account, they'd take it out of your check.
cons: I worked in registration/scheduling in Mankato.  The nurse team within cardiology was downright brutal with the bullying tactics, and management did NOTHING.....abuse was common from the cardiology RN nurses, and they laughed if they made you cry.  Again, registration managers did ABSOLUTELY nothing. Plus, they made it difficult to transfer out, most likely due to the fact they didn't want anybody else finding out about their abuse.

headline: Great company

Interesting and valuable work.
Many different laboratories to choose from.
Great Benefits.
Encourage Diversity (not applicable to me.)

headline: General Surgery Resident
pros: Good operative experience, friendly staff all around, excellent teachers and mentors

headline: Nursing
pros: Excellent medicine, nurses and allied staff
cons: Physicians can fire you.  No true division from physicians and nurses.  Physicians still yell at nurses and have then written up. Nurses do not have a say in patient care or policies.  Physicians dominant everything.  Best thing a nurse can do is keep her/his mouth shut to keep their job.  Politics here are the worse I have ever seen.   Good place for patient care but not a good place to work

headline: Physician working at Mayo
pros: Physician led organization. Closed, private clinic so no need to travel to multiple hospitals to see inpatients. Manageable patient volumes with 60 minute appointments for new patients and 30 minutes for follow-ups (in my department), averaging 10-12 patients per day.
cons: Out of state patients often seek us out based on the Mayo name and expect we can perform miracles for them that their doctors at home cannot (unrealistic expectations). Research infrastructure is cumbersome, lots of red tape and slow activation process for clinical trials, plus cost of trials run at Mayo very high which limits interest of study sponsors in selecting us to run studies. Emphasis is on patient care first, which often means sacrificing time in other areas such as research; Mayo portrays itself as an academic institution but in reality it is a private practice with a relatively small focus on research.

headline: Brilliant
pros: Nice people and they work very hard all in all nice company
cons: There is no cons at all expect could be a bit bigger building

headline: Senior Fellow
pros: Mayo Clinic provides a good work environment and has a system to provide feedback. They are constantly trying to improve their services and also the benefits to the employees.
cons: Mayo Clinic is located in a place with very harsh weather and long winters. This can dampen spirits. Pay scales could be improved upon.

headline: Current Status
pros: flexibility, resources and management support available to perform your job

headline: Great place to work!

headline: Great Mission, patient focused and driven to help those in need
pros: Any position at Mayo Clinic provides immediate connection to the many patients that turn to Mayo for their most urgent/dire health needs.  Depending on position, balance can be a challenge, but is certainly possible to achieve.  With their two locations in Arizona and Jacksonville, movement in also an option.  Great people working to help others every day.
cons: As a not for profit, salaries seem right for most positions - but compared to for profit healthcare, Mayo pays lower salaries.  If you are a big city person, Minneapolis-St. Paul is just an hour away, but Rochester is a smaller town for some folks.

headline: Very Disappointed

cons: Lab management very poor. No family values. Absolutley No Recognition for Job Well Done!! Have to put all PTO time in for the year in Jan. U never get approved for ur PTO including if Airline Tix and vacation is planned u will not get approved no matter what!!

headline: Service Designer

nice people at frontline
decent food

lay-offs

headline: Patient Financial Services - Precertification

cons:
Lack of leadership from management for technological advancements in the IT department. 
Stuck in the old way of running a business.  Very manual processes and procedures.

headline: Project Manager

Flexibility - allowed to get the job done without being micro-managed
Benefits-403b matching
Pension
Vacation
cons: A little slow moving organization

headline: FROM  GREAT TO A MONEY/PUBLICITY EMPLOYER
pros:
Short drive
Still have some health insurance
great supervisor
Some of the old staff still here-nice to see familiar faces
cons: Each year the yearly raise and benefits go down - I am the poorest I have ever been even with an additional PT job.  I don't think I can hold on much longer. Can't afford surgery, new tires, even enough groceries. With the stress also, I have lost 10% of my weight this year, which I can't afford to lose. They keep piling on the work, so now we are each doing the work of 4 people. Oh that's right. they gave us an app to go on (smirk) but no one has time. We come in, pound it for 8 hours and often go home without saying a word to anyone. Wait for the next blast of fireworks to happen. Despite the PR done on this page, all that matters is $$$$$ and keeping the name in the news for the most trivial things. Very sad and stressful place. We miss our old clinic.

headline: Post-doc

headline: Project Manager

cons: Integration between Mayo Clinic and Mayo Clinic Health Systems has recently caused some confusion for employees - mostly around benefits, pay, position titles and processes.  Employee parking is a pain.

headline: Great place ro.work.as long as you never speak your own  mind

cons: Long hours never being able.at times to gwt your breaks in . Have to call out to get a day off..work is open 7/24 365..so plan working weekends

headline: Okay place to start out

headline: Great place to work!

cons: Can move a little slow at time given committee structures.

headline: lab assistant

cons: pay could be higher, there is a divide between employee and human resources, very slow career progress, not a lot of great communication between employees and management

headline: Run, don't walk from MCSB Lab
pros: Benefits and that's it.I have not one pro . Maybe that the reputation of Mayo is not what is at the Phoenix location.
cons: Management is run by overgrown adolescents. Favoritism, intimidation, retaliation and harassment. If you work hard, your coworkers will sit around and watch. They won't think out of the box. Patient care is of no concern here. If you like drama, jump right in. I suggest you run as fast as you can. Pay is better at other companies. They are not certified and they perform tests they are no qualified for. A whole week they gave out erroneous results because management is not educated in the field. Run!!New cancer center will be run by same management and can't be trusted with performing as Mayo states.

headline: Work study

cons: There are times when communication is poor. There is also that they have very strict guidelines in some areas which are needed but can become annoying at points.

headline: Great place towork
pros: collaborative and inclusive. Cutting edge. Changes are made based on research and Staff input.
cons: Cant thing of anything.

headline: Not as great as advertised.
pros: Very slow paced department. Equipment with the latest technology. A control center that rivals most bigger police department. Very friendly co-workers.
cons: Tough Promotion Capability, Favoritism. Offers no additional training for supervisors and management to grow professionally and become more efficient. Difficult hours to pursue continuing education in order to advance in company. Culture of clicks within managemen

headline: Great Opportunity to give excellent care and receive good benefits

Benefits (Insurance, wellness program, educational opportunities)
Reputation and Level of Service 
Up to date on newest standards of care and treatment options
Research ongoing to continue to reach highest of standards
cons: Cons vary depending on locations so I can only speak for two of the locations that I have worked at and those issues all relate to lower level management.

headline: Cardiovascular Technician

cons: Mayo is so big sometimes talent can get lost in the day to day operations. There seems to be no room for mobility unless you cross train in something in need.

headline: Great place to work in Rochester!
pros: Great benefits, work-life balance, mission-driven.
cons: none to add...great employer, great city

headline: RN
pros: There are some truly wonderful, yet overworked and underpaid nursing staff.
cons:
Too many to name them all. This hospital has a poor reputation in the community and assuming the Mayo name hasn't changed that. The culture needs improvement; staff seem miserable since Mayo took over.

Average RN pay is very low compared to the rest of the state. 

Benefits are dwindling. In fact, Mayo powers that be voted and now this is the only Mayo facility where you will not receive a pension creating even less incentive to work there.

Also the PTO program is ridiculous and seems to penalize any absence and favors presenteeism at all costs.

Workers do not have a vision plan available to them along with their health care insurance like most other hospitals offer. 


This facility does not seem to operate under the Mayo model of care like you might find in larger facilities. The building is old. The model of care is archaic. 

There is very poor management especially in the Nursing department. Communication between staff and management seems to be very poor in the worker's input doesn't matter.
 
Staffing level is often unsafe. Management has no regard for this and no contingency plan for short staffing. This place cannot retain staff. There is little room for advancement.

headline: interview review
pros: Nice town to raise a family. Basically there is no traffic anytime of the day.
cons: job interview has little relevance to the job you are applying. The interviewer does not have clear idea what the job requires.

headline: Clinical Assistant

headline: Great place

headline: POS

headline: Assistant Supervisor - General Service

headline: Great Place

headline: Great place

headline: Mayo health systems.

headline: HR Rep

Policies and Procedures are consistent...treating all fair.
Leadership is amazing, respectful and great follow through.
Great place to work!

headline: CA
pros: Ongoing education, diverse environment, great benefits,
cons: micromanagement, unqualified management, parking, under staffed

headline: Review
pros: I currently enjoy flex time (between 7a-5p) and being able to telework 1 day per week. Flex scheduling has been very helpful when trying to maintain some work/life balance.
cons: Rules are not always enforced equally amongst co-workers.   Leadership has indicated we can't telework more than 1 day per week but we have one person who is teleworking from another state.  Her move was never announced to the group and they even kept an office for her with her name on the door.  We can reach her by phone and email, but we aren't supposed to know that she is actually 3,000 miles away.  So stupid.

headline: good for freshers
pros: Technical satisfaction, friendly interaction among co-workers.
cons: Not completely structured, Priority changes depending on the individuals.

headline: Excellent Company

cons: Pay is on the low end.

headline: Family like atmosphere with high stress
pros: friendly staff, opportunities for advancement
cons: high stress, multi-tasking at the max, under staffed

headline: World-class. Best place to work!
pros: The heartbeat of Mayo Clinic is patients' needs always come first.  This commitment anchors the organization to what matters most.  Without question, Mayo is the gold-standard for all hospitals and physicians to emulate.
cons: As with many large organizations, collaboration is challenging and there are layers of bureaucracy that impede initiative.

headline: Working at Mayo
pros: Great company, good benefits and potential to move up the ladder.
cons: Sometimes because of the sheer size of the facility and number of employees, it's easy to feel like you're just a number there.

headline: Great place to work overall
pros: Great benefits, company has been around 150 years, strong brand, loyal patients, great work environment.
cons: Changes in Healthcare are driving massive changes within the organization.  Not filling positions.  Promotional are minimal in Administrative roles unless you want to live in Rochester.

headline: World class healthcare, mediocre IT
pros:
- The company is obviously a leader in healthcare in the US and the world.
- Stable employment. As long as you meet the minimum requirements for you position your job is safe. The bar for success is surprisingly low. In 18 years I have never seen anyone let go.
- The pay is competitive for the area, and the benefits are still OK.
cons:
- The IT department as a whole is poorly organized and very inefficient. Efforts to improve this are ongoing, but implementations of those improvements are extremely slow. 
- The leadership model is strange for IT. Mayo is a physician led organization, and the values of the company are very patient focused, as they should be. These values tend to cross over into IT and while there are many smart and dynamic IT leaders, they tend to be less technology focused. Most lead programmers I know were never really programmers, and are more project manager types. As result there is a lack of real technical leadership at Mayo. Depending on your perspective this is not always a bad thing. It is easier to get your way when your boss doesn't understand the technical details of what you are doing. 
- Over the 18 years I have been here they have whittled the benefits away at a pretty constant rate. The compensation is still competitive with other employers in the area, but it is just another signal of the change in how Mayo values it's employees.

headline: Data Analyst
pros: Supportive team, nice working environment
cons: The building for IT is old

headline: Scheduling Specialist
pros: Mayo Clinic is a very customer caring and puts the needs of the patient first. The training specifications are clearly delineated to the employee to provide exceptional customer service to the patient.
cons: I don't have any cons associated with my tenure, as an employee of Mayo Clinic. I was very pleased to be employed at Mayo Clinic.

headline: Awesome place to work!
pros:
The needs of the patient really do come first.  
Competitive salary.
Multiple opportunities.
Growing, thriving place to work
cons:
Too middle-management heavy
Decreasing benefits for current employees
Becoming too "commercialized" with expansions, losing that "Mayo" feel

headline: Wonderful place to work, best employer to have.
pros: Good benefits, flexible work schedule, only have to work every third weekend and one major and one minor holiday a year. The holidays rotate each year so you won't have to work Christmas for another two years if that is your holiday this year. You will have to work eve and day of the holiday. But you get the other major holidays off to spend with your family. If you can't accept that type of schedule then you shouldn't work for a hospital. But every year there are people complaining usually about working Christmas but I just shake my head since they shouldn't work in an industry where the doors never close 24/7 regardless of what holiday it is.
cons: It is a hard place to get into but persistence and having a good work history and resume helps.

headline: Great Employer Overall
pros: The work environment is great along with the people.  Benefits are great and very layback.  For example, HR doesn't ask for documentations to prove if you are married in order to add your spouse to benefits.  They dont ask for medical certification to see if you qualify for FMLA.  Managers are always very helpful and willing to find resources to help make their employees job easier.
cons: There are no room for advancement.  Mayo is a very large employer but in order to get promoted you have to know the right people.  It not base on performance, skills, knowledge, or educational background.  It who you know and that can be a downfall because talented people are not in the right position.

headline: Coding Operations
pros: "The needs of the patient comes first."  The basic value of Mayo is always in view.  Great, friendly environment. Wonderful employee events and benefits.
cons: I used to work at the downtown campus and had to take a commuter bus, as employee parking is about to 15+ years!  However, I now work from home, so that's no longer an issue!

headline: CRC

cons: Management seems unorganized and doesn't follow through.

headline: Scientist

headline: cath

headline: RN
pros: Mayo Clinic is a leader in providing  a wonderful example of excellence, integrity, and innovation in today's challenging healthcare environment. It was an honor to work for them..

headline: World's Famous Place to Work
pros: Upgrades, Pay, Health Care, Benefits........

headline: RN

headline: Great place to work!
pros:
In no particular order: 

-Great benefits (health/vision/dental/etc)
-Good employee discounts within community
-Professional and respectful atmosphere
-Cultural diversity (which is honored and celebrated), with outstanding colleagues from all over the world
-Beautiful buildings with great history
-Patient comes first mentality is truly embraced here at all levels of the clinic and research
-Location in Rochester, MN - a very pleasant / comfortable community to call home.
cons: -Some preference to hire from within the organization first when looking outside for employees could bring in new talent/improvements

headline: Great place

headline: Great Hospital
pros:
Fantastic company to work for. Cant beat the education and experience.

Good benefits, could be a little bit better on the pay scale

headline: Good experience, not necessarily good for daily life
pros: There are good benefits. The job is stable and if I do a reasonable job I feel like I will have a place to be employed.  I do enjoy working with the patients.  There are lots of world-class physicians and medical experts here.  I enjoy being around the research and education environment.
cons: In my particular division, people with my job (physician assistant) are treated less respectfully than at other organizations where I have worked.  There are lots of layers of management here but relatively few people to actually do the work of taking care of patients. "The needs of the patient come first" is not what I have always seen here.  They are not flexible or open to change in terms of employee satisfaction (alternative schedules, etc).  Change does not happen fast here.  I think it may be different in different departments but I have seen a definite downturn in the work environment in the past 7 years that I've been here.

headline: System analyst

headline: Great place

headline: Excellent

headline: Mayo Clinic
pros: Wonderful healthcare organization.  Great teamwork.  Fair salaries.
cons: Most hospitals still have pensions.  Mayo used to pay complete pension for employees.  Employees did not put a penny into pension.  So0n Mayo will start matching employee contributions like every other hospital.  Management thinks they only have to match other healthcare organizations, and is making Mayo more and more like a corporation instead of what the Mayo Brothers intended.  Also, they don't understand that benefits must be better than other organizations to keep people in the Rochester weather.  Short-sighted.

headline: I am very satisfied with my job and my supervisor.

headline: I have good people skills, medical terminology, very dependable, team player,

headline: Used to be great to work for

headline: 16 years as a bedside care giver--two as a PCT, and 14 as an RN.
pros: Decent nurse-to-patient ratio; Love my co-workers, team pulls together in a pinch.  So many great experiences caring for such complex, unique, challenging patients.  Nurse-friendly units regarding access to adequate supplies, ancillary personnel to provide excellent patient care.
cons: Teamwork communication lacking between physicians and nursing, especially dealing with residents; patient expectations sometimes unrealistic because "this is Mayo Clinic";  Administration seemingly out-of-touch with unit-based nurses.

headline: Awesome
pros: Love working here it is the best place in the world. The employees are the nicest people to walk the face of the earth.
cons: i have nothing bad to say about this company. Straight class all the way. Nothing but good things for this company.

headline: Nurse Practitioner
pros:
It is the Mayo and it looks good on your resume and you get some good experience. 
A pro is the pay. They employ about a thousand mid-levels (NP/PA's) at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, MN. The pay is above normal for Minnesota because it is hard to attract people to Rochester, and get them to stay, and live there.
cons:
1. The Mayo Clinic is a top tier Medical School. You work in a specialized service and the medical residents and Fellows do the diagnosing, prescribing and everything else; you will practice well below your training.
2.  I was in orthopedic surgical services and as the Certified Nurse Practitioner a registered nurse, surgical assistant, medical assistant or secretary could all do my job. 
3. You have to live in Rochester, MN, and there is nothing here. Rochester's population is about 110,000 people. The Mayo Clinic in Rochester employs 36,000 people. The city government, hotels, shops and restaurants all survive on hand-me-downs from the Mayo Clinic.  There is no diversity, culture or competition and the Mayo loves it that way.

headline: Great place
pros: Pay is good.  The staffing could be good, if the company made a decision to make it good.
cons: Staffing is not optimal.  Come on the needs of the patient come first!  2 vented patients as an assignment in the ICU is not safe.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Great place to work. Great sense of accomplishment. Feel like your are doing something that actually is helping people.
cons: A large organization with lots of meetings that can slow things down.

headline: Alright place to work, nothing special anymore.
pros:
Patients are fairly nice, excellent nursing staff and clinicians as well.
Cost of living in Rochester, MN is low.
Presence of some of the latest in clinical technology.
Some great management, dependent on position.
Nice name on a resume and good place to start a career.
cons:
Parking
Health Insurance is below device industry and competitor health systems standards. It's quite average now.
Retirement policy basically requiring a life long career to get anything worthwhile
Bureaucracy Galore.

headline: Case Manager
pros: Supportive of education, offers traditional pension and tuition reimbursement.
cons: Variations in compensation, path towards greater earnings can be a mystery.

headline: Literally one of my worse experiences.....
pros: Multiple specialties for patients, research, and higher salaries
cons: Callus and ineffective management, excessively frugal, poor training, disorganized,

headline: Loved working here!
pros: You are working for one of the top medical centers in the world. Since I have left Mayo Clinic, I have missed a lot of my co-workers and supervisors. Benefits are the best!
cons: No parking downtown for employees... Besides that nothing!

headline: License practical  nurse
pros: Love taking care of ppl making sure. They feel comfortable I want them to know I genuinely care for them and their well being  some ppl smile at the patient but they can tell if your being really sincerely or this is what They have to do to keep there jobs. when your sick and if your in the hospital you already feel bad because people know stranger have to take care of them but you have to come in hold there hand and introduce yourself and tell them you are their nurse today and if U need anything just ring your bell I will be here or someone else from our wonderful staff
cons: You wish you could save everybody I don't like to see people suffer so I will make you as comfortable as possibles even if I need to ask the doctor if they Would need something to make get out of some really bad pain just do it you Can make some ones day a little better.  Bg I really hate lazy people please do your work and their nothing wrong with doing something for your patient and it not really in your job description example taking them to the toilet and not make them wait for a nurses assistant.

headline: RN
pros: Co-workers can be fun to work with.

headline: Enjoy work, changes a bit stressful.

headline: Good Place to work

headline: Postdoctoral Fellow

headline: clinical research fellow
pros: The place where I am provides flexible schedule, ample learning opportunity, good benefit and friendly environment. It is very stable job.
cons:
This job does not provide a high salary but it is ok to live in this town with the salary I make.
Rochester is a small city and has a limited option for cultural activities.

headline: Not all it's supposed to be...
pros: Organization does great things clinically and that is something to be proud of.
cons: Pay is well below market and does not cover rising cost of living in Rochester.  Organization leadership tends to live off of it's history instead of innovating.  Little advancement opportunity.  Stated values and mission are great, but do not necessarily apply to all, especially management.

headline: It's ok
pros: Generous paid time off.  Plenty of interesting work going on.  If you are on the "inside" you will have smooth sailing.  If you are not, you will be on the outs and forgotten about.  So, if you know someone at a fairly high level on the allied health side you may really like it.
cons: Inexperienced people getting promoted to management positions, leading to chaos.  Rampant cronyism.  Very weak HR that will side with whatever management wants to do--bending rules, giving jobs to friends, etc.  Lots of "lifers" as well--people who have only worked at Mayo and don't know anything else.  Aggressive affirmative action hiring.

headline: Overall great company, but cytogenetics needs to get their act together
pros: always hiring, so great for recent graduates. great work experience. very meaningful work. Great coworkers. Great pay and annual raises.
cons: management has no formal training and is not great at handling employee conflicts. Training for employees is poor and veteran employees are not nice to new employees.

headline: Clinical Research Coordinator
pros: Competitive pay, good benefits, excellent employee occupational health program, great work out facility and cafeteria has healthy food for employees.
cons: Management, poor employee morale, heavy workloads, burn out, computer systems are outdated, too many weekly meetings.

headline: This is great organization and I love working here!
pros: The needs of patient really do come first.  The staff can realize great satisfaction in serving others.
cons: It is possible to feel burnout at this institution but they are working on solutions to fix this.

headline: The Needs Of The Wealthy Comes First
pros: World class organization, expensive buildings, patient centered, and pension funded.
cons: Poor middle management, ideas by people doing the actual work are not listened to or implemented due to committee management  style or lazy people not willing to change or learn something new, ultra conservative, managers actually spend an ubsorbantly amount of time coming up with policies that are not evenly enforced.  Some are meeting lovers.  Also, some upper managers or physicians are arrogant, and if you are paid hourly (allied-health staff) be prepared to pick up the slack of overpaid salaried coworkers so they can use the workout center during work hours.  Hourly paid individuals are kept on a tight time tracking leash with strict sick time rules.  Salaried workers have much more freedoms and trust in their time management abilities.  Thus some abuse that.

headline: Team-work
pros: Amazing staff and very good location
cons: Not much flexibility with your time

headline: Wonderful Company!
pros:
- Pleasant co-workers
- Education reimbursement
- Upward mobility
- Departments work as a team
cons: None! I loved working here!

headline: Great place to work for!
pros: Takes care of their employees
cons: Nothing bad to say about company

headline: Needs of the Patient come FIRST!
pros: Awesome experience - great opportunities for professional growth. Management listened to concerns of employees and implemented changes when possible.
cons: None with Mayo Clinic - only with MN winters; brutal.

headline: Great Healthcare, Tough Culture
pros: Mayo Clinic is world renowned for is excellent and often cutting edge medical treatment, its medical education and its medical research.  It works tirelessly to address the needs of the patient to create the best possible outcomes.
cons: Mayo Clinic is like 2 companies in one.  The medical practice side, and the Administrative side (including HR, IT, Finance, etc.)  On the Administrative side, the culture attempts to emulate the medical practice, but to its own detriment.  Key decisions are made in committee with no single accountable party, authority (top down) is often undermined by power (bottom up).  While the Admin organization attempts to serve the medical practice, they often provide sub-optimal solutions that are the outcome of minimizing any potential change within the organization.

headline: Good overall starting position
pros: Great co workers in my area. Not all departments are the same though. It is very different in patient financial services compared to clinical settings.
cons: Management was very disconnected to staff and is always in meetings instead of actually managing. Ideas for improvement are not usually listened to.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Really take care of their employees
cons: Things are not always equal between the different sites

headline: Used to be great
pros: Job security is good if you dont mind being jerked from job to job when they decide to change everything again.
cons: Management is just horrible. No commom sense.

headline: Amazing things going on here.
pros: Down-to-earth coworkers, people working together towards a common goal, life-saving technology being developed
cons: There were no cons of this job for me.

headline: Nice place to work but...
pros: Always have supplies, nice work environment, benefits are ok
cons: Management very slow to act, little respect for nursing, raises are based on where you are on a pay scale, not merit

headline: Rated best in the country for healthcare- not managment
pros: benefits. pay, patient care, efficiency in a troubling time in healthcare
cons:
supervisors micromanage, don't know who is actually working and who talks about working 
closed doors of communication from upper management 
transportation
parking

headline: Great organization
pros:
Well-staffed relative to other area facilities.
Collegial atmosphere.
Adequate supplies for performing our work.
Great mission!
cons:
Tone-deaf management.
Focus on the bottom line a little too much.
Will put up with bad actors in mgmt. without any apparent accountability for performance/excellence.

headline: Administrative Assistants @ Mayo Clinic
pros: Mayo Clinic has Administrative Assistants; there are no perks to being an Administrative Assistant other than for those who are trying to enter Mayo Clinic as an employee - this is the way to get your foot in the door.
cons:
Mayo Clinic has been reevaluating a lot of job classes stemming from the Sirota Survey responses.  But the only job class/category not being reevaluated is secretarial positions.  The last change made to this job category was back in 2004 (11 years ago in March) and only a title change was made from Administrative Secretary to Administrative Assistant.  The pay range was not adjusted to reflect this change as is the case with numerous other job title changes at Mayo Clinic.  

Part of the new Mayo Clinic culture is to invest in Talent as part of their Strategic Plan.  So why does Mayo Clinic not invest in the talent they already have on staff or by hiring those with specific vocational degrees and job experience instead of investing in someone with no work experience and a non-related degrees (i.e., Biblical Theology, Psychology, etc.) to perform Administrative Assistant work?  That’s the million dollar question.  Mayo Clinic sees talent as having a Bachelor's Degree and no experience and you don't even need to know how to spell or use proper grammar.  

There are employees at Mayo Clinic who are currently doing secretarial work who have had their job title and job description changed along with a salary range increase but are still performing secretarial work.  For example, two women could be sitting in the same office performing the same job duties but, because one has a bachelor’s degree, is paid more.  To get around the federal rules the minimum qualifications are changed and/or the job description. However, a job description change does not necessarily mean that is what is being done in that job.  When employees witness such action, it is demoralizing to those who are working in the same capacity but are paid significantly less.  

A lot of other job classes requiring Associate Degrees and/or Diplomas offer different steps that employees can move through in their positions; e.g., Research Protocol Specialist I, II, II & Senior, etc. For those of us who choose this as a career and have 10, 15, 20-30 years of experience in this field, we are not considered “talented” enough to be given opportunities unless we have a Bachelor’s Degree.

Unfortunately, for those of us who have vocational degrees/diplomas, we are not allowed to advance in our field of choice because Mayo Clinic is oppressing those of us who love this work and choose to do this work as a career choice.  For those of us who speak up, we are basically banished from ever going further in this field.  After dedicating many years of your life to Mayo Clinic as an Administrative Assistant you will eventually be capped at the top of the pay range.  At this point you will only receive the pay range increase and nothing extra.  Mayo Clinic used to give our Merit Increases to those who were at this point, but this has been done away with for the secretarial field.  All other fields get their Merit Increases by being able to advance to different levels within their job fields and by job titles being changed to make accommodations for exclusive employees to continue receiving pay increases.  In 2015, the pay range across the board increased 2% so that means those at the top of the pay range only receive a 2% increase.  Now that’s investing in your talent and investing in staff who give 1/2 their lives to an organization.

headline: Career advancement is more about "who" you know rather than "what" you know or have done
pros: Working in areas related to research, education, or the practice is good. Other areas are obsessed with cutting costs. Time off benefits are generous. They still offer a pension!
cons: All the employees get the same percentage raise... even the lazy ones. Department/Division chairs don't do enough to develop their managers. Employees pay a lot of the costs after going to the doctor. Not a modern mindset.

headline: Loved working here
pros: Loved working with The Resdents
cons: Co workers from other shifts

headline: At times, like working for the federal government
pros: Good health plan, low expectations, average pay, stable, strong brand, lots of opportunity for latteral mobility, similar to government or university employment, best medical care on earth, universal pay raises irrespective of performance
cons: Mayo has a big problem tolerating low-grade, incompetent administrators (management) alongside world class medical specialists, nurses, techs. Why accept two vastly different levels of professionalism? The two functions don't have to be incompatible for the medical part to thrive. Mayo's potential is onl being partially realized because of this.

headline: I'm an IT/Programmer analyst here at mayo clinic.
pros: Working here at mayo clinic is one of the best jobs i had because it is one of the best places to work for in US and also the best hospitals in the US.
cons: Challenging job was to develop and maintain the huge amount of data

headline: Staff Consultant
pros: Excellent Physician and Nursing staff who remain dedicated to their craft and our patients.
cons: No longer a physician-led organization. Now firmly in the hands of administrators who care more about lean/Six Sigma than supporting the Mayo Model of Care. Very sad to see a rapid decline in morale over the last decade.

headline: Medical Technologist
pros: Best Place to work. Perfect environment.
cons: Low pay Low pay Low Pay

headline: Mayo clinic cytogenetics lab
pros: Well paid, easy work, interesting job
cons: Port management, hostile working evironment

headline: Very good place to work for.
pros: Good pay and benefits package
cons: Not much opportunity for advancement

headline: mayo waycross
pros: Health insurance starting on first day
cons: Low pay, dirty looking building (old)

headline: Great place to work and do research that really makes a difference.
pros: Healthcare, Education and Research are the three major pillars of this organization and it has a world class reputation in each.
cons: The committee structure that Mayo management depends on can be somewhat "top-heavy".  Also, unfortunately, in our nation's environment of shrinking medical reimbursements, our health care coverage and retirement benefits are becoming somewhat watered down...

headline: Great clinical care, but research is under a lot of stress
pros: Very nice people, with a executives that provide clarity and vision. Work-life balance is great, as are medical benefits. A lot of visiting scholars from outside the USA makes working with colleagues interesting and always changing.
cons: Pay is low and Rochester is a lonely place if you are single. A great place to start or have a family but only if your spouse also has work at the Clinic. Salaries are too low for one income at a Fellow level to support a full family.

headline: Worked for Mayo for 10 years
pros:
Patient centered
Outstanding resourses
Well managed
Sense of making a contribution to medicine
cons:
Harsh winters
Sometimes slow to change

headline: Good culture, but benefits declining
pros:
- Positive Atmosphere, great Co-workers
- Staff physicians very approachable
- Pay is equitable
- Prestigious, name recognition
cons:
- Health benefits keep getting reduced and costs continue to rise
- Prescription drug coverage TERRIBLE; if you need specialty drug, get ready to hand over your paycheck
- Finally a match for 401K equivalent but does this mean pension going away?

headline: Informatics Specialist
pros: Great Benefits provided to all the employees!!!
cons: Weather can sometimes be brutal

headline: Great
pros: Very professional environment to work in.
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Excellent
pros: Benefits, work life balance, employee appreciation
cons: Leadership, limited time-off/high burn-out rate

headline: Meaningful and great experience
pros: there is a wonderful spirit  at this  facility. Everything aims to improve  patients well being and  employees  happiness ...
cons: I would like that every place  is like this one

headline: Great place to work, great collaboration with colleagues, middling pay, flat structure
pros:
Team- oriented colleagues
Provides adequate budgets for projects
Super secretarial support
High- level projects for the field
cons:
Flat management structure-- not much of a career path to follow
Pay only OK, no bonuses
Medical benefits have been severely downgraded for 2015, paltry retirement match
Mayo does not fire those who don't perform

headline: Long commitment to company
pros: The Mayo Clinic offers a wide vast of variety in different settings in which to work for your job.  You have the opportunity to work in the clinical, hospital, and research under one company.  They are a strong advocate for furthering education for the employees through higher educations and company classes.
cons: They need to find ways to find more ways to keep the current employees from leaving too soon as well as draw new employees to join Mayo Clinic's teamwork.

headline: Great Clinic, lousy I.T. department
pros: Mayo truly values its customers - the patients, and anything you do to help patients is acknowledged. There is a very positive sense behind the mission of the place.  The benefits are good and the retirement funds are more than adequately funded.
cons: The Information Technology Department is run by people who think that Dilbert is a management guide, a pro-management guide.  They impose ridiculous and expensive top-heavy processes and call it "agile" in a lame attempt at new-speak.  IT is the deepest and widest department in the institution and imposes its inadequacies upon the entire enterprise, thus impeding the greater institutional mission of helping the sick.

headline: I am inspired by the talent and dedication of the people of Mayo Clinic. Feel honored to work here.
pros: I have had opportunities to work with people from many professions on projects that are worthwhile. Mayo leaders take a sincere interest in your work and are willing to give of their time to help you when their involvement is needed. People here are very busy but always willing to help. This place has a BIG heart.
cons: Periodic micro-managing; may need to provide some of your own resources at your own expense; commitment to transparency inconsistent; female physicians seem to be promoted only so far--not one has served as Mayo's top CEO over the course of its 150-year history. This is no criticism of our current CEO, who is excellent in the role and is an inspirational leader.

headline: Great Experience
pros: Collaborative, fun, welcoming, inviting, social
cons: location- rains almost every day

headline: Nothing good to say
pros: Good location, Rochester has a lot to offer.
cons: Almost everything from bloated management, to supervisors who play favorites and only look out for the people who suck up to them. The wrong people are being promoted into lead roles to the detriment of the patients. Quit cutting the hell out of a formerly great benefit package for retirees.

headline: The needs of the patient come first.
pros: great culture, highly trained and knowledgeable staff, great facilities, strong leadership, incredible support for employee advancement
cons: Minnesota  winters can be brutal

headline: Truly the best hospital in the world!
pros: I had to relocate recently and this is the only reason I left Mayo! Hardest decision of my life! This is the best hospital in the world to work at or be a patient. Extremely professional, kind, and competent employees. The best environment for nurses to work in. Everyone respects each other and you can depend on your co workers. "Mayo nice" is a thing. If you don't have it...you won't last here! I'd trust these people with my life!
cons: Rochester, MN is kind of in the middle of nowhere. And it's Minnesota so winter is endless and there's no such thing as a snow day so your going to have to plow your way to work! St. Mary's is an old hospital and a couple of the floors are a little dated, but most are being remodeled!

headline: Good place to work, if you are in the correct lab.
pros: Mayo Clinic has a very friendly work environment, and employees a lot of good people.
cons: Promotions are usually hard to come by unless you really fight for them.  Some people feel it is based on years of service, not work performance.

headline: Busy Allied Health Staff
pros: Great opportunities, team work, and diversity. Pay and benefits are above average. Value in going home knowing you are contributing to a good cause.
cons: Matrix organization. Constantly being pulled between different priorities. The person dictating the workload usually isn't the same person with the control of the resources. Periods of extreme burnout and frustration. All part of working through a major change in the industry though.

headline: Great Company!
pros:
Offer competitive benefits and wages.
Really care about their employees and the patients.
Easy to move between departments and most of the management want to help you work towards your goals. 
Lots of opportunities to be involved in committees.
cons:
It is sometimes very hard to get fired and so there are people working there that don't fit the Mayo values.
If you need time off in the summer months, you must know early in the year and have your request in, and then it is determined by seniority. Can be hard to get the time off that you want. 
One of the most frustrating things about working here is, they offer decent benefits, but as an employee it is super hard to get an appointment to be seen unless it is an emergency.

headline: Mayo Clinic Florida was an amazing place to work for and grow and develop in healthcare.
pros: Very influential in research and cutting edge technology; innovative; great compensation
cons: Can be hard to obtain a position initially, but once you are in, you are in.

headline: Mayo is an excellent place to work!
pros: Wonderful people, excellent atmosphere, great benefits.
cons: Generally speaking, the work environment is great, however my recent experience has been outside the norm. I can only assume it's a different aspect of the organization that allows for some inappropriate behaviors (puzzling as that may be), however I know that Mayo does great things and employs great people, so I'm not concerned by this small piece of the employee population with respect to Mayo as a whole.

headline: HUC position
pros: Great group to work with. Benefits are nice.
cons: Pay is low, hours are bad.

headline: Good Steady Job
pros: Great team structure, amazing benefits, ample time off.
cons: Hours are late. Working can be repetitive.

headline: Disappointing.  Motto should be "The needs of the patients with MONEY comes first.
pros: Excellent patient care.  Fair wages and benefits. State of the art equipment.
