cons: Change in benefits to exclude retired Mayo employees from health care once they become Medicare eligible.  Disrespectful, arrogant and bullying behavior from physicians and supervisors is never addressed or disciplined.  I didn't quit my job, I quit the people I worked with.

headline: Patients come first
pros: The over all environment is good. Everyone has a sense of pride to be employed by Mayo Clinic. There is access to great care resources and events.
cons: Work life balance at Mayo like many health care systems can be difficult to maintain. In Rochester especially where the majority of the people in the community have direct ties to Mayo Clinic it may feel difficult to separate work from personal life.

headline: Fantastic Company
pros:
Great company that really cares about developing you so that you are the best both for yourself and for the company

Good benefits
cons:
There is much bureaucracy, but that is to be expected with a company as expansive as Mayo Clinic.

Health insurance exclusive to Mayo

headline: a good place with nice people. slow system with a lot of  bureaucratic issues. very respectful doctors and nurses
pros: a wonderful hospital with a lot of practices and research opportunities; depending on if you can get into transnational research, it  is a very unique place you can grow yourself.
cons: bureaucratic system. severe political barriers for junior people. cold weather and boring small-size city. comparing to very lively eastern and western coast, here is a place for you to start a career and raise your small kids, but not good for expanding and finding more opportunities.

headline: Amazing place to work.. !
pros: Working in this place gives a great Job satisfaction, and has great benefits for employees. City has most of the things you need.
cons: I did not find anything negative. Working here helps you to have a great work-life balance.

headline: Evolving
pros:
-Ample opportunity to contribute to the growth of your field/department
-pays well
-an overall good culture that really tries to show its appreciation for employees as much as its patients. 
-great benefits and looks out for employees
-generally high-quality physicians, nurses, and laboratory staff. 
-if you mess up (in a non-criminal way) there are people in place to help you get on track and rehabilitate. They invest in their employees so they will coach you to help you succeed.
cons: -mayo is viewed by a lot of people as the zenith of medical care, so it's stressful to keep up that "make no mistake.....ever" mentality.

headline: Amazing. I feel fortunate enough to work for this great organization, the culture is something to be experienced.
pros: Salary, Benefits, shift differential, medical, dental, eye. The needs of the patient really do come first here an it shows. People from all over the world recognize Mayo as the best and Mayo proves it everyday.
cons: Parking is very limited and creates some issues when going to and from work on day shift. When working second or 3rd shift there is no issue.

headline: Proud to work for Mayo
pros: I have been at Mayo Clinic since the early 2000s, and it's the only major institution I've worked in, though I have had other part time positions elsewhere. I didn't realize how good I had it for the first few years until I started to realize how hard it is to get in to a company like this, especially in economic hard times. I now work in a teleworking position and actually live out of state, even though I started out on the Rochester campus downtown. Working from home has improved my job satisfaction immensely, even though there are sometimes technical difficulties, being able to avoid commuting and having to buy work clothes makes up for the periodic inconvenience. Mayo does take good care of their employees; though, just like any large company, some work units have better supervisors and policies than other. Overall, though, they try to keep things fair in terms of compensation and hours, including systematic raises and pay ranges.
cons: There are often "hiring freezes" in which, in order to save money, when someone leaves, they are not replaced except for in rare circumstances. Our work unit has experienced this several times now, and the work continues to be redistributed, sometimes stretching people beyond their limits, even if temporarily. The past few years, there have been a lot of campaigns to "work differently," meaning finding ways to work more efficiently and using less resources, waste, etc. It has made a big difference in a positive way in many areas; and, in the current job market, many of us who are still working, we are grateful to have a job with good benefits--however, some of the uncertainty is a little unsettling for some work groups who are always wondering if they will be next on the chopping block. For the most part, however, if a team is eliminated, those folks get first priority in placement in other departments.

headline: Overall good, with a ton of change coming
pros:
The mission 
Most of the people that you work with
cons:
Constant change without clear focus 
There are people just 'mailing it in'
No performance bonuses

headline: Great Company... But Best for Those with MD Title.
pros: Great healthcare plans. Fitness center in complex for employees. Shuttle buses from surrounding area. Most of complex is connected through tunnels, helpful in cold winter months. Patient-centered, so facility is always well-kept.
cons: Doctor worship. If you aren't one of the docs, be prepared to be somewhere further down the totem pole for how important you are to the company.

headline: Great organization to work for, strong value, culture and rich history.
pros: Retention of Employees is strong, if looking for longevity. Benefits are great; Growth and opportunity is there as long as you are creative and open minded;
cons: Limitation in career movement as it is a challenge to become "one".  There is a lot of conversation but not enough solution surrounding how to embrace the change.

headline: Nothing is better than working for Mayo Clinic!
pros: Great system with lots of opportunity to move-up. The pay is great, the educaitonal and professional opportunites are execellent as well.
cons: Lots of cahnge occuring in the health system through convergence and integration efforts, which has created ambiguity with regard to current and future trajectory. Also, I am given so many "additional duties as required" to the extent that there is no bandwidth to take on more and meet the needs that my role requires.

headline: Number one in the Country for a reason
pros: Pay and hours, benefits are great- cheap health plan options, Employer paid pension, 401k with employer match, great shift differential. Lots of opportunities to get OT (if you want it).
cons: There is a serious parking issue in Downtown Rochester. If you plan to work at a Mayo satellite location, you should be fine.

headline: I worked at Mayo for 5 years in their IT department.  It's a mess!
pros: Mayo has a great reputation overall.  They utilize cutting edge technology that enhances patient care, but things move VERY slowly.  They still have/had pension benefits.  Overall acceptable benefit package - although decreasing each year.
cons:
Management has been there so long, they have forgotten how to operate 'outside of the box' and used to doing things the same way.  It's all they know.  They tend to micro manage - so if you are a free thinker - probably not the place for you.  A still current employee (who has been with Mayo for 20+ years) once explained to me that as long as you 'move with the herd, you'll be fine'.  If you cannot - the herd will find a way to 'push you off the cliff'.  
HR is there strictly for management, not for YOU.  Don't be deceived.

headline: great boss and lovely job, never gonna leavve
pros: boss is so nice and is always saying something nice
cons: sometimes yyou have to work nights;(

headline: Moving on to better places
pros: Good benefits at the present yet benefits are consistently being cut back little by little.  The health care system does have many specialties in which staff may choose although getting assigned an interview is difficult due to the HR department.
cons: The corporation has become very arrogant over the years. The staff are no longer important in the grand scheme of things only the patients are. This has caused resentment and distrust in the corporation. Staff do not feel there is any loyalty by management or the from the company as a whole. The attendance policy is not conducive to staff who work in a healthcare setting thus being prone to catching illnesses. Nurses work various shifts and are severely punished if  sick, late or accidentally miss at shift. Past work attendance or work ethic does not matter if a staff member is written up for inadvertently breaking the attendance policy.

headline: Don't care about Autism!!!
pros: It's a job that pays well. Don't expect employees to work too hard.
cons: Insurance does not cover therapy for autistic children even though we live in WI and WI requires employers to cover ABA Therapy. Mayo is large enough they can get away without having to do it. Very disappointing for a medical organization!!

headline: Decent opportunities but leadership needs more training.
pros: There is a lot of good work being done here with many talented individuals in departments across the country.  The benefits are really quite good, and Rochester is a nice place to raise a family.  Tons of different research and clinical labs here too, so lots of options to pick from.
cons: Training!  The major downfall of this company is that their values stress that "the patient comes first", but that's not the culture.  The culture is that the doctor comes first, which usually means that they have little to no experience or training in managerial skills.  A PhD or MD can have a lab, but that doesn't mean it will be run well.  To some extent this is likely true around the world, but Mayo doesn't even attempt to improve the managerial skills of their top workforce members.  However, if there are issues, HR is pretty good at handling them effectively.

headline: Residential Staff
pros: Prestige of working at Mayo Clinic
cons: Politics of the management team

headline: Great place
pros: Best doctors in the world
cons: Minnesota is not for everyone

headline: Wonderful place to work
pros: career opportunity, education, employee gym, great coworkers
cons: none that I can think of

headline: Clinical Analyst
pros: Well organized and superior patient care
cons: Health Insurance was high and as an employee you are considered a number and in a silo.

headline: Don't Believe The Hype
pros: Great benefits including PTO and health insurance, reimbursement account for vision and dental. Great reputation. Great health care. Amazing physicians.
cons: Work life balance is terrible. Management is horrid. Expectations are ridiculous. Nothing matters except the needs of the patient. Forget the needs of yourself. You get a good deal of PTO but good luck using it, especially in the summer.

headline: I worked at The Mayo, and it was okay.
pros:
Clinical lab work here is a breeze:  up to date instruments and methods, tons of specialist support, and all the Facebooking you want.
Mayo subsidizes public transportation (including coach buses), which allows long-distance commuters to defray travel costs.
Employees have access to world-class doctors and treatments for their own medical care.
cons:
As the "Bastion of Conservatism", dress codes are too rigid and out of date, especially for areas with zero patient contact.
Mayo used to offer all employees free health care and a more relaxed absentee policy; over the years they have slowly tightened the screws to eliminate little perks that used to be taken for granted.
Mayo is located in the bowels of Minnesota = Winter Hell.

headline: Excellent place to work.
pros: Benefits are great. Lots of job opportunity. Education reimbursement.
cons: Ageism, once you reach 50 there are not many promotions.

headline: Medical Secretary, good experience, and a great name to have on your resume.
pros: Great benefits, wonderful physicians, above average pay.   Beautiful facilities, great cafeteria food.
cons: Do more with less...basically as a medical secretary having to support 4 to 7 physicians is very stressful and too much for 1 person to handle.  You work hard and rarely get recognition of your good work.

headline: Research Analyst
pros: I want to build my career and look for residency opportunity.
cons: everyone is very intelligent and hard working.  Team work is essential so you need to keep up with the pace.

headline: Awesome place to work!
pros: Staffing here is amazing.  You won't find these kind of patient to nurse ratios anywhere in the country.
cons: They have a tendency to move slow to change anything.

headline: Secretary
pros: Good facilities, good doctors, good variety of work.
cons: Some Middle management (ops managers) are not very competent.

headline: Great place to work!
pros:
The best thing about Mayo is that everyone(well, almost everyone) really does realize that the needs of our patients come first, regardless of what time of the night or weekend it is. 

That being said, working at Mayo in IT is mostly an 8-5 job. The reason for this is that there is not enough parking downtown, so at 5:00 pm there is a max exodus of employees trying to catch their bus ride home. There is an on-call rotation, however, so  I can be paged in the middle of the night if a system has a problem. 

Management is good, and I happen to work right now for an exceptional manager. 

Salary and benefits are excellent, even though old timers grumble about the "good old days" where healthcare premiums were covered free of charge.
cons:
IT at Mayo is what I would charitably call "mass controlled chaos". Doctors have a lot of power at Mayo, so in the past, if a doctor wanted a pet project, she usually got it. Regardless of whether it required special databases, middleware, etc. 

Because of this, Mayo is rife with one-off applications, environments and technologies all over the place. Until recently, it was a free-for-all where almost anything goes. 

Finally, Mayo brought in a new CIO who is working towards streamlining IT and attempting to introduce standardization. It's a slow process, but we have seen some positive changes already. Still lots of work to do in this area. 

Work/life balance is very good, but Mayo is a bit conservative, so there is not the flexibility like there is at other companies like IBM. You're pretty much expected to be in the office from 8-5. 

Parking in downtown Rochester is abysmal for Mayo employees. I think the current waiting list for a parking spot is about 12 years. Most employees park at "Park & Rides" and take the bus into downtown.

headline: Overall very good but getting promoted is tough
pros: Good working environment. Good benefits.
cons: In nursing there is a "Good ol' Girls" clique when it comes to promotions. Couldn't get an interview and was more qualified than the person that got the job. When asked why told didn't have experience in that area. Neither did the person that got the job.

headline: Clinical
pros: benefits are good, and work-life balance ok
cons: lower pay but good benefits

headline: IV Technician
pros: Great health care and benefits
cons: work can be tedious and boring

headline: Fast pace, cutting edge hospital, emphasis on new technologies
pros: Challenging and rewarding place to work;  While there are always budgetary constraints, for the most part you are given the opportunity to bring in what you need.
cons: Large organization, spread out geographically between 3 areas (Fl, AZ, MN/WI).  Because of the size, things can move very slowly, and a lot of disorganization at times.  Middle leadership is ok, but upper levels gets into a lot of politics, and who can make the biggest splash in the puddle.

headline: Collaborative Atmosphere
pros:
- Work with experienced, dedicated professionals
- Access to individuals with subject matter expertise that is unparalleled 
- Ample opportunity, if you desire
cons:
- Same as any large organization: necessity of processes, things take time - not a knock on the organization, but rather an unfortunate side effect of large corporations
- Location is rather unfortunate as well - Small town MN

headline: Is a great very big company that appears very stable
pros: Solid Base, Ok wages, Normally easy to find coverage for when you want time off. Full time offers good benefits for 401K and Health Benefits
cons: A Little management heavy at times while they are wanting to make all facilities all one bit happy family

headline: Excellent mentorship & research opportunities with great benefits.
pros:
-Excellent mentorship and research opportunities.
-Best hospital in the world, so translational research training here is deep, broad, and diverse.
-Chance to work with the world's experts in just about every clinical and translational research area.
-The salary is competitive especially in light of the low cost of living in Rochester, MN.
-Benefits are plentiful and the commute is very light.
-The culture is strongly focused on providing the best care for each patient.
cons:
Winters can be harsh, but with the patient and employee subways in addition to on-site parking provided (standard for
research fellows), it is not a problem. Also, with many local state parks nearby in addition to Quarry Hill, these
locations provide great opportunities to take advantage of exploring the outdoors during these times.

headline: Excellent institution for medical training with great benefits, but in a small city with harsh winter and little to do
pros: There are few hospital systems with the prestige and innovation of the Mayo Clinic, so training here is a unique experience. You get to work with the world's experts in just about every medical specialty and sub-specialty. The salary is excellent in light of the low cost of living in Rochester, MN. Benefits are plentiful and the commute is easy. The culture is strongly focused on providing the best care for each patient.
cons: With such a large institution, bureaucracy is inevitable. There are way too many administrators disconnected from the front line clinical care who sometimes make ill-informed decisions that negatively impact patient care and physician satisfaction, even though this is a physician-led practice on the most part. The harsh winters in Minnesota is also something to behold. The bitter cold last from November to March, and it's not uncommon to have single-digit or subzero temperatures throughout the entire January.

headline: Sodexo Mayo Clinic
pros: Food service shifts for Patient Services are good for college schedules. Management will work around your schedule the best they can as long as they have enough notice.
cons: There are absolutely no benefits for part-time workers. You must apply for the full time position for benefits even if you are working full time hours.

headline: Best place
pros: everything available, work wise ! good people and management
cons: Weather and a lot fun places

headline: Incredible place to work!
pros: Excellent work environment, rewarding career, beautiful facilities, strong management, excellent benefits and great pay! Mayo Clinic is a fantastic place to work and their spot on the Fortune 100 best places to work list is very well deserved!
cons: No cons to report - I have loved my employment at Mayo Clinic!

headline: Medical Secretary
pros: Excellent benefits, reasonably good pay, consistent hours, emotionally rewarding, professional environment, training available, busing was paid for, good, healthy cafeteria food available at all times
cons: sometimes understaffed, was laid off due to downsizing, some of the doctors were very arrogant and overbearing, office culture was backstabbing and unnecessarily stressful over petty issues

headline: If your not a doctor don't expect to feel very valued
pros: Decent benefits, additional career cultivation programs
cons: Unbelievable leadership arrogance and doctor favoritism.

headline: Not a good career move for someone with prior experience
pros: As a science major, I would see this is as a good place for a first job.  But if you are looking at Mayo as a replacement to your present job, I would not recommend it unless you are coming in with a medically related background (doctor, nurse, etc.) or are moving into what you want to do for a long time.  Opportunity for advancement is not good so unless you are willing to wait, this is probably not where you want to be.  Compensation is good for what you are doing, but it comes at a big price.
cons: When you first come on board here, your prior experience means something.  Once you've been here for a time, what you did prior to coming here means little or nothing.  And movement within the organization is based on who you know, not what you know.  I can say that the job I hold has really turned me off on staying in a lab related job.

headline: The needs of the patients do not come first when it comes to patient billing.
pros: Biweekly paycheck, insurance benefits were ok. The employee cafeteria was a real advantage if you worked close enough to eat there.
cons: Very poor training, appears primary goal is to make patients pay regardless if billing is correct or not.   Departments within billing structure DO NOT help each other which in turn makes helping the patient nearly impossible.

headline: Needs of the patient come first.
pros: An inspiring environment to collaborate with world class surgeons, scientists, and healthcare professionals in order to provide the highest level of healthcare.
cons: Centralized decision-making and administrative infrastructure with decreased autonomy for individual departments.

headline: Great experience
pros: Great benefits. Great pay. Very welcoming.
cons: There really are none that I can think of.

headline: Mission Driven
pros: Mayo really does put the patient first in virtually all of their decisions, which makes for a rewarding work experience.
cons: It has added several layers of administrators over the past 10 years which has created a more bureaucratic work place and has reduced the decision-making roles of those who interact with patients the most.

headline: Loved working for Mayo Clinic as an RN.
pros: Excellent management, work loads was fair.  Company that gave a great raise every year that I worked there.  Excellent and easy to navigate benefits.  Truly felt supported by management and physicians.  Conferences and learning opportunities were encouraged and paid for.
cons: Working for such a large organization sometimes there are changes made company wide that may not make the most sense for your particular position.

headline: A place to work for physicians
pros: Great place to work for passionate docs
cons: Terrible city, bad weather, overall likely that you will have isolated life

headline: Excellent work experience.
pros: Mayo Clinic has an extremely professional work environment with state-of-the art facilities.  Collaboration within and between departments is encouraged.  Mayo also has an excellent work culture and business integrity.
cons: Parking close to your building is limited.

headline: Great Employer
pros: Salary, benefits, diversity, staff, culture, leadership
cons: Waits, staff attitude, consistency, communication

headline: My experience with the Mayo clinic was exceptional, the needs of the patients clearly come first.
pros: Very good medicine is practiced.
cons: Switching to a new electronic medical record was time consuming and stressful.

headline: Mayo Clinic
pros: World renown medical center with top patient care.
cons: Treat patients better than its employee. Research is always the second after everything else. Benefit getting worse. Politics plays everywhere.

headline: Hard working, but worth it.
pros: Health and dental Benefits, 405b/401k, vestments, PTO, etc
cons: Very internally hired- difficult to get into, frequent hiring freezes.

headline: Clinical Pharmacist
pros: Progressive thinking, abundant resources, intelligent young minds
cons: Scheduling is  and pharmacist coverage areas are always not as advertised

headline: Unpalatable --uncompetitive work place
pros: Don't see any pros. I'm in research and research is not very good here.
cons:
I have just joined Mayo as a postdoc research fellow. It's all negative from my perspective (I needed a job so I took this). 
It takes several weeks after you have accepted the offer before you can join because HR takes a long time with their internal process.
You will be required to take tests (TB etc...) and vaccinations. You have to fill out a form listing your entire vaccination history --who has that kind of information? Note this is for research staff--I'm a mathematician--I don't deal with patients.
There is a dress code--I can understand this for patient-facing physicians but for a mathematician doing research!!! This is 2014 and they expect their researchers to come to work in a suit!!
Food at the food court (yes like in a mall) is appallingly bad. I understand that this is the middle-of-nowhere- midwest but still Mayo could have made an effort.
Then of course the fact that there is nothing NOTHING attractive about Rochester. Even getting a decent cup of coffee will be a major challenge. 
The weather--less said the better.
It seems mayo has done their best in making this an extremely unpalatable experience. Congratulations.

headline: Wonderful example of caring in action.
pros: Mayo is an all-around solid organization. It treats its employees well, provides opportunities for you to be your very best and the work-life balance is awesome. They usually promote from within when it comes to job transfers also.
cons: My only con is regarding sick time. You don't really have sick time per se, so any unplanned absence is unexcused.

headline: fantastic experience
pros:
access to experts, and many different specialties of PT
part of a legacy
access to many opportunities of continuing education on campus on a daily basis as well as many research projects
able to participate or generate your own reasearch
opportunities to mentor and supervise students, there is a PT school on Campus
cons: It is a big place and sometimes it is hard to make changes for the better, the process of change just gets stuck "somewhere" in the system

headline: Nursing is challenging, rewarding, and satisfying.
pros: Salary is competitive. Benefits are satisfactory. Fellow nurses are supportive and are team players. Work offers a variety of learning experiences and there is opportunity for advancement.
cons: The work pace is fast and requires quick thinking on your feet, multitasking and real time charting in the electronic medical record.

headline: Good benefits long hours
pros: benefits are good;  salary is good.
cons: Too much uncompensated overtime with no appreciation

headline: Wonderful
pros: A lot of great people work here
cons: As in all healthcare, politics stink

headline: Every day is rewarding
pros: Caring people who love their job, and knowing that truly, the patients needs come first. Ample PTO, great management, good benefits, job stability
cons: nothing really. The benefits are not what they used to be, but still better than average

headline: World class health organization
pros: Mayo Clinic has unlimited resources and high standards within a professional and compassionate work environment. Possibilities are endless when looking for opportunities to change departments.
cons: Paid time off has become limited recently and staffing ratios are changing constantly. The leadership is strong and can sometimes be overwhelming. The atmosphere can be challenging at times, but mostly in a good way.

headline: Great company, would highly recommend.
pros: Company does great things for the community, patients and employees.  The benefits are top-notch.
cons: There is a "Mayo Culture" in Rochester.  In most areas at Mayo you have new people being hired with great new ideas, but at the same time you have the "lifers" that have been there for 20+ years and are scared of change.  This slows progress and is very detrimental to the company.

headline: Great Company to work for.
pros: Excellecent facilities and staff with a great corporate culture.
cons: Small town, not much to do for young singles.

headline: Ok place to work, great city
pros: A lot of motivated people, great city.
cons: Getting things done is like herding kittens. Work life balance is not good. Direction is muddy.

headline: Needs of the patient come first
pros: Good benefits,  pay raise annually
cons: Patients always right no matter what happened. They think its a hotel and we have to treat them as such. I felt like a character from "The Help" at times.

headline: OK place to work
pros: Benefits, pay, dedicated employees, lovely ambiance.
cons: Management / leadership is poor.

headline: Good pay, tough politics
pros: The pay is great, the benefits and facility itself are wonderful.
cons: There are a lot of hoops to jump through sometimes just to get a straight answer. The higher ups don't necessarily want to commit a direct yes or no answer to something. I've had one supervisor who was actually caught in a lie, due to something like this.

headline: A wonderful organization that truly values its patients and employees
pros: On the unit where I was employed for the summer, I felt that the staff truly did live out the motto, "the needs of the patient come first". The manager was very understanding and worked incredibly well with his staff. The other nurses on the unit seemed to really enjoy being at work each day, creating a positive and enjoyable work environment. Patient satisfaction seemed to be high, also boosting the morale on the unit. Overall, I really enjoyed my 10 week internship with this organization.
cons: Location - Rochester is somewhat small if you're coming from a large city, and also lacks affordable transportation options to other major cities. However, the Twin Cities are only a hour and a half drive away and from there you can find whatever you need, including the Minneapolis airport.

headline: Very fast paced, very encouraging, lots of growth opportunities
pros: Benefits are outstanding. They encourage growth from within and help with the cost of continuing education. Salary packages that encourage stability.
cons: Everything is black and white, there is a policy for everything.  No room for the human aspect at times.

headline: Sixteen years at Mayo, Ups and downs but overall positive experience
pros: Good work/life balance.  Ability to innovate within your scope of work as long as it doesn't cost money.  Eventually if you prove yourself it could end up being your next career move.  Mayo is well respected in medicine.  Benefits are good at the moment.  Tuition reimbursement program.  Easy living city with low stress.
cons: As of late, the focus on money has overshadowed the needs of the employees.  There is a feeling that the organization doesn't have the backs of its' employees like it once did.

headline: 24 years at Mayo Clinic
pros: Teaching Hospital with excellent Consultants. I worked here 24 years and enjoyed the patients as well as my co-workers. Excellent variety of learning opportunities and tuition reimbursement. Many employees were able to get their Graduate Degree paid for by Mayo and have never used that degree.
cons: Top heavy. I, along with over 20 RN's were "encouraged" to resign from Mayo. All of us had more than 20 years at Mayo, were at the top of the pay scale and had surgery in the past five years. We were all in our 40's as well. None of us had ever been counselled prior to this and we all had excellent reviews and were active in committees. We were able to keep part of our retirement benefits. When we refused to resign we were fired.

headline: Mayo RN Phoenix
pros: Great benefits, great leadership, very friendly and professional co-workers.  Would highly recommend this organization. Great Midwest values brought to the Southwest!
cons: Lack of advancement opportunities from bedside to administration.

headline: Great for patients, but not so much for employees
pros: Great for medical training, early career
cons: Small town, insular culture, lack of strong leadership

headline: care culture great, allied health staff culture corrosive
pros: Nice place to be at if you get sick or have a major medical issue at work.
cons: No advancement.  No growth unless personal growth.  Low salaries. Crony kingdoms and emperor builders abound.  Don't show initiative or ambition you'll be the first one shot.

headline: Challenging, fast-paced work environment with growth opportunities.
pros: Lots of opportunity for growth, learning new skills, and expanding your talents. They offer competitive pay with a standard work schedule.  Directors and supervisors encourage a strong work/life balance.
cons: Lots of change happening throughout the organization affecting nearly every department as the Health System integrates with Mayo Clinic.  With integration comes fear and anxiety and while they acknowledge fear and anxiety they fail to provide tools for helping all staff navigate the times.

headline: One of best places to work
pros: Excellent teamwork, good work-life balance, stable job
cons: Slow decision making process - needs approval from so many committees

headline: Stability
pros: The pay has been substantially better in the last few years.
cons: Insurance covers most of the raises.

headline: Scheduler
pros: You get to work at home and that is a big plus
cons: Trying to get time off can be ver frustrating

headline: Safe and Ethical without Risk; but without Challenge Also
pros: This company is the ultimate ethical company.  Treats employees well but offering basically lifetime employment unless you do something stupid.  That said, it also draws people who want the welfare experience.  Pay is at best average and therefore you draw average talent.  A rich history of quality medical practices and outcomes which has build the brand.
cons: Even though the brand is strong for the right reasons, those from the business side of things will not find a challenge here.  Decisions are made by committee on everything!  The loudest voice often gets its way in those environment, or decisions don't get made and the solution is very watered down/ineffective.  No one is willing to take a stand on anything and most everyone is risk adverse; doing time to collect a pension.  There is almost no understanding about financials in decision making.  Why?  Because a long time ago, the Mayo Brothers made Doctors the ultimate leaders.  This has its benefits when it comes to overall medical decisions and direction but when it comes to competing in other non-medical arenas that the Clinic participates in, these part-time leaders frankly are not qualified to lead.

headline: Great place to work...
pros: Stable job.. great benefits... good team work
cons:
Decisions are not made timely.. bureaucratic procedures sometimes.
No performance based incentives.

headline: Mother Mayo
pros: Mayo strives to take good care of its research staff with a good benefits package, and 60th percentile pay ranges. Strong Core labs make cutting edge research attainable.
cons: Whopping big indirect costs on research funding, and an overall second-class status for the research community in favor of the clinic and patient care at the intitution.

headline: Collaborative medical institution in the mid-sized Midwestern City
pros: Mayo Clinic is extremely collaborate, the people are great, and the access to cutting edge technology, samples, and research is top notch. Compensation is mediocre compared to other top institutions nationally, though cost of living is low. While possible, promotions need to be aggressively sought after as committee after committee needs to approve them.
cons:
Work life balance is fantastic and leadership is strong and transparent. In an age of quickly changing healthcare and basic medical research, Mayo Clinic is determined to help define the future, not follow.

If you are from a big city you will likely feel Rochester is too small, antiquated, and unfortunately just far enough away from the Twin Cities to be frustrating. The city is the biggest downside to working at Mayo Clinic from this perspective. This extends to significant others, who, if they do not work in the healthcare field will likely find other employment opportunities lacking.

headline: A mess...........
pros: Co-workers were excellent. Not much else I good I have to say .
cons: No one seemed to know what the hell they were doing most of time including upper management and administration. Upper management and administration like to micro-manage every detail of your day to day work, and then find more ways to give you work with no wage increase. Benefits were not all that great.

headline: Its a good place to work
pros: Mayo Clinic has a great reputation so its a good resume builder. The pay is great in Arizona in comparison to Banner and other medical facilities.
cons: It's more of a name than a reality. It is mostly MD managed, so decisions are generally in the favor of physicans, not support staff. They are making a lot of changes right now with the budget so it is not the Mayo Clinic that it once was.

headline: The place for a life long career
pros: Great opportunities for advancement, reimbursement for returning to school, support from coworkers and supervisors is unparalleled! Benefits surpass any other place I've ever worked. Has not laid off workers during tight budget/ recession/ etc. Definitely a company that I anticipate spending the rest of my career with!
cons: Very limited parking for those without seniority. Trying to fit 30,000 employees in a 5 block radius does not work. Most employees (except Physicians/Researchers) need 10+ years of seniority for on-site parking, otherwise subsidized/free bus passes and park and ride shuttles available.

headline: overall experience is positive
pros: Benefits, well know company to work for
cons: parking, its all abou who you know

headline: I have never been so taken care of in my life. They really care for the wellbeing of every one of their employees
pros: Supervisors try to do what they can to help you with scheduling, pursuing interests in and out of the office, and there is a great sense of community and teamwork as everyone is trying their best to do good quality work. The pay is great too.
cons: Some people have only worked for Mayo Clinic and don't know how good they have it and will complain about changes or little things that can be frustrating about every job. If you've worked anywhere else though you'll learn to just ignore the whining and continue to love how good you've got it. I think the worst thing about the entire company is trying to find parking.

headline: Mayo Clinic, the Best of the Best?
pros: Mayo offers great benefits, flexibility to your work schedule depending on where you work, wonderful job security, and pretty much guarantees you yearly salary increases.
cons: During orientation we were told that Mayo hires the best of the best.  That is flat out false.  Maybe 20 years ago that was true, but no longer.  Unfortunately it is clear that the management and leadership have no business being managers or leaders for such a large company.  They follow the "treat everyone the same" mentality which, in turn, creates a culture of mediocrity.  You can work three times as hard as the next person, but your compensation will be the same.  There is little incentive to be better than the next person.

headline: Mayo Rochester
pros: Has many job opportunites for nurses
cons: too many levels to management

headline: Going down hill in general care for the employees
pros: Great healthcare coverage, employee benefits and pretty good pay for the area. Somewhat flexible hours to be able to take off if needed.
cons: When Luther Midelfort merged with Mayo Clinic things started going down hill. Employees positions were cut or moved to Eau Claire, where employees were forced to either drive the extra 50 miles, take another position in Barron if one worked for them, or resign all together. Employees became afraid of losing their jobs despite the constant blab of how much they care for their employees and keeping them around. Many positions ended up having an over abundance of work forced upon them to avoid re-filling positions or hiring more employees. Management became far less friendly and the overall atmosphere plummeted.

headline: very good
pros: Job security, competitive compensation package, multiple locations and growing.
cons: Bureaucracy slows things down. Also sometimes, good ideas never gets implemented if it does not align with strategic imperative, but may be a great idea.

headline: Best place to work (emphatic period)
pros: Culture of inclusion, safety, family.
cons: It is in Rochester MN...

headline: Excellent place to work
pros: The general policy is to make sure staff are successful. The highest level leadership follows through supporting the mission statement of the needs of the patients come first. They have tremendous resources they employ in alignment to support the mission.  With over 34,000 employees in Rochester, there are tremendous networking opportunities with specialists in a wide variety of skill areas.
cons: The weather is cold in the winter and can get humid hot in the summer.

headline: Amazing people, company built on mutual respect.
pros: Great work atmosphere, state-of-the-art, stellar benefits, and excellent teamwork.
cons: Salary, difficult to achieve leadership roles.

headline: Simply the BEST!
pros: Fun Co-workers, supervisors that are approachable, pay is better than other health care facilities in the area, benefits are AMAZING!!! 401K, 403B and pension, not to mention totally affordable insurance with excellent coverage, opportunity to grow and learn about the new and latest medical advances. Still gives employees annual raises despite major changes within the health field. Feels great to work to a not for profit company. Stills offers tuition reimbursement and encourages continued education, one of my favorite perks. Open to new ideas and willing to try out employee ideas to be even better.
cons: waiting outside in the winter for a shuttle bus to the park and ride. Company is also under the same pressure as every other medical facility on the U.S.

headline: While the job duties increase, the pay conitnues to remain frozen.
pros: Good benefits package and paid Holidays. I enjoyed working from home and being able to flex my schedule to balance work and family.
cons: Being outsourced out of a job. Having a freeze in wages. Working from home can be difficult as well, as it's too easy to forget you're speaking to real people.

headline: Okay
pros: Amazing Care. Best place to be if you are sick.
cons: Conservative managment style and low pay.

headline: I enjoyed working for Mayo Clinic Health System
pros: Excellent caring people to work with
cons: Lots of layers of management

headline: Best employer in healthcare industry
pros: Excellent benefits. Career growth opportunities. Respect by administration
cons: Takes longer to get promoted as current leaders are very satisfied in their positions and are not easily moved.

headline: Mayo Experience
pros:
Good compensation package.
Midwestern values
Encourages furthering education
Constantly changing environment
cons:
Management issues
Benefits packages keeps getting reduced
Run by committee

headline: Problems and Opportunities at Mayo Clinic
pros: good benefits,internationally recognized,superior care in most areas.
cons: Nurses have very little leeway with clinical decision making. Top-heavy.Nurses are expected to run unnecessary tests to get the institution to get more money or paranoia about lawsuits, or both..

headline: high pressure research environment, high volume of patient access making clinical research the place to be
pros: Access to human specimen and diverse patient population.  Lots of smart, driven clinician-researcher, making it THE best place to do translational research.
cons: low career mobility for PhD scientists. Takes long time to get tenure.

headline: Systems Engineer
pros: The Belief at being the Best is instilled throughout the organization.
cons: Decisions take too long to make. Opportunities are lost in the process.

headline: Life changing career.
pros: The best that health care has to offer.  Working here you can tell there is a difference in how they approach health care.  This is the place people come to get answers.
cons: The only real con is hearing back from human resources is painfully slow in a company of 40k employees.  Be patient, they get a lot of applications for the jobs they post and there is a reason for that.

headline: Good and bad
pros: Prestigious name, good benefits and decent pay
cons: A lot of attention is paid to quality of care for patients, but very little is spent on taking care of employees.  Like most healthcare institutions (I imagine), there is always a strain for fewer providers to see more patients.  That makes the clinic more money, but burns out the people who care for these patients.

headline: Mayo is all about the name And not about there employees
pros: The company appears to care about there employees but the company cares more about the mayo name. Human resources is a joke
cons: They fell that you are there's and family and safe work environment   I.e. language is very bad.

headline: Good place to work and job security
pros: Job security, good salary and benefit
cons: No movement, no productivity measures, some people work and some do not but they do not loose their jobs because of lack of productivity.

headline: Rewarding Career
pros: Stable organization, lots of opportunities for advancement
cons: very slow decision making, losing sight of their core business

headline: My experience with Mayo Clinic has been very good and rewarding.  The needs of our patients do come first.
pros: The diversity that comes with a large company is always beneficial.  Collaboration and respectful behavior as an expectation makes work more enjoyable and creates trust.
cons: The strength of a large corporation can very quickly become it's weakness. Finding the balance is a key factor in its success, particularly with regards to staff satisfaction and retention. Disrespectful behavior should be dealt with more consistently, particularly among leadership.

headline: Good
pros: The benefits are excellent, including medical insurance, paid time off, discounts, back-up childcare, and 401K. Salary is above average and there is always room for advancement and able to apply to new positions every year or two.
cons: Conservative environment despite the "diverse atmosphere" they claim to have.

headline: so so
pros: good medical benefits, really good work/life balance
cons: No careers opportunities as a scientist, not valued unless an MD, low salry

headline: Great place to work
pros: Friendly enviroment, top medical services
cons: Winter is too cold and long

headline: Great new facility with top of the line equipment and latest technology.
pros: Professional environment, latest technology, excellent educational department for nurses.
cons: Unfortunately politics affected management decisions and occasionally had a negative impact on staff.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Location is good and especially for raising kids. Very good reputation for its quality medicine.
cons: It is Not a very bad concern: Minnesota has too long winter. Other two Mayo Clinic location is exception.

headline: mammography technologist
pros: wonderful new hospital, beautiful location
cons: H.R. didn't support employees fairly

headline: Excellent Company
pros: Great Benefits, great atmosphere, pay raise after a year. Loved working here!
cons: There are strict clock-in policies and infraction policies.

headline: Great name recognition, but could do with more benefits
pros: Great presentations and guest speakers, nice local environment
cons: Always feeling like someone is watching you, low salary compared to other parts of U.S. for similar work, few vacation days

headline: Great place to work!
pros: The needs of the patient come first. Staff members are well respected. Strong sense of culture. Amazing things happen here every day.
cons: Historical manner of handling employee issues is the go-to solution. Employee policies do not always seem to fit all employee types yet they are written to group everyone together.

headline: Pervasive, altruistic culture, great working environment
pros: Everyone knows why they work at Mayo, and they are proud of it.  The benefits and general working environment are top-notch without feeling like they are throwing away money.
cons: Such a huge organization, your ability to access upper management is limited.  Mid-level managers are quite competent.

headline: A bit conservative
pros: Great benefits. The organization is smoothly run because work is so well-delegated. Professionalism and the needs of the patient are strongly emphasized.
cons:
The culture seems a bit conservative.
Mayo Clinic golden handcuffs...

headline: Overall it is an okay place to work
pros:
The benefits are still good, although over the last few years there have been changes and cuts in benefits.
The payscale is par for this type of job nationwide
cons:
Too many politics
Too many small minded people here
Too much criticism over your personal life
Too much emphasis on things are super-facial and not patient related

headline: Organization culture needs improvement
pros: Professional enviroment.  Diversity creates sense of community made up of understanding respeful people.  Depending on the individual PI (immediate Boss) give positive experiences.  Lucky to have good mentor but if you get a bad mentor then it will be in the cons!
cons: Top Management levels do not really seem to care about employees.  Decisions are made independent of hand-on working individuals.  HR is not transparent and do not encourage improvement of employee's satisfaction.  No reward for working harder than describe job description since pay is only based on years of working at Mayo.  The salaries do not reflect result or performance.  It lacks career advancement due to misunderstanding of research needs.  Business personnel making decisions of sciences needs are not a way to go.

headline: Allied Health Staff member for more than 20 years
pros: I'm proud to work with some of the best leaders in healthcare!  Salary is good, benefits are good, I feel valued in my work.
cons: There is a lot of middle management and micro management, and there are some bad apples that don't belong here.

headline: Outstanding
pros: Great place to work.  They truly care about their employees and work as a team.
cons: I cannot think of anything to report.  This is a great facility and everyone there truly cares about the needs of the patient and expects quality care from all of their employees.

headline: All in all, a good place to work.
pros: Good benefits and pretty good pay.  Rochester is a great place to live.  Mayo stresses that "the needs of the patient come first", and they do live up to that standard.
cons: Raises not tied to job performance, but are based on your position and time with the company.  Downtown parking is a nightmare.  Whether you can even park downtown or need to be bused in is based on time with the company.

headline: If I were a doctor I would be treated better.
pros: Job security, there isn't much more than that.
cons: Benefits have decreased, Management doesn't care about the people, only about money.

headline: Mother Mayo is turning into Big Business Mayo
pros:
Working at one of the premier health care facilities in the world.
Can really make a difference in people's lives.
cons: Having been part of the Mayo culture for over 30 years I can tell you that working here is no longer the prize it used to be. There used to be a sense of community and family - "Mother Mayo". Now it's a corporation and very much feels like one from the inside.

headline: Overall, Mayo is a nice organization to work for.
pros: great resources at your disposal; high collaborative environment; and pretty relaxed ambiance
cons: The politics in this place is very suffocating!

headline: Solid Organization but a bit old fashioned
pros: Friendly coworkers, stable company, positive organization that does a lot of good.
cons: Very old fashioned and up-tight culture.

headline: Great Organization
pros: Great people to work with, and connection With Mayo Clinic is awesome.
cons: The departments are management heavy.

headline: Mayo stands behind their employees.
pros:
Work/Life balance
Diversity of work
Appreciated for what you do
cons: There are too many committees

headline: A wonderful, international place to work.
pros: Great benefits, great culture, and inspiring coworkers.
cons: Location is tough for couples whose spouses are in different industries than health care.

headline: My Twelve Years at Mayo Clinic
author_position: Ingénieur/Inspecteur Prévention Des Risques Incendie Et Sécurité Gaz
pros: No weekend work. Good people to work with. Very good PTO and worked with your personal life as needed
cons: The main campus was in Rochester, MN. Projects would start and be shelved frequently.  Too many administrators who knew nothing of supply logistics.

headline: Not as Prestigious as It Purports Itself To Be
pros: Decent Benefits- Pay is OK
cons:
Non Clinical Staff members are treated poorly
Merit Increases are small or non-existent

headline: Great Atmosphere, horrible pay
pros:
Relaxed atmosphere (in my department)
Recognition for accomplishments and achievements
cons:
Horrible pay
Little chance for advancement in the Health System

headline: A Great Place to Work ... Only if you are a Medical Professional
pros: Exceptional pay for the area, outstanding health benefits, pension (vested after three years) employee resource groups promoting diversity.
cons: If you are part of 'allied health staff', which basically means anyone not providing direct patient care, you are not considered important.  Poor management. They are attempting to manage cross sites and are clueless.  Leadership does not care about working conditions and employee morale; when concerns are brought up, employees are told to they are free to move to another company.  Limited advancement opportunities for those who want to grow with the company.

headline: Great experience
pros: Lots of experience, many research cores available to use.
cons: Was only offered a part time position after applying and interviewing for a full time position.

headline: Mayo is a good place to work.
pros: Good pay, good hours.  Encourages further education and personal improvement.
cons: Lack of leadership in some divisions.  Failure to follow through on promises for increased opportunities.

headline: IT
pros: Great people. Great learning experiences.
cons: Managers too busy creating their "kingdoms." More about power than anything else.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Dedicated to the best interests of the patients while still looking out for each and every one of the employees as well
cons: Sometimes focused on a bigger picture that leaves the individuals left out of the process

headline: Mayo clinic is the best place to work
pros:
Salary
Health Benefits
Friendly staff and Management
You get lots of respect and recognition.
Job satisfaction for those who want to serve humanity
cons: None of which I can think of

pros: Beautiful Hospital, good food, free CEUs.
cons: Non medical staff very unwelcoming.

headline: Financial Analyst III
pros: ability to work on your own pace
cons: growth prospects very limited in finance

headline: Good place to work, but not as amazing as they let on
pros: The pay is above average, the benefits are great. Some of the people are very nice and friendly. They pay for your uniform once every year for a pca and they pay for all classes you may need to take for your job (such as CPR). I just love working with those patients that you grow a bond with :)
cons: They make it seem like this amazing place to work, where everyone is always happy and friendly. They sweep under the rug certain, however. Some of the people are very full of themselves and have an attitude. I have lived in Minnesota for most of my life and I don't really care for the area nor the people...sorry.

headline: Mayo clinic
pros: Excellent healthcare when you need it.
cons: Allows mediocrity at every level.  Wont deal with poor performers.

headline: Fantastic environment and benefits, with a few caveats
pros:
- Great benefits (health insurance, pay ...)
- Mayo's name is well-known and will potentially open doors for your future career
- Certain departments are very efficient and their performances are top notch
cons: - Mayo has a distinct culture, sometimes almost hypocritical; this is something that you either deal with or leave it altogether

headline: A lot of bravado
pros:
Layed back work environment
Very flexible
Love the primary value - "the needs of the patient come first," which for the most part the organization tried to deliver on.
cons:
It was over six years before I got a performance review, which my manager was lousy at doing.  However, others did get performance reviews and were then promoted.  So basically, if your manager likes you and your personality you will get ahead.
Favoritism is common place.
Everybody gets a raise…nothing is based one's performance, so everyone eventually becomes complacent.
Mayo was a "physician lead" organization, but has become a physician MANAGED organization.  As a result, decisions take for ever and they are slow to respond to fast changing market conditions.

headline: Good Place to for anyone to work great place for the medical staff
pros: The culture is probably the largest postive in my mind. I can say that everyone in a leadership role, that I have encountered, is both kind and empathetic to the needs of of the employee. They still have solid benefits even though they have been reduced from there previous levels. Their pay is competitive and their campuses are pristine.
cons: Their scheduling systems are challenging to work within, at least at the site that I work at, because of the high demand for both physician and testing resources. It is a difficult game that administration plays with the marketing of the brand and the reality of what is possible.

headline: Don't be conned by the MC reputation
pros:
No one gets laid off (a pro but also a con)
One if the last employers to offer benefits
cons:
Intensely political atmosphere
Zero ability for those at mid-management level to make decisions or have recommendations taken seriously
Lack of vision for the future
Ideas from outside Mayo are thoroughly crushed by old-timers
Physicians have poor business sense

headline: What happened?
pros:
Mayo Clinic in the historic sense beams excellence.  Incredible minds and technology have been developed here.  Not too long ago that intellect and zeal were almost palpable in what could more-or-less be called the crown jewel of the city of Rochester.  I was honored to continue these traditions through my work and dedication at a place in aesthetics, aptitude, and psyche was an example for the medical community. 

Mayo Clinic offers excellent compensation for your time and very competitive benefits.  Its one of the few places I have worked at that still offers a pension, affordable medical insurance, several weeks of vacation upon starting, and decent lateral movement should you want to do so.  

Mayo once offered a foundation by which you could make life long plans and aspirations.
cons:
So what happened?

Mayo Clinic for the last few decades has continuously degraded by mediocrity, preferential treatment, poor implementation, ghost riding, and lack of vision. Mayo has been riding on the ghosts of its accomplished past.

A career at Mayo Clinic is an enigmatic one.  On one side of the coin you will be enthralled to work with able minded people who are not only skillful in the craft of science but who legitimately have passion for patient centered research and care.  I have had the pleasure of seeing people with drive who have worked from the ground up from a simple technician to become an administrator or even Ph. D, as I am currently working on.  The other side of the coin includes select consultants, senior/middle management, and even mid/low level scientists seem to think that once you get your “Golden Ticket” to Mayo you simply put your heart and mind into neutral and coast to maintain the status quo.  There are many wallflowers that only care about the bottom line: their paycheck or personal status.

While Mayo Clinic fosters brilliant and effective minds, there are just as many if not more that are busy waiving their “Golden Tickets.”  My time has been plagued with a few pampered consultants who verbally and psychologically abuse you, entitled management who are woefully under-equipped in wisdom/aptitude, and salaried/hourly technologists who get away with harassment or being paid for flat out not contributing.  You may as well not report incidences like these, since at any rung of the aforementioned nothing will change.  Rocking the boat puts you at risk for retaliation, ridicule, being overlooked for a promotion, etc.

The current status of Mayo Clinic would be as one of my colleagues put it, “…we have too many chiefs and not enough Indians.”  When you answer to many people, some of who may be inept or incommunicado with their own contemporaries, avoidable mistakes are made, inefficiencies continue to build, decisions that may be completely dangerous to patient care are created, and the overall mission of Mayo Clinic, “…the needs of the patient come first,” continue to diminish.  At the end of the day the blame is usually assigned to the easiest target or those too meek to defend themselves.

Mayo’s initial answer to the economic environment in 2008 was lethargic.  Excessive spending on parties, other frivolity, and business as usual continued.  Fast forward to 2013 and Mayo is virtually in a panic over cost control due to being overextended at the cost of morale of its employees and patients.  Benefits large and small continue to shrink or have disappeared completely.  Forward thinking and preparing for fiscal pumps in the road, not banking on changes in philanthropic donations, having MML be fiercely competitive with other health systems, ceasing kingdom building projects, etc. were not a part of the equation until lately.  

Mayo is finally starting to take the punch bowl from its own party.  The problem is that while Mayo has been partying for the last 20 years the competition has become a lot smarter and leaner, where Mayo has become slow due to its own convoluted bureaucracy and over indulgence.  The withdrawals are very hard everyone especially for those that actually work very hard, since those perks were the things keeping the talent here. 

In the years I have been here I have seen magnificent individuals of all levels of employment be crushed by the current of “Mother Mayo’s” will.  When your lifestyle depends on who writes your paycheck, you always see the zombie like following of Mayo either too scared, too indoctrinated, or too burnt out to care to resist the crumbling paradigm that is the psyche of Mayo Clinic.

headline: nightmare
pros: Health insurance and Paid Time Off were good, involvement in community activities was nice (if you don't mind walking in a lot of parades that is)
cons: MCHS preches open culture, needs of the patient come first... at the location I was employed at that open culture sure has a long way to go. Managers have meeting to talk about meetings which is all they do all day long. Organization as far a defining roles still has much work to be done. Management was like a big band of brothers if one was displeased they all would be in some way. Employees are stretched very thin.

headline: Overall good company.
pros: Generous benefit programs you will not find anywhere else.
cons: New changes are slow to come down the pike because it is a large organization.

headline: Great place, and great people.
pros: Great environment good peploe willing to what is best for patients.
cons: Conservative, and stuffy sometimes, but the good outweighs that.

headline: Great place to get your care from quality people who care!
pros: Many great benefits working a t this large organization. Many choices if change wanted.
cons: Good ole' boys networking still exists.

headline: RN
pros: great training, great Dr's to work with
cons: I hate the white scrubs!

headline: Mayo Clinic cares about its patients and its employees, cultivating a culture of kindness and excellence.
pros: My supervisors and most of my other fellow employees are great, which is not just chance - it is the product of the company culture that Mayo Clinic cultivates, starting with orientation for several days. They try to keep pay above average and give good benefits. They require continuing education and encourage moving up within the company, even between departments.
cons: Annual pay increases are dependent upon meeting certain requirements - basically doing your job competently. You are always made aware of what those expectations are and where your performance is lacking. If you don't negotiate a higher pay when hired on, it's difficult to increase it other than through those annual fixed (percentage) pay bumps.

headline: It's a job
pros: It's non-profit, lower pressure type situation.  If you live in Rochester, it's not a bad gig.
cons: Living outside of Rochester there is some bias against the rest of the organization.  They are starting to feel the pressure of the Affordable care act, and having to make decision not previously required.

headline: Mayo
pros: Helping others who are ill
cons: Nothing much else in Rochester except Mayo and IBM.  If you want to do any shopping that's not picked over you need to go someplace else.

headline: Not for independent thinkers.
pros:
Decent pay. 
Hard to get fired simply because you're incompetent.
cons:
Bottom line comes first, patients second, and employees a distant third. 
Was told "not to rock the boat" by several people within a week of moving to Rochester. The scary part is that some of them were not mayo employees but had heard enough to know what the culture of the institution was like.  They weren't wrong. Incompetent cool aid drinkers are invariably preferred over those from "elsewhere" who bring uncomfortable new ideas and practice suggestions with them.

headline: I guess it's Ok
pros: nice coworkers, nice clinical buidings, nice volunteers, nice equipments, many workshops. I like the skyways, which can lead to many places, including library, parking, etc.
cons:
I don't think the compensation and benefit is good compared to others, at least in my case. 
Work: isolated, without communications, no natural light. can't see career growth.

headline: deep traditions
pros:
Deeply committed employees
The patient comes first
cons:
Dangerously introspective organization
Largely discounts the world outside

headline: Very professional.  Managed well.
pros: Plenty of career and educational opportunities .
cons: Pay scale is above average and challenging business structure.

headline: Ok
pros: Macro-managed, friendly management, flexible, understanding of work life balance
cons: The facility needs to learn to work together

headline: Current employee IT
pros: Have a hard time getting fired - no matter what you do
cons: Backwards technology, way too many inefficiences and total lack of procedure, architectural principles.  Most of my peers are stuck in the 80s and early 90s

headline: Dedicated employer...Not so sure.
pros: Pay and bennefits are good.
cons: Upper management is more sneaky and controling of its employees than the pretend to be. This organization is not as supportive and understanding of their employees as they lead on to be.

headline: Terrible company to work with
pros: Interesting work and amazing doctors. Outstanding health insurance benefits. A position that encourages very little creativity or ingenuity. There is only one way to solve every problem and that is the Mayo way.
cons: Office politics is over the top! HR only protects incompetent mangers with complete disregards of patients and employees. The Peterson principal is in full display in every layer of management! Turn over in some departments is 98% per year. Several patient scandals have occurred as a result of lack of trust and openness among staff. There is always retaliation for speaking out! Thinking out side of the box is ostracized and will lead to termination.

headline: Retired Nurse after 25 years at Mayo Clinic
pros: Working at Mayo Clinic provided me with a large variety of experiences with  many different kinds of patients and rare disease processes. I also learned the differences in working with consultants, residents and fellows, a teaching hospital. Good benefits, nice workout facility.  I saw Mayo Clinic change dramatically. There was a huge difference when the Sisters of St. Francis were managing the hospital, they made sure the patient's always got excellent care including the details. The hospital has teams for starting IV's, putting in urinary catheters and drawing labs, as a nurse you can call a team to take care of those things for you.  Excellent consultants if you are lucky enough to see them. All of their facilities are very clean and well organized.
cons: Small but critical things fall through the cracks. Inexperienced Residents are not closely supervised  by the consultants. I have experienced this both as a staff member and as a patient. Medications errors by the MD, and when followed up on are brushed under the rug. Discharge summaries that state that the patient is being discharged with home health or hospice care and the discharge planner or MD have not even consulted with the agency, they just tell the patient to call someone when they get home. Patients feel "pushed out the door". They have discharge planning nurses that have never even seen the patient and are making referrals. The clinic is focused on checklists and procedural guidelines that are written by nurses who have not worked with patients for over 20 years. They actually have a committee on committee's, lots of wasted time and money with administration and time and money taken away from quality patient care. I was so proud to work for Mayo....it is sad to see the lack of attention to details. I spent 75% of my time as a staff nurse charting and 25% of my time doing patient care.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Friendly environment, variety of benefits
State-of-the art science
Many research opportunities
cons: Limited opportunities to achieve permanent position

headline: An amazing company in every regard--patient experience, career mobility, commitment to staff and mission-driven.
pros: Investment in employees in every regard--stability, career mobility, salary/benefits, learning/education opportunities, teamwork, industry leader, resources to excel in your job, and on and on and on...
cons: Culture is not for everyone...but, if you are a fit, it will be your last employer (you won't want to look anywhere else)!

headline: At Mayo, Patient Care is the #1 Priority
pros: Stability, Decent Salary, Friendly Working Enviroment
cons: in Rochester Minnesota. Not a lot of activities outside of work

headline: Have never been treated better
pros:
Salary is better than anywhere else in Minnesota for a new graduate
Relocation assistance
Great benefits
cons: The city has little to offer other than the hospital

headline: Disappointing Recruiting Experience, Not Living the Mayo Values
pros: If you have hope that Mayo will truly live up to its values and new ideas will be welcomed, then give Mayo a chance
cons:
Poor follow up
Wasted my time with a poorly facilitated panel interview
Took forever to get my expenses reimbursed, almost $500 took 6 eeks to reimburse

headline: Mayo Clinic is a wonderful employer and offers many opportunities for educational growth and has competitive salaries.
pros: Mayo Clinic has many wonderful benefits, and one of those benefits is parking priviledge after approximately 10 years of service. Mayo pays subsidies for riding commuter buses for employees who work away from Rochester.
cons: At times Mayo can be beaurocratic and can be political.

headline: Fantastic employer
pros: Fantastic work life balance. An institutions with a mission and core values you can feel proud of. The commitment to the staff is amazing.
cons: Mayo does not provide financial incentives for job well done. The same raise calculation is used regardless of performance.

headline: Would the Mayo Brothers be disappointed?  Probably.
pros:
Mayo Clinic has many great things going for it.  You have the opportunity to work with some world class minds and equipment.  Making lateral movements within the foundation is a viable option even if it takes some time.  The compensation is geared to keep people for the long term, the benefits are reasonable (provided you receive treatment at a Mayo facility), and the fact you are associated with the Clinic in general allows many perks with insurance, discounts, etc.

On paper the mission statement that drives the direction of the Clinic "...the needs of the patient come first..." sounds wonderful.  The "Three Shields" concept is motivating: Practice, Education, & Research.  There are many people that are intelligent, driven, and truly do care about the direction of the medical field to enhance patient care, satisfaction, and experience.  When you find those people, hold onto them, as they are your true resource to experience the vision that the founding Mayo Brothers had.

While the location of Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN, itself is a little boring, it has the feel of a small town with some of the conveniences of a large city, which isn't such a bad thing if you have a family.
cons:
Mayo Clinic is a bureaucratic hell.  There is enough unnecessary red tape to suffocate any and every respirating organism on the planet.  At times getting access to equipment, funding, and personnel for clinical research can be a struggle, whereas another colleague can request the same thing and literally have it almost instantaneously.  Mayo Clinic is very much a who you know community rampant with nepotism, favoritism, and other inequities.

The "Mayo Mantra" is to speak up when you as an employee have comments, questions, or concerns.  This can be to your detriment given the aforementioned, and I speak of this in a completely neutral fashion.  You don't have to be forceful, rude, or considered a "problem" to be the recipient of severe backlash should your viewpoints contradict a member of management's or a consultant's (doctor's) opinion.  Suggesting something, even altruistically, can come back to bite you the higher up you go in the Foundation's food-chain.

Despite encountering intelligent, driven, and compassionate individuals for every one of them there are 20 who care nothing of innovation.  People with whom I have spoken with that have been with the Clinic for decades and from my own experiences have shown there are plenty of hourly, salaried, and management staff members who care nothing more than to maintain the status quo and their paycheck.  Some individuals get away with terrorizing other employees or flat out not working regardless of how many times they are reported.  This has been observed in lower to mid level management as well.  Mediocrity can be a problem, and from what I have seen these are the people that get promoted.

The management system is stifling, where they have more say or pull than the scientists and consultants for whom the patients actually come to see for care.  Having multiple people with whom you report to often leads to contradiction to the point where you spend more time finding out how to navigate around these confutations to finally get to producing something valuable to the Clinic.  Do they have meetings to schedule meetings more than they should?  You bet.  Management of my department has admitted to having hour long discussions of words like "tardy."  Really?  Webster could define that in moments.  We use the private donation and visiting patient's money for that?  More often than not people that aren't even remotely your equivalent in experience or education level will be in charge of you, who will request you to do something that is either completely wrong or in some instances dangerous.  During your time in research you may find yourself continuously baffled as to why people that would be perfect candidates for these positions tell you that they applied for "that job" only to be turned down many times.

Mayo reacts like an overactive immune response to problems that could be solved with simply firing a issue employee.  Example: if one employee is constantly leaving early and reporting they are staying much later Mayo remedies this by punishing everyone to a new time keeping system.  What was once a flexible and amicably maintained perk in the interest of the patient and Clinic has now become almost completely inflexible.

Mayo Clinic as a whole is in some respects still living in the past and riding on its name too much.  The world is changing and Mayo's competition is growing in aptitude at a better price point.  "Mother Mayo" seems to think she is the entire cosmos when in reality she is still a microcosm.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Loved working with the team.
cons: It's in Rochester, so not great for location. Rochester is great, but small town in the middle of corn field country.

headline: Very satisfied and love to work here
pros: Job satisfaction, Job stability - lots of good points to mention
cons: None to mention for now

headline: Mayo Clinic is a good place to work
pros: Very professional and good for career growth
cons: I don't find any cons at this place.

headline: not a good place to grow
pros: good amount of time off and fair pay
cons: hard work and education not valued as much as age and years of service

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great place to work and learn
cons: Change can be slow with a large hospital

headline: It was a pleasant experience with a HUGE learning curve but achievable.
pros: GREAT BENEFITS. GREAT HOURS at the CLINIC in Scottsdale. Disciplined.Innovators. The BEST of everything to work with in Nuclear Med.
cons: Military style of leadership. Rigidity.

headline: RN
pros: enjoy helping patient feel better
cons: Could get really stressful at times

headline: World class physicians but a lot of cronyism and incompetent middle management.
pros: Good work life balance, yes
cons: It really helps to be someone's nephew, brother, son etc to get ahead

headline: Not a place for growth
pros: Good work/life balance. Great benefits
cons: No opportunities for growth. Specifically our dept is cheap.

headline: World renowned healthcare
pros: Be a part of a second-to-none institution that treats its employees like gold
cons: Need more non-patient care areas (lounges, courtyards, gardens, etc.)

headline: Not my best career move
pros:
Excellent place for a recent grad to get some experience out of college
Pays well for market
cons:
Management hires people w/o plan in place on how to train, etc.
Very little movement between areas inside the firm (easier to move up within your group)
