Company does not do much to retain quality employees (no plan in place to do so)
Seems like they see your entire resume before they hire you but once you are here, it is almost like the part of your resume longer exists (only what you do here counts)
Depends on the company's name too much to get/keep you

headline: Used to be good, going downhill very fast
pros: They payed well in my field, otherwise I would have never stayed so long.
cons: Where do I start?  Mayo used to be a pretty good workplace, unfortunately it's been changing for the worse since the early 00's.  The workload is increasing exponentially, and the hiring doesn't follow.  Useless training, procedural steps and policies are constantly piling up, without improving workflow or productivity (think of the movie "Office Space").   Good employees are getting completely demotivated and burned out, lazy employees know they can get away with doing hardly any work , since Mayo never fires for poor performance.  A supervisor once told me with a straight face that some employees in her unit were trained only for the easier duties only because they couldn't handle the complexity of the task / the workload / the stress.  It  would imply that more capable and smarter co-workers were expected to pick up the slack..... for the same pay.  I finally realized things were not likely to improve, even if I transfered  to another unit (I am not saying that there are absolutely no well-managed work units at Mayo, but they are excessively rare).  I am now living in a different state.  I make about 60% of what I was making at Mayo, but in return I am keeping my health and my sanity.

headline: It is a good place for Clinic and Research
pros: Strength: Value and Benefit. And it has a nice surroundings and is located in a very beautiful town.
cons: Networking and family, especially the long winter season.

headline: Mayo? More like MICRO...
pros: Great Pay, awesome Benefits, ALOT of potential!
cons: Terrible leaders on the department level, overly micro-manged from the length of your dress socks to the fact that one second late is an occurrence.

headline: Multifaceted
pros: Mayo provides wonderful benefits for its employees, job security is stellar, some of the people who work here are the best in their fields.
cons: As a contractor, you don't get access to really any benefits, the pay for contractors is low taking into consideration that you don't have benefits. The trajectory for upward career advancement is limited due to competition and low transition of upper level managers.

headline: Financial Representative
pros: Mayo has great benefits for all employees, way better than previous employers I've had. Generous PTO, health/dental/vision insurance, tuition reimbursement, back up daycare, sick child daycare, employees get discounts at several businesses around town, etc.
cons: My particular position is a call center which is very reptitious and gets old fast.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Great health benefits, mix of small town and metropolitan lifestyles.
cons: Midwest backdrop makes for a slightly slower pace of life/work.

headline: Senior Research Fellow
pros: nice city, great institute, palms
cons: no benefits, cafeteria, too small waves in the ocean

headline: Excellent training, great experience, and a good name to have on your record.
pros: At Mayo, you will work hard but you won't be treated like a slave. The facilities and equipment are well above average. People from other labs and departments are extremely helpful. If you do your part, your PI will do all he/she can to get your work published.
cons: You may fall in love with Mayo, but they won't fall in love with you. Start planning your next position as soon as you start your postdoc position here. Postdocs are strictly temporary employees, if you're lucky, you may get to stay 3 years.

headline: Amazing for patients, horrible for staff.
pros:
Access to some of the best doctors around.
Exposure to the latest trends in medicine.
Great place to expand your skill set as a RN.
cons:
Way to many chiefs and not enough Indians.
Management is completely clueless when it comes to the way in which the various units work which in turn causes many unsafe patient assignment loads and staffing across the units.  
The staff at the Florida campus is treated like red headed step children within the organization and not offered the same compensation and benefits as the other two campuses.
Management would rather let an employee leave (after the $70k it cost to orient them) than to make changes offered up by various staff members.

headline: Poor management, too many chiefs!
pros:
Clients are wonderful
Nice to be out in the field all day and away from administration
You get to donate hours of your time unpaid and away from your family!
cons:
Micromanage you to death
There is no sharing of information between departments so you repeat the same things 10 times
Nursing supervisor and nursing admin do not care about you as a person

headline: Overrated
pros: Pays very well, and takes a lot to get fired.
cons: Poor managment. Afraid of "change". People are not treated equally.

headline: Feel like I stepped back in time 15years
pros:
a paycheck
employee discounts
tuition reinburstment
no pressure that you will lose your job
clean hospital
cons: i have worked in major institutions all over the US and this has to be one of the most unprogressive orginizations in the country, I have a hard time calling it a hospital, it's more like big business, ideas are dated,ideas take multiple committees to go through to get approved and then they are outdated,equipment is outdated,slackers don't get fired,you can work here forever and not worry about losing your job,I tell people all the time that once you go out of the tri state area(WI,ND,IA) alot of people have never heard of the Mayo Clinic, don't care and get just as good or better care,Mayo lives in this fantasy world that everyone want's to come to Mayo, sorry I burst your bubble,hard to get seasoned employees from the outside, they tend to hire students from there schools(in allied health esp) so they can "Mold" them to the Mayo Way!!!!!

headline: Busy
pros: Mayo is highly respected in the medical community.
cons: to the point where employee's are disposible, rather than valued for past and current work experience.

headline: The experience of working at Mayo is awesome!
pros: Opportunities for learning are awesome. Tuition reimbursement has allowed me to continue my education and advance my career.  Compensation packages are reasonable.
cons: Parking is an issue! We live in a cornfield and have to ride a bus from a Wal-Mart parking lot!  Communication in such a large institution is sometimes marginal and recognition is limited.

headline: "Regretful!!"
pros: Benefits, great educational support w/Library providing assistance with articles and so forth. Tuition reimbursement is one of the best in the Nation for an employer! Amazing Gym for staff at a very reasonable price. As a nurse, I've worked elsewhere and I must give credit where it deserves credit. There is good open communication between nurses and "residents" but zero with the consultants. Consultants here are the Staff doctors, and most of them 98% walk with their noses up in the air never acknowledging the nurses who care for their patients. Rochester is a very safe, small, no traffic kind of town. If you have kids, this is the place you can appreciate living in. If you are single, don't get your hopes up.
cons: No Parking for new staff. If you work a 7A shift, you basically have to wake up at 5A to get here on time, and that's only if you live in TOWN!!! No diversity what so ever, and Minnesotan Nice is not nice at all! Too many two faced people here. I'm not saying that there aren’t any hypocrites anywhere else, but nothing like this place! A very bureaucratic management and advancement opportunities for nurses are limited. It certainly is about who you know and how well you've gotten along with your nurse manager to move up the ladder. If you've never worked anywhere else but Mayo you will not feel competent to work anywhere else after working here. Nurses don't start IV, or even put foley cathers in! They have a "team" for all of this. At first this may seem nice for you that you don't have to worry about doing this, but when you need an IV STAT, good luck! They give you less patients to care fore than other hospitals, but you will be doing a lot more than your nursing role to make up for that. Nurses here change linens, bathe your patients in a shower not just in bed, feed your patients and do your strict I&O, and sometimes get paid to sit in a combative patient's room as a one to one, because they don't have patient sitters here. Oh and to top it off, you'll also be a social worker calling Nursing homes to hold patient's bed and arrange home health Oxygen and so forth. Basically, they call this "Primary Nursing." I would have to say the ultimate con in this workplace is the lack of diversity and way too much back stabbing and triangulation. If you are not from the Midwest, don't ever move here! You will regret it!! Go to Jacksonville or Arizona but don't ever think of coming to this frozen land!!

headline: Good
pros: Mayo provides very good benefits; particularly for research staff I has 18 conference days. Health and other  benefits are good as well. Very collegial environment.
cons: Visible signs of inefficiencies as people are here for forever. This often results in a simple task taking unreasonably long time.

headline: Very good
pros: Very good benefits, doing research in cutting-edge field, good name
cons: Administrative system is a little bit sluggish and inefficient, but not a big problem.

headline: Its a job.
pros: Benefits, healthcare and tuition reimbursement
cons: abilities to expand your career
